Oxford transcription team, 1992-1998: Peter Robinson, Elizabeth Solopova, Lorna Stevenson, with contributions from James McCabe, Hubert Stadler, Cathy Swires, Paul and Maureen Watry, Laura Wright, Diana Wyatt and Simon Horobin
Sheffield transcription team, 1992-1998, led by Norman Blake: Michael Pidd and Estelle Stubbs, with Linda Cross, Claire Thomson and Simon Horobin
De Montfort transcription team, 1998-2005: Peter Robinson, Barbara Bordalejo, Orietta Da Rold, Gavin Cole, Pip Willcox, Jennifer Marshall, Takako Kato, Jacob Thaisen, Nicole Green
University of Saskatchewan team, 2010-2013: Peter Robinson and Barbara Bordalejo

Brigham Young University transcription team, 1995-2006, led by Paul Thomas: Sara Black, Jessica Cox, Barbara Christiansen, Kerry Clift Spencer*, Heidi Elldredge, Leona Fisher Sankhla, Kela Flint*, Melissa Gallup, Shannon Harris, Rebecca Johnson, Mary Jorgensen, Darin Merrill*, Wesley Pack*, Jared Perkins, Jon Penny, Randall Rogers, Ryan Rowberry*, Sara Slack, Carie Soderquist Jackson*, Kat Southerland, Matt Tenney, Briton Wright, John Young. Asterisks after names denote those who supervised other transcribers.

Adam Mickiewicz University, Poznan, transcription team, 2007-2010: (names to be supplied), with support from Adam Mickiewicz University and the The Polish Ministry for Science and Higher Education, grant N104 045 32/4256.
Nila Vazquez Gonzalez, University of Murcia.
Institute of Book Studies and Textual Research of the University of Münster, Germany, c. 2000-2004,led by Gabriele Müller Oberhauser; transcribed by Ulrike Grassnick.

University of Sheffield, 1994-1999, led by Norman Blake: Michael Pidd and Estelle Stubbs, with Linda Cross, Claire Thomson, Orietta Da Rold and Simon Horobin. In partnership with the Canterbury Tales Project, at that time led by Norman Blake in partnership with Peter Robinson and Elizabeth Solopova (up to 1998), and using images and other resources supplied by the Project, the Sheffield team transcribed eight manuscripts in full (Ad3, Corpus, Dd, Gg, Ellesmere, Ha4, Hengwrt, Lansdowne), sections of some seven other manuscripts, and all manuscripts of the Franklin's Tale. No part of these transcripts is contained in this iteration of the Project.

div.l: The prologe of the knyghtes tale .¶ O . yee so noble and worthi pryncis and . princesseoþer estatis or degrees . what euer yee beo þᵗat hauedisposicione / or plesaunce . to rede or here þe storiesof olde tymis Passed to kepe yow frome ydelnesseand slowþe . mescheuing oþer folies þat mightbe cause of more harome filowyng / . vowcheth saufI be seche yowe . to fynde yowe occupacioıı̄un in þe Reding /here of þe tales / of Caunterburye wiche beon . /compilid / in þis boke filowing First foundid ymagenid and made / boþe for disporte and leornyngof all þoo that beon gentile of birthe or of cōmdicoıı̄unsby þe laureal and moste famous poete þat euer //was to fore him / as in þemvelisshing / of oure rude .moders englisshe tonge . clepid Chaucyer a Gavfredeof whos soule . god . for his mercy have pitee of hisgrace Amen . ¶ Nowe here firste . begynnyþe þe prologe of þekneytis tale
Whanne þᵗat Aperyll wᵗith his shoures swoote /
Þe Drowght of marche hathe perced to þᵉ rote
And baþed eủer/rey veyne . / in suche lykoure
Of wiche vertue . / engenderid is þe floure
Whanne zepherus eke ; / wᵗith his swete brethe
Enspiryd hathe in eủer/rey holt And hethe
The tendre croppys . And þe yownge sonne
Haþe in þe Rame . his halfe cours eronne
And smale foules . maken melodye
Þat slepen Al þe night wᵗith open eye
So prickeþe hēm nature / in þayre courages
Þanne longen folkes to gon on pilgrymages
And palmeris eke / to seche straunge strandes
To ferne halowes . / kowþe in sundrye landis
And speciallye . frome euery shyres ende
Of England / to Cavnterburye þei wende
The hooly blyssfulle martyr . For to seke
Þat hem hathe holpon whanne þᵗat þei were seke .
By felle hit in þᵗat saysoun . on a day
In sowthwerke / at þe tabard as I laye
Redy to weonde . / vpon my pilgrymage
To Cauntovreburye . wᵗith devoute courage
At night was come / in to þᵗat hostelerye
Wel nyen and twenty on a companye
Of sundry folke . by Aventur efalle
In feleship and pylgrymes were þei Alle
Þat towarde Caunturburye wolden Ride
Þe chaumberis ⁊and þᵉ stablis werne weyde
And wele were þei eesed / . al at þᵉ beste
And shortly whan þe sonne was to reste
So had I spoken wᵗith hem eủer/reychoon
Þat I was of hir . felishippe A noon
And made forwardis eorly for to ryse
To . take oure weye þer as I yow devyse
But naþelesse . wheyle I haue tyme ⁊and space
Or þᵗat I forþer . in þis tale passe
Me thynkithe hit . / Acordaunt to Rayson
To tellen yowe // Al þe conduciou
Of yche of hem / so as it semod me
And wiche þei weren / and of what degree
And eke in what araye þat þei wer in
Þus at a knyght I wol fyrst be gynne
¶ ¶ a knyght þer was / and þᵗat a worthy man
Þat from þe tyme / þat he firste bigan
To rydin owte x he loved chevallerye
Trouth and honowre / Fredam ⁊and crutesie
Full worthy was he / in his lordis werre
And þer to had he riden / no man ferrer
As welle in crystendame / as heþennesse
Oueral honnoured for his worthinesse
At Alisaundir he was / whanne it was wonne
Ful oftyn tymis / he hade þe borde bygonne
Aboven alle þᵉ naciouns / in peyne Pruse
In lecto hadēm he reyssed / and in Ruyce
No cristenman . so ofte of his Degree
In Garnade at þe seege / eke had he be
Of Algasire . and ryden in belmarye
At lyes was he . / and at Satalie
Whanne þei were wonne / and / in þe gret see
At many a noble armee had he be
At mortell batayles / hade he be fifftene
And Fowghten for oure feythe at Thramassene
Withe in lystis thryse / And aye slayne his foo
Þis ilke worthy kneyght had ben Asoo
Some tyme wᵗith þe lord / of palatee
Ageynst a noþer heþyn / in Turkye
And euermore / he had soủer/reeyne pryse
And þaughe þat he was worthy he was wyse
Of al his porte as meke as any mayde
He neuer yit no velanye ne saide
In all his lyve / vn to noman wyght
He was a verray ꝑper/parfite trewe kneyght
And For to tellen yowe of his Arraye
Hees hors were good // but he was not gaye
Of Fustian he werid a Iu poune
Al bysmoteryd wᵗith his haburgeoune
For he was late ecome frome his viage
And went þus for to done his pilgrimage
Wᵗith him ther was his son / A younge squier
A lovyer A lusty bachelere
Withe lockis croulle . as þey were leyde in presse
Wel twenty yere of Age / he was I gesse
Of his stature / he was of evene lengthe
And wonderly deliủer/ree / And gret of strenght
For he had ben som tyme in Cheuauchee
In flaundres Arthoys ⁊and in pycardye
And borne him welle / as of so litille space
In hope to stonde in his ladies grace
Enbrowded was he / as it were a mede
Al ful of freysche flowris / white ⁊and Rede
Synging he was or flytyng al þᵉ day
He was als Fresshe as is þᵉ monthe of may
Short was his goune / wᵗith slevis long ⁊and wyde
Wele koude he sitte on horse / And fayre ryde
He coude songes make / And wel endite
Iouste eke and Daunce wel pourtray And evryte
So hote he lovid / þat by þe nightertale
He slepte namore / þane doþe a nightyngale
Courteyse he was / lowly ⁊and servisable
And kerff by fore his Fader at þe table
¶ A yoman had he And sarvauntꝭes namoo
As for that tyme / hym list to Riden soo
Þe wiche was cladde in coote ⁊and hode ⁊and grene
A sheff of pecok arowes / withe hedis kene
Vndir his belt he bare full thrifftili
Wel covde he dresse / his takle yomanly .
Hees Arowes drowped / nowght wᵗith federis lowe
And in his hande he bare Amytye bowe
A notte hede hadde he / wᵗith a browne visage
Of wodocraff . koude he wele al þusage
Vpon his arme / he bare A gay bracere
And by his syde / A swerd wᵗith a brode bokeler
And on þat oþer syde / a Fyne Daggere
Syluer herneysid / and sharp as poynt on spere
A cristofer on his brest / of silver shene
An horne he bare þe bauderike was of grene
Sum Forster was he / soþely as I gesse
Þer was Also / a nonne A prioresse
Þat of hir smyling // was ful symple ⁊and coye
Her grettest oþe / was but by saynt loye
And she was clepid / ma dame Eglentyne
Ful wel she sange þe servyse devine
Entunid in her nose / ful semly
And frēmshe she spake / Right fayre ⁊and fetlye
Affter þe scole of Stratford of þe bowe
For frēmshe of paryse / was to hir on knowe
At þe mete welle etawght / was she wᵗith alle
She lete no morsell / from hir lippis falle
Ne wette her fyngeris / in her sause depe
Wele covde sheo carye / a morsel ⁊and welle kepe
Þat noo drope ne fel / vpon her bryste
In courtesye / was sette fully her lyste
Hir ouerlippe / wiped sheo so clene
Þat in hir cuppe / þer was no ferþing sene
Of grece þat whan sheo had dronken hir draught
Ful semely / Aftir hir mete shēmo Raught
And sekirly she was of gret desporte
Ryght plesaunt and amyable of porte
And peynid her to countrefete þe chere
Of courte to been / estatly of manere
And to be holden dingne of Reuerence
But for to spekyn / of hir consience
Sheo was so charitable . And pytowse
Þat sheo wold wepe yf sheo saughe Amouse
Kaught in a trappe . / yf hit were dede or bledde
Of smale houndis / had she þat sheo fedde
Withe Rostyd flesshe / or mylke or wastillebred
Leueþe me sheo wepte / Ful sore whan on was dede
Or yf men smote hit / wᵗith a yerde smerte
And al was conciens . and tendre harte
Ful semly hir wimpille epinchid was
Hir nose was streyght / hir eyeghen grey as glas
Her mowthe mesurable / ful soffte ⁊and Rede
But sekurly sheo had A fayre forehede
Hit was Almoste A spane brode I trowe
Ne dowte yowe nought / sheo was not vndirgrowe
Ryght Fetyse was hir cloke / as I was ware
Of smale corall / Abovte hir arme she bare
A peyr of bedis gaudeed / all wᵗith grene
On weche þer hang / A broche of gold ful shene
Wher on was graven firste A . crovnid . A .
And Aftir Amor vincit omnia
A noþer nonne with hir / þoo had she
That was her chapellayne / and prestes three
A monke þer was a Feyre for þe mastrye
An outryder / þat lovid venerie
A manly man / to ben an Abbot Abe
Full many a deynte hors / had he in stable
And whan he Rode he mythe his bridil here
Gyngeling / in a whistelyng wynde als clere
And eke als lowde as doþe þe Chapelle belle
Þer as this lord was keper of þe Celle
Þe rule of saint Maure or of Seint Benette
By cause þat it was olde and sumdele streyte
Þis ilke monke / leet old thyngꝭes passe
And held Aftir þe . nuwe worlde þe space
He gave not of þe texst / a pulled henne
Þat seyþe þat hunteris / beon nought hooly menne
Ne that a monke . whan he is Recchelesse
Is likenid til a fishe al watelesse
Þat is to seyne . a monke owte of þᵉ clostre
But thilke texste helde he not worthe an oystre
And I sayde his opynioune / was good
What shulde he studye / and make hym selven woode
Vpon A booke Alwey / in cloystre poure
Or swynke wᵗith his hondis or laboure
As austyn bid how shalle þe world be servid
Lete Austyn have / his swinke to hym reservid
Þer for he was a prikasour a right
Grehoundis he hade / als swyffte as Fovle of flyte
Of priking and of huntyng for þᵉ hare
Was al his lyfe / For noo coste wold he spare
I seghe his sleves / pourfiled at þᵉ honde
Withe grys and þᵗat þᵉ fynest in a londe
And for to fasten his hode vndir his chynne
He had of golde ewroute A coryovse pynne
A love knotte in þe gret ende graven was
His hede was ballid þᵗat shone as ony glasse
And eke his face / as he had ben anoynte
He was a lorde fulle fatte / and in good poynte
Hees yen stepe / and Roullyng in his hede
Þat steymd . as þe fourneys made of lede
Hees boutis souple / his horse in grete estate
Nowe certaynly . he was a feyr prelate
He nas not pale as a forpyned gooste
A fatte swanne loved he best of any Roste
His palfreye was as browne as is burye
A Frere þer was a wantone ⁊and a murye
A . Limytoure Right a ful solempne man
In Al þe orderis foure is non þᵗat can
So mochil of dalyaunce and fayr langage
For he hade made ful many mariage
Of yovnge wymmen at his oune coste
Vn to his ordre / he was A noble poste
Ful welbelouid and famulier was he
Wᵗith Frankeleynis . ouir al in his cuntree
And wᵗith þe worthy wymmen of þᵉ toune
For he hadde power of Conffescione
And saide hym selfe welmore þan a curat
For of his ordre / he was lysenciate
Fulle swetly hard he / confessioune
And plesaunt was his Absolucioune
He was an Esy man / to geve penaunce
Þer as he wyste / to have a good pytaunce
For on to povre ordre / for to gyve
Is gret signe þat a man is wele eshreyve
For yf he gaf / he durst welle make a vaunte
He wyste ther by / a man was Repentaunte
For many Aman is so herde of herte
He may not wepe / al þough hym sore smerte
Þer for in stede of wepyng / And prayers
Men mot gyve silver on to þᵉ pore freres
His typpet was ay farsid ful of knyvis
And of pynnis to gyve þe fayre wyves
And certainly he had a mery noote
Welle coude he syngen and pleyne on a Rote
Of yeddinges / he bare vtterly þe pryse
His nekke als white as is þᵉ flore de lyse
Þer to he was als stronge as Chaumpyoune
He knowe þe tavernis welle in every tovne
And eueriche hostellier / and Tapistier
Bette þane a lasier / or a begstier
For vn to suche a worthy man as he
A cordid nought / as by his faculte
To have wᵗith such seke laisers acqveyntaunce
It is not honeste it may no thyng A vaunce
As For to dele / wᵗith any suche pouraille
But all wᵗith Riche / and sellers of victayle
And ouer al þer as proufyte shoulde Aryse
Courtese he was And lowly off service
Þer nas noman no wher so vertuous
He was þᵉ best begger / in his house
For þauhe A wedowe nad but oon shoo
So plesaunt was his In principio
Þat he wold have / A ferthyng or he went
His purchas was wele bett̉er/re þan was his rent
And Rage he kouþe Right as doithe A whelpe
In love dayes þer kouþe he mochel helpe
For þer he Nas not lyche / A Cloystorier
Wᵗith þe thredbare cope / as a poure scolier
But he was liche Amaistre / or A pope
Of dowble worstede / was his semy cope
Þᵗat Rounded as A belle / owte of þe presse
Somwhat he lypsid / for his wantounesse
To make his Englisshe swete / vpon his tong
And in his harpyng whan þᵗat he had songe
Hees eyen twenkelid in his hede aright
As don þeos sterres / in þe Frosty nyght
Þis worthy lemetoure / was cleped hewberd
¶ A marchaunde was þer / with a Fourched berd
In motley and heyghe on hors he satte
Vpon his hede / a Flaundrisshe bever hatte
Hees botys claspid / Fayre and fetysely
And al his Raysonis he speke ful solemply
Shewyng Al weyes þe encresse of his wynnyng
He wold þe see were kepte for Any thyng
Be twyxste . Midilborow ⁊and orwell
Wele coude he by eschaunge sheldis selle
Þis worthy man Ful welle his witte bysette
Ther wist noo wyght þᵗat he was in dette
So estately was he of governaunce
Wᵗith his Bargaynes / and wᵗith his chevissaunce
For soþe he was A worthye man wᵗith al .
But soþe to sayn / I not howe men him calle
¶ A Clerke þer was of Oxenford Also
Þat vn to logyke / had he long goo
Als lene / was his hors as is a Rake
And he nas nowte fatte I vndirtake
But loked holow / And þer to sobourly
Ful thredbare was / is ouerest courtpy
For he nade goton hym / no benefyse
Ne was so worldly to have an office
For him was lever haue / at his beddis hede
Twenty bookes clade / in blake or Rede
Of Aristotle and his phelosophie
Þanne Robes Riche / or Fydille or Savtrie
But al by þᵗat he was Aphilesopher
Yette had he but A litill gold in coffre
For Al þat he myght / of his frendis hent
Vppon his bookꝭes / and lernyng he hit spent
And besyly gane for þe soules pray
Of hem þat fonde him / wherwithe to scoley
Of studye toke he / moost cure an hede
Nought oon word spake he more þan was nede
And þat was sayd / in fourme ⁊and Reuerence
And short and quike / and ful of hye sentence
Sownynge in moral vertu / was his speche
And gladlye wold he lerne / and gladly teche
A Sargeaunt of þe lawe / ful ware ⁊and wyse
Þat often tymes had ben at parvys
Þat was Also fulle riche off excellens
Discret he was / and of gret Reuerence
Him semid suche // heos wordis were so wyse
Iustice Ful oftyn he was / in assyse
By patente / and by pleyne coumyssioıı̄un
For his syens / and for his hye renoune
Of Fees and roobis had he many oon
So gret a purchassoure / nas noo whernoon
Al was phesymple to him in effecte
His purchasing might not ben infecte bet
No wher so busy a man as he þer nas
And yette hym semyd besyer þan he was
In termes had he / domes And Cases alle
Þat frome þe tyme of kyng William were falle
Þer to he coude Endite / and make a thyng
Þer kowþe no wight pynche as his wreytyng
And euery statute kouþe he playn be Roote
He Rood homly in a medlee Cōmote
Girt wᵗith a seynte of silke with barres smale
Of his arraye / telle I noo lenger tale
A Frankeleyne was þer in his compaignye
White was his berd as is þe dayessye
Of his complecciou he is sangwyne
Wel loved he by þe morowyn a soppe in weyne
To lyven in delite . euer was his wonne
For he was Epicurus owne sonn
Wiche helde opyneoun þat playn delite
Was werray felicitee / parfyte
An hovseholder / and þᵗat a gret was he
Saynt Iulian . he was in his cuntrey
His bred / his ale / was Alweys Aftir oon
A better envyned man . was noo where . noon
Wᵗith oute bakemete was nevermore his house
Of fushe of Flesshe and þᵗat so plentivouse
Hit snede in his house mete ⁊and drynke
Of Alle Deyntees . þat man koude ought bethynke
Afftir þe sundery saysonis of þe yeere
So chaunged he his mete / and his soupere
Full many A fatte parteriche . had he in muwe
And many A breme / pyke And luce In stue
Woo was his Cooke / but yf his sauce ay were
Poynyant and sharpe / and Redy al his gere
His table dormant in his halle Alweye
Stode Redye couerd / al þe long daye
At sessiouns þer was he lord ⁊and syre
Wel offte syþes / he was knyght of þe shyre
And Anlase and a Gipsere al of silke
Heng at his girdelle whyte as any mylke
A Shirreff hade he ben And a countour
Was nowher suche a worþy vavassoure
An haburdassher . And A Carpentier
A webbe A dyer and a Tappissier
Wiche were cladde al in on liueree
Of A solempne and grete fraternitee
Ful fresshe and / newe / al her gere epiked was
Hir knyves nerenot Tappid withe brasse
But al wᵗith siluer wrought Ful clene And wele
Hir girdelis and hir powches eủer/reye dele
Wele semed eche of hem / a feyr Burgeys
To sitten in a yeldehalle / on hye deyse
Euerych for þe wisdom þᵗat he can
Was shaply for ben An Alderman
For cateyle had they enoughe and Rent
And eke hir wyves . wolde hit welle Assent
Ellys certaynly were they foule to blame
It is ful faire to be clepid madame
And at þe vigylles / gone all oþer be fore
To have hir mantell ryallyche ebore
A . cooke they hadde wᵗith hem for þe noones
To boyle the chekonis . wᵗith þe marybonis
And poudre marchaunt . tarte wᵗith galingale
Welle koude he knowe A drawte of londou ale
He kouþe Roste ⁊and boyle / and seþe ⁊and freye
Maken mortreaux . and wel bake A pye
But harme hit was gret as thought me
Þat on his shyn / a mormal had he
For blāmmangre þat made he with þᵉ best
A Shipman was þeir wonneng far by west
He Rode vppon a Rouncᵃy / as he kouþe
For ought I wot he was of Dertemouþe
In a goune of falding vn to þe knee
A Dagger honging / in a lace hade he
Aboute his necke / vnder his arome downe
Þe hote somer / hade made his huwe albrovne
And certainly / he was a goode felawe
Ful many A dravght of wyne had he drawe
From Bourdeux wardes / whiles þe Chapman sleepe
Of nyce consience . toke he litill kepe
Iff þat he faught / and had þe hyer hande
By water he sent hem home / to euery lande
But of his crafte to Reken welle hes tydis
Hes streems and hees daungers him besidis
His herborowe his mony his lodemanage
Þer nas non suche frome hull vn to Cartage
Herdye he was / and wyse to vndir take
Wᵗith many A tempest . had his berde be shake
He knew well all þe havens as thei were
Forme Goutland to þe Cāmpe de fynestre
And euery Cricke . in Brettaigne and in spaigne
His Barge eclepid was þe maudeleyne
Wᵗith vs was eke A Doctoure of fysike
In All þis worlde þer was noon him like
To speke of Phisik . and of surgerye
For he was grovndid / in Astronomye
He kepte his paciens A ful grete dele
In þe houres / by magyk naturelle
Ful welle kouþe he fortune þascendent
Of heos ymages for his paciens
He knewe þe cause of euerye maladye
Were hit of hete of colde moyste or drye
Where of engenderid / and off what humer /
He was A werray ꝑper/parfite practisoure
Þe cavse he knewe ⁊and of his harome þᵉ Roote
A . noon he gafe þe seke man his boote
Ful Redy had he heos Appoticaryes
To send him draggees and þeyre letwaryes
For yche of hem made oþer for to wynne
Her frenship nas not nuwe for to be gynne
Wele knewe he þe olde Escalapius
And discorides eke and him Ruphus
Wyse ypocras halye ⁊and Galyene
Serapyon Razie and Auiyzene
Auerios damascien and Constantyne
Bernerd and Gatisdene / and Gylbertyne
Of his dyete / mesurable was he
For he used no suꝑper/parfluite
But of gret nereshyng / And degestible
His studye was but litell on þe bille
In Sangwyne and in pers he cladde was al .
Lyned wᵗith taffata and withe sendall
And yete he was but esy of dispence
He kepte þat he wanne / in þe pestelence
For gold in phisike / is a cordialle
Þer fore he lovid golde in specialle
A goode wyff þer was of besydes bathe
But sheoo was sumdele defe ⁊and þᵗat was skaþe
Of clothe makyng sheo hade suche þanne an haunte
Sheo passithe hem / of þpre and of Gaunte
In Al þe parishe wyf þanne was þer noone
That to the offering / to fore her shulde goiþe
And yf þer did certaine þanne wrothe was shee
Þat she hadde lost / al hir hole charitee
Hir kouerchiefis wel fyne were of grounde
I dourst wel swere . þey wer worth x pounde
That on A sonday were vppon her hede
Hir hosyn were of Fyne skarlette Rede
Ful streyte eteyed And shoos ful moyste ⁊and newe
Bolde was hir face ⁊and fayre ⁊and Rede of huwe
Sheo was a worthye woman / al hir live
Husbandes at þe chirche dore had shoo had fyve
Withe owtēm oþer cumpanye / in yowþe
But ther of nedithe nought to speke as nowe
And thryes hade sheo beon / at Ierusalem
Sheo had passid many A fulle straunge streme
At Rome sheo had ben and at grate Bouleyne
In galys at saynt Iame . and at couloyne
Sheo kouþe moche on wanderyng by þᵉ weye
Gate toþed was sheo sooþelye to saye
Vppon an Aumbeller Esely she satte
Ewympuled wele and on her hede An hatte
Als brode as is A bokeler or a targe
A foote mantell Abovte her hippis large .
And on her fete / A peyre of sporis sharpe
In pheleshipe wel kouþe sheo / laughe ⁊and carpe
Of Remedyes of love / sheo knewe par chaunce
For sheo kouþe / of þᵗat arte þolde daunce
A good man was þer / of Religioune
And was A poure ꝑper/parsoune of A tovne
But Riche he was / of holy thought ⁊and werke
He was Also A lernid man A . Clerk
Þat cristꝭes gospelle . trvly wolde Aye preche
His parrisshens devoutly wold he teche
Bennigne he was / and wondir deligent
And in Adversyte . ful pacyent
And suche he was preeved ofte sithis
Ful loþe were hym to curssen for his tyþes
But raþer wolde . he yeven . owte of dowte
Vn to his poure parisshenis him Aboute
Of heos offeryngꝭes . And of his substaunce
He kouþe in litil thyng / have suffisaunce
Wide was his parishe howses fer A sondre
But he ne leffte neyþer for Reyne ne thundre
In sekenesse ne in mischef to vesite
Þe firþeste in his parische muche ⁊and lyte
Vpon his Fete / And In his hande a staffe
Þis noble Ensample / vn to heos sheope he gaffe
Þat firste he wrought / And Afftirwardis he taught
Ovte of þe gospell he þoo wordis kaught
And this figure / he added eke þer too
Þat yf golde þouste / what shall þanne yren doo
For yf A prest beo foule / on whom we truste
No wondir is þaughe levde men þanne Ruste
Gret shame it is yf A preeste take kepe
A shitten shepard And A clene shepe
Wel aught A prest / . ensaumple for to gyve
By his clennes howe þᵗat his sheope shulde lyve
He should nought sette / his benyfise to hire
And lete his sheope / be comberid in þe myre
And Rynne to london . vn to saynt poules
To sechin him a chaunterye for soulis
Or wᵗith a broþerhed . to ben wᵗith holde
But dwelle at home / and kepe welle his folde
So þat þe wolfe make hit not miscarye
He was a sheparde / and not a mercenarye
And þaughe he holy were / and vertuous
He nas not to synfull folke despitouse
Ne of his speche daungerovse ne digne
But in his techyng descrete and benigne
To drawen folke . to hevene by fayrnesse
In good Ensample . was his bessinesse
But it were ony parsone . obstinate
What so he were of heght or lowe estate
Him wolde he snibbe sharply for þᵉ noons
A bett̉er/re prest I trowe þat nowher non is
He wayted affter no pompe ne Reuerence
Ne maked him A spiced conciens
But crystꝭes love ⁊and his Apostelis twelve
He taught but first . he felowed it him selve
Wᵗith him þer was a ploughman his owne broþ̉er/re
Þᵗat hade eladde of dongge ful many A foþer
A ful gret swynker And a trewe was he
Liuing in pes ay ⁊and in charitee
God louid he beste wᵗith al his hole herte
At Al tymis þaughe he gamed or smerte
And þanne his neghbore . as he dide him selve
He wolde thresshēm . And þer to dyke ⁊and delve
For . Crystꝭes sake for every poure wight
Wᵗith outen hire yf hit lay in his myght
Heos tiþes payde . he alle fayre ⁊and welle
Boþe of his propre swynke / and his kataele
In A taberd he Rode vp on a mere . /
Þer was Also A Ryve ⁊and A Mylner
A Sompner And A pardoner Also
A Maunciple . and my selff þ̉er/re were no moo
The mylner was a stoute carlle for þᵉ noones
Right bigge he was of braune ⁊and eke of bones
Þat proeued welle . for oueral wher he came
At wrastelyng he wold have þᵉ Ram
He was short sholderid . a thikke knarre
Þer nas noon dore . he wold heve ought of harre
Or breke it at a Rynnygne wᵗith his hede
His berd as any sweyne . or Fox was rede
And þer to brode . as þaughe it were Aspade
Vppon þe coppe . Right of his nose he hade
A wrette and þer on stonde A tuffte of heris
Rede as þᵉ Brystelis of A sowes eris
Heos nostrelles blake were ⁊and weyde
A swerd ⁊and A bokeler bare he be his side
His mowthe Als gret as was an huge furneyse
He was A Iangeler / and a golierdeys
And þat was most of synne . and harlotryes
He kouþe stele corne . and tolle it thryes
And yette he hadde A thumbe of golde ꝑper/pardee
A weyte coote ⁊and A blewe hode werid hee .
A Baggpype welle kouþe he blowe ⁊and sowne
And þer wᵗith al he browte vs ovte of toune
A gentil Maunsiple was þer of þe temple
Of whome Achatours mighten take ensaumple
For to be wyse in bying of vitayle
For whethir þᵗat he paid or toke by tayle
Algate he A waytid soo in his Achatee
Þat he was by forne ⁊and in gode state
Now is not þat of god / A ful hy grace
Þᵗat suche A lewde manis witte shalle passe
Þe wysdome of an hepe of lernid men
Of mastirs had he moo þane thryes ten
That wer of lawe . expert and curyous
Of wiche þer were A douszem in þat hovse
Worthye to ben stewardis of Rent ⁊and lande
Of any lordꝭes þat is in Englond
To make him lyve by his ꝓpropre good
In honoure dettelesse but yf he were woode
Or lyve als scarslye . as him list desire
And Able for to helpen All Ashire
In any case þᵗat might falle or happe
And yette þis maunsiple sette þeyre aller cappe
Þe Reve was A sklendir colorike man
Hes berde was shave als neyghe as eủer/re he can
Hes here was by hes erys ful Rounde shorne
His toppe was tonsured lyche A preost byfore
Full long were heos leggꝭes . and fulle lene
Elyche A staffe þer nas no calffe essene
Welle kouþe he kepe A garnar or a bynne
Þer nas non auditoure . kouþe on him wynne
Wele wist he by þe drought . and by þe Reyne
Þe yeldyng of his sedee . and of his greyne
Hes lordis shepe his nete his dayerye
¶ His sweyne his store his horsse ⁊and his pultrye
Was hooly in this Reuis governinge
And by covenaunt gave his Rekenyng
Sith that his lord was twenty yere of age
Þer kouþe no man bring him in Arerage
Þer nas baylye ne herde ne oþir hyne
Þat he ne knewe . his sleyght and his couvyne
Þei were adradde of him as of þᵉ dethe
Hes wounyng was ful fayr vppon an hethe
Wᵗith grene trees be shadowid was his place
He kouþe welbetter þanne his lorde purchase
Ful Riche he was / Astorid / prevelye
His lorde wele kouþe he plesyn suttelye
To geve and lene him of his oune goode
A have A thanke And yitte A cote an hode
In youþe he hadde lerned / a goode mistere
He was A wel good wreyght . a Carpenter
Þis Reve satte vpon A Right goode stotte
A long sircote of perse he hadde vppon
And by his side . he bare A Rusty blade
Of norfolke was þis Reve of wiche I telle
Be sides a towne þᵗat hitaght baldeswell
Tukked he was as is A Frere A boute
And ever he Roode þe hynmast of oure Route
¶ A sumpnour was þer wᵗith vs in place
Þat hade a fuyry red / Cherubyns face
For saucefleme he was / wᵗith yene narowe
Als lecherous he was as is A sparowe
Wᵗith scalled / browes blake ⁊and pillid berde
Of his visage chylderne were A ferde
Þer nas qviksiluer . lytarge or bryston
Boras or sour ne oyle of tartre noone
Ne oynement þat wold clens and byte
Ne him might helpen of his wheolkes whyte
Nor of þe knobbis sittyng on his cheokes
Wel loved he garlec onyonis and leekys
And for to drynke strong weyne rede as bloode
Þanne wolde he speke and crye as he were woode
And whanne þat he weldronkon had þe wyne
Þanne wolde he speke . no worde but latyne
A fewe termes had he þanne two or three
That he had leorned owte of some decree
No wondir is he harde hit al the daye
And eke yee konwe hit wele howe þᵗat a Iaye
Can clepe watte as wele as can þe pope
But who so kouþe in oþer thinge him grope
Þanne hadde he spent alle his philosophie
Ay qvestio quid / Iuris wolde he crye
He was A gentil / harlote and A kuynde
A better felowe / shalle man nowher fynd
He wolde wele souffre . for A quarte of wyne
A good felowe to have his concubyne
A twelvemonþe and excuse him at the fulle
Ful prevelye eke A Fynche kouþe he pulle
And yf he fonde . o . wher A good felowe
He wold techin him to have non Auve
In suche cas of þerchedeakens course
But yf manis soule were in his purse
For in his poursse he shulde punysshed bee
Pourse is þe Erchedeakonis hele saide he
But wel I wot he hed right indede
Of courssing aught ych giltiman him drede
For corse wol sleo . right as soyling saueþe
And Also wax him . / of A significauit
In daungere had he . right at his owne guyse
Þe yong gyrlles of al þat diosice
And knew her counsale / and what was hir Rede
A garland had he sette vppon his hede
Als grete as it were for an Ale stake
A bokeler had he made hym of A cake
Wᵗith him þer rode . A gentil pardoner
Of Rouncivale . his freonde ⁊and his compere
Þat streyte was coume from þe covrte of Rome
Ful lowde he songe come hedir love cōmme
Þis Sompnour bore to hym a stiffe bourdoun
Was never trompe of vnde ne grete of sown
Þis pardoner hadde here as yelowe as waxsse
But smooþe hit hang as doþe astrike of flaxsse
By ownces hong þe lookes þᵗat he hadde
And þer wᵗith al hees sholders ouer spradde
But thynne they laye by culponis oon ⁊and oon
And hood for Iolyvetee . ne werid he noon
For hit was trussid vp in his wallette
Him thought he Rode . Al of þᵉ nuwe Iette
Suche glaring eyen . had he as and hare
A vernicle hade he sewed wppon his cappe
And his walet beforne . him in his lappe
Brettfulle of pardoune . come frome Rome al hoote
A voyce had he als smal / as any goote .
No berd had he . ne neuermore shuld have
Als smoþe it was as it were late shave
I . trowe he were A geldyng or a mare
But of his craffte frome Berwike in to ware
Ne was þer suche Anoþ̉er/re pardoner
For in his wallet he hade Apilowbere
Wich þat he saide . was oure ladies veyle
He saide he hade A gobette . of þe sayle
Þat saint petre hade . whanne þᵗat he went
Vpon þe see . til Ihesus crist him hent
He hade A Croysser of laton ful of stonis
And In a glasse he hadde pigges bonis
But with þoos relikes . whanne þᵗat he fonde
A poure persone dwellyng vpon londe
Vppon A day . he gate hym more moneye
Þanne þᵗat þe persone gate . in monthes tweye
And þus wᵗith feyned flateryng and Iapes
He made þe pesone . and þe people heos Apes
But trewly to tellyn at þe laste
He was in cherche A nobele ecclesiate
Wel kouþe he Rede A lesson or A storye
But Alderbest he sang an offratorye
For wel he wist whanne þat song was sunge
He must preche . And wel a file his tonge
To wynne siluer . as þat he wel coude
Þer fore he song so merely and loude
Now have I tolde yowe . sooþely in A clause
Þe state þarraye þe noumbre ⁊and þe cause
Why þᵗat assembled was / þis compaignye
In sothewerke / at þis Ientile hostelarye
Þᵗat heght þe taberd fast by þe belle
But now is tyme vn to to yowe to telle
Howe þᵗat wee beeryn vs þᵗat ilke night
Whanne we were in þᵗat hostelarye alight
And afftir wolle I telle yow of oure viage
Wᵗith alle þe Reminavnte . of oure palgrimage
But first I pray yow . of yovre courtesye
Þᵗat ye dyrette it nought . my vilanye
Þoughe þᵗat I speke pleynly in this mater
To tellen yowe þeyre wordes / and þeyre chere
Ne þaughe . I speke . þeyre wordes propurlye
For þis ye knowen alle / als welle as I
Who so shalle telle atale / Aftir A man .
He mote Reherse . als nyhe as eủer/re he can .
Eueryche A word / yf hit be in his charge
Al speke he neuer / so Rudly ⁊and large
Or ell he mut telle his tale on trewe
Or feyne thynges / or fynden wordes newe
He may not spare . al þouhe he were his broþ̉er/re
He most Als wele . seye . on worde as a noþ̉er/re
Criste spake him selfe . ful brode in holy wrytte
And welle yee witte . no velany is it
Eke Plato seyþe who so can him Rede
Þe wordis mote nede be cousin to þᵉ dede
Also I pray yowe / þᵗat ye for give hit me
Al have I not / sette folke in hir degree
Here in þis talis / as þat they shulde stande
My witte is short ye may wele vndirstonde
Grete chere made oure hoste vs euerych oon
And to þe souper . / sette he vs Anoon
He servid vs . wᵗith vitaillꝭes of þe beste
Strong was þe wyne . and wele to drinke vs liste
A Semly man . oure host was wᵗith al
Ye for to ben A marchal of An halle
A large man he was wᵗith yen stepe
A Feyrer bourgeys / is þer non in chepe
Bold of his speche . and wyse ⁊and wel etaught
And of manhode him lacked no right naught
Eke þer to right a mury man
And Affter soper . pleyen þus he gan
And spake of mirthe . a monges oþ̉er/re thinges
Whanne þᵗat he had made oure Rekeninges
And saide þus nowe lordingis trewely
Ye be to me welcom . right hertlye
For by my trowthe . yf þat I Shal not lye
I sawe not this yere so mury A compeny
At oons in þis harborowe / as is nowe
Fayn wold I do yowe myrth and I wiste howe
And wol yee here . what I am nowe be thowghet
To don yowe eese and hit shall cost yow noute
Ye gon to Cavntirbury god yow spede
Þe blissfull martir qvite yow yowre mede
And wel I wote . as ye gon by the weye
Yᵉ shapen yow to talen ⁊and to pleye
For trewly coumfort / ne no mirthe is noon
To Riden by the wey . als Doumbe as a stone
And ther fore wolle I Fynde . yow Disport
As I Saed erste and don yow some comforte
For yf yow likeþe all by oon Assent
For to stonde at my Iugement
And for to wirchen as I Shalle yow saye
To morow whan ye Riden by þᵉ weye
Nowe by my fader sowle þᵗat is ded
But yee be mury I wol gyve yow my hede
Holdiþe vp youre handis . wᵗith oute more speche
Oure counsaile was not long for to seche
Vs thought it was not worthe . to make it wys
And grauntid him wᵗith outen more Avise
And prayde him saye his verdight as him liste
Lordingis quod he now herkenith for þᵉ beste
But take hit not I pray yow in þis deyne
Þis is þe poynt to speke short ⁊and pleyn
Þat eche of yowe to shorten oþeos weye
In this wiage shalle telle . tales tweye
To Cauntourebyri I mene it right soo
And homewardis . he shal telle A noþ̉er/re too
Of Aventouris whylom þat haue be falle
And wiche of yowe þᵗat berithe him beste of Alle
Þat is to seyne / þat tellithe in this caas
Tales of best sentens . And moste solace
Shalle have A souꝓpro / at oure Alderscoste
Here in this place sittyng by þis poste
Whanne þᵗat we comen A gayne from Caıı̄unnt̉er/rebyri
And for make yow þe more mury
I wolle my selfe . wᵗith yow gladlye Ride
Right at myn owne coste . and beo yoᵃ guyde
And whoo soo wille . my Iugement wᵗith seye
Shalle paye al þᵗat we spende by þe weye
And yf yee vowchensauffe þᵗat it be soo
Telle me anoon / wᵗith owten wordis moo
And I wolle erly shapen me þer fore
Þis thyng was graunted and oure oþes swore
Wᵗith Ful good hert and preyden him Alsoo
Þᵗat he wold wouchesaff so to doo .
And þat he wolde be þus oure governoure
And of owre tales . Iuge ⁊and Reportoure
And sette A sopper at A serten pris
For we weel ben at his devisee
In heght and lowe . and þus by oon Assent
We ben A cordid to þis Iugement
And þer vpon þe weyne was fette A noon
We dronke ⁊and to Reste went everiche oon .
Withe outen ony lenger tareyng
A morowe . whan þe day be gan to spryng
Vp Roos oure hooste . and was oure Alder cokke
And gaderid vs to gedir . in A Flocke
And forthe we Redyn A feyre esye pase
Vn to þe watering plase of seynt Thomᵃs
And þer ovre hooste . gan his hors A reste
And saide lordyngis . herkenithe yf ye liste
Yee wote yowr forwarde / if I it yowe recorde
Yf euyn song ⁊and morowe song acorde
Lete seo nowe who shall telle þe firste tale
Als euer mot I drynke weyne or Ale
Who soo beo rekkelle to my Iugement
Shal pay for Al þᵗat by þe wey is spent
Now draueþᵉ cutte . or þᵗat we furþer twynne
Loke wiche þat haþe þe shortest shall byginne
¶ Sir knight quod he . my maister ⁊and my lorde
Now drawethe cutte for þat is myn Acorde
Comiþe x nere quod he my lady prioresse
And sir Clerke / lat be yowre shamefastenesse
Ne studyeþe . lay . hond to euerye man
Anoon til drawe euery wight bygan
And shortly for to tellen as hit was
Were it by Aventure . or soorte or cas
Þe sooþe is þis þe cutte fel to þᵉ knyght
Of wiche fulle blithe / And glad was eủer/rey wight
And tel he mot his tale . as is raysoun
By forwardes pleyne / And Cōmmposicioun
As ye have harde . what nedeþe wordes moo
And whan þis good man saughe / þᵗat it was soo
As he þᵗat was wys and obedient
To kepe his forward . by his free Assent
And sayde syþen I shalle begynne þe game
What welcom be þe cutte on goddis name
Now late vs Ride . and herkenithe what I saye
And wᵗith þat worde we Riden forthe oure weye
Þus he bygan . wᵗith Right A goodly chere
His tale A noon And sayde / as ye may here

hi.hi: Loo here eondiþe þe prologe of þe Knightes tale / and Folowyng þe knyght be gynnithe to telle his tale

div.l: (base) Here bigynneth / the knyghtes tale
(base) c incipit fabula Militis ;
(base) Iamque domos patria Scithice post asꝑper/para gentis laurigero etc Here bigynneth the knygtis tale
(base) Whilom / as olde stories tellen vs
(base) Ther was a Duc that highte Theseus
(base) Of Atthenes / he was lord and gouernour
(base) And in his tyme / swich a conquerour
(base) That gretter was ther noon vnder the sonne
(base) Ful many a riche contree / hadde he wonne
(base) What with his wysdom / and his chiualrye

div.l: (base) He conquered / al the regne of femenye
(base) That whilom / was ycleped Scithia
(base) And wedded / the queene ypolita
(base) And broghte hire hom with hym / in his contree
(base) With muchel glorie / and greet solempnitee
(base) And eek / hir yonge suster Emelye
(base) And thus with victorie / and with melodye
(base) Lete I this noble Duc to Atthenes ryde
(base) And al his hoost . in armes hym bisyde
(base) ¶ And certes / if it nere to long to heere
(base) I wolde haue toold / fully the manere
(base) How / wonnen was the regne of Femenye
(base) By Theseus / and by his Chiualrye
(base) And of the grete bataille / for the nones
(base) Bitwixen Atthenes / and Amazones
(base) And how assegeged was ypolita
(base) The faire hardy queene of Scithia
(base) And of the feste / that was at hir weddynge
(base) And of the tempest at hir hom comynge
(base) But al that thyng I moot as now forbere
(base) I haue god woot a large feeld to ere
(base) And wayke / been the oxen in my plogh
(base) The remenant of the tale / is long ynogh
(base) I wol nat letten eek / noon of this route
(base) Lat euery felawe / telle his tale aboute
(base) And lat se now / who shal the souper wynne
(base) And ther I lefte / I wol ayein bigynne
(base) Incipit narracio
(base) ¶ Here bygynneth the knyghtes tale.
(base) This duc of whom I make mencioun
(base) Whanne he was come / almoost to the town
(base) In al his wele / and in his mooste pryde
(base) He was war / as he caste his eye asyde
(base) Wher that ther kneled / in the heighe weye
(base) A compaignye of ladyes / tweye and tweye
(base) Ech after /oother clad in clothes blake
(base) But swich a cry / and swich a wo they make
(base) That in this world / nys creature lyuynge
(base) That herde / swich another waymentynge
(base) And of this cry / they nolde neuere stenten
(base) Til they / the reynes of his brydel henten
(base) ¶ What folk been ye / that at myn hom comynge
(base) Perturben so my feste / with cryynge
(base) Quod Theseus / haue ye so greet envie
(base) Of myn honour / that thus compleyne and crye
(base) Or who hath yow mysboden / or offended
(base) And telleth me / if it may been amended
(base) And why that ye / been clothed thus in blak /
(base) The eldeste lady / of hem alle spak
(base) Whan she hadde swowned / with a deedly cheere
(base) That it was routhe / for to seen and heere
(base) ¶ She seyde / lord / to whom Fortune hath yiuen
(base) Victorie / and as a Conquerour to lyuen
(base) Noght greueth vs youre glorie / and youre honour
(base) But we biseken / mercy and socour
(base) Haue mercy on oure wo / and oure distresse
(base) Som drope of pitee / thurgh thy gentillesse
(base) Vpon vs wrecched wommen / lat thow falle
(base) For certes lord / ther is noon of vs alle
(base) That she ne hath been / a duchesse / or a queene
(base) Now be we caytyues / as it is wel seene
(base) Thanked be Fortune / and hir false wheel
(base) That noon estaat assureth to been weel
(base) Now certes lord / to abiden youre persence
(base) Heere in this temple / of the goddesse clemence
(base) We haue been waytynge / al this fourtenyght
(base) Now help vs /lord syth it is in thy myght
(base) ¶ I wrecche / which that wepe and waille thus
(base) Was whilom wyf / to kyng Cappaneus
(base) That starf at Thebes / cursed be the day
(base) And alle we / that been in this array
(base) And maken / al this lamentacioun
(base) We losten alle oure housbondes / at that town
(base) Whil that the sege / ther aboute lay
(base) And yet now / the olde Creoun weylaway
(base) That lord is now / of Thebes the Citee
(base) Fulfild of Ire / and of Iniquitee
(base) He for despit and for his tyrannye
(base) To doon / the dede bodyes vileynye
(base) Of alle oure lordes / whiche that been slawe
(base) Hath alle the bodyes / on an heep ydrawe
(base) And wol nat suffren hem / by noon assent
(base) Neyther to been yburyed / nor ybrent
(base) But maketh houndes / ete hem in despit
(base) And with that word / withouten moore respit
(base) They fillen gruf and cryden pitously
(base) Haue / on vs wrecched wommen / som mercy
(base) And lat oure sorwe / synken in thyn herte
(base) ¶ This gentil Duc doun from his courser sterte
(base) With herte pitous / whan he herde hem speke
(base) Hym thoughte / that his herte wolde breke
(base) Whan he saugh hem / so pitous / and so maat
(base) That whilom weren / of so greet estaat
(base) And in hise armes / he hem alle vp hente
(base) And hem conforteth / in ful good entente
(base) And swoor his ooth / as he was trewe knyght
(base) He wolde doon / so ferforthly his myght

div.l: (base) Vpon the tiraunt Creon / hem to wreke
(base) That al the peple of Grece / sholde speke
(base) How Creoun was / of Theseus yserued
(base) As he that hadde his deeth / ful wel disserued
(base) And right anoon / withouten moore abood
(base) His baner he desplayeth / and forth rood
(base) To Thebesward / and al his oost bisyde
(base) No neer Atthenes / wolde he go ne ryde
(base) Ne take his ese / fully half a day
(base) But onward in his wey / that nyght he lay
(base) And sente anoon / ypolita the queene
(base) And Emelye / hir yonge suster sheene
(base) Vnto the town of Atthenes / to dwelle
(base) And forth he ryt ther nys namoore to telle
(base) ¶ The rede statue of Mars / with spere and targe
(base) So shyneth / in his white Baner large
(base) That alle the feeldes / glitren vp and doun
(base) And by his Baner / born was his penoun
(base) Of gold ful ryche / in which ther was ybete
(base) The Mynotaur / which that he wan in Crete
(base) ¶ Thus ryt this Duc . thus ryt this conquerour
(base) And in his oost of Chiualrye the flour
(base) Forth he rode with grete power and myght
(base) Til that he cam to Thebes / and alighte
(base) Faire in a feeld / ther as he thoghte fighte
(base) ¶ But shortly / for to speken of this thyng
(base) With Creoun / which that was of Thebes kyng
(base) He faught and slow hym manly / as a knyght
(base) In pleyn bataille / and putte the folk to flyght
(base) And by assaut he wan the Citee after
(base) And rente adoun / bothe wal / and sparre / and rafter
(base) And to the ladyes / he restored agayn
(base) The bones / of hir freendes / that were slayn
(base) To doon obsequies / as was tho the gyse
(base) But it weere al to long for to deuyse
(base) The grete clamour / and the waymentynge
(base) That the ladyes made / at the brennynge
(base) Of the bodies / and the grete honour
(base) That Theseus / the noble Conquerour
(base) Dooth to the ladys / whan they from hym wente
(base) But shortly / for to telle is myn entente
(base) ¶ Whan that this worthy duc this Theseus
(base) Hath Creoun slayn / and wonne Thebes thus
(base) Stille in that feeld / he took al nyght his reste
(base) And dide withal the contree / as hym leste
(base) ¶ To ransake in the taas / of bodies dede
(base) Hem for to strepe / of harneys / and of wede
(base) The pilours / diden bisynesse / and cure
(base) After the bataille / and disconfiture
(base) And so bifel / in the taas they founde
(base) Thurgh girt with many a greuous blody wownde
(base) Two yonge knyghtes / liggynge by and by
(base) Bothe in oon armes / wroght ful richely
(base) Of whiche two / Arcita highte that oon
(base) And that oother knyght highte Palamon
(base) Nat fully quyk / ne fully deed they weere
(base) But by hir Cote armures / and by hir geere
(base) The heraudes / knewe hem best in special
(base) As they that weren / of the blood roial
(base) Of Thebes / and of sustren two yborn
(base) Out of the taas / the pilours han hem torn
(base) And han hem caryed / softe vnto the tente
(base) Of Theseus / and he ful soone hem sente
(base) To Atthenes / to dwellen in prisoun
(base) Perpetuelly / he nolde no raunsoun
(base) ¶ And whan this worthy duc / hath thus ydoon
(base) He took his oost / and hom he ryt anoon
(base) With laurer corouned / as a conquerour
(base) And there he lyueth / in ioye / and in honour
(base) Terme of his lyf / what nedeth wordes mo
(base) And in a tour / in angwissh and in wo
(base) Dwellen this Palamon / and eek Arcite
(base) For euere moore / ther may no gold hem quyte
(base) ¶ This passeth yeer by yeer / and day by day
(base) Til it fil ones / in a morwe of May
(base) That Emelye / that fairer was to seene
(base) Than is the lilie / vpon his stalke greene
(base) And fressher than the May / with floures newe
(base) For with the Rose colour stroof hir hewe
(base) I noot which was / the fairer of hem two
(base) Er it were day / as was hir wone to do
(base) She was arysen / and al redy dight
(base) For May wol haue / no slogardye a nyght
(base) The sesoun pryketh / euery gentil herte
(base) And maketh it out of his sleep to sterte
(base) And seith arys / and do thyn obseruance
(base) This maketh Emelye / haue remembrance
(base) To doon honour to May / and for to ryse
(base) Yclothed was she fressh / for to deuyse
(base) Hir yelow heer / was broyded in a tresse
(base) Bihynde hir bak a yerde long I gesse
(base) And in the gardyn / at the sonne vp riste
(base) She walketh vp and doun / and as hir liste
(base) She gadreth floures / party white and rede
(base) To make / a subtil gerland for hir hede
(base) And as an Aungel / heuenysshly she soong

div.l: (base) ¶ The grete tour / that was so thikke and strong
(base) Which of the Castel / was the chief dongeoun
(base) Ther as the knyghtes / weren in prisoun
(base) Of whiche I tolde yow / and tellen shal
(base) Was euene ioynant to the gardyn wal
(base) Ther as this Emelye / hadde hir pleyyng
(base) Bright was the sonne / and cleer / in that mornyng
(base) And Palamon / this woful prisoner
(base) As was his wone / by leue of his Gailler
(base) Was risen / and romed in a chambre anheigh
(base) In which / he al the noble Citee seigh
(base) And eek the gardyn / ful of braunches greene
(base) Ther as / the fresshe Emelye the sheene
(base) Was in hir walk / and romed vp and down
(base) This sorweful prisoner / this Palamoun
(base) This wooful louere this Palamon
(base) Gooth in the chambre / romyng to and fro
(base) And to hymself / compleynyng of his wo
(base) That he was born / ful ofte he seyde allas
(base) And so bifel / by auenture / or cas
(base) That thurgh a wyndow / thikke of many a barre
(base) Of Iren greet and square as any sparre
(base) He caste his eye / vpon Emelya
(base) And therwithal he bleynte / and cryde . A .
(base) As thogh / he stongen weere / vnto the herte
(base) ¶ And with that cry / Arcite anoon vp sterte
(base) And seyde cosyn myn / what eyleth thee
(base) That art so pale / and deedly on to see
(base) Why cridestow / who hath thee doon offence
(base) For goddes loue / tak al in pacience
(base) Oure prison / for it may noon oother be
(base) Fortune / hath yeuen vs this aduersitee
(base) Som wikked aspect or disposicioun
(base) Of Saturne / by som constellacioun
(base) Hath yeuen vs this / althogh we hadde it sworn
(base) So stood the heuene / whan that we were born
(base) We mote endure it this is the short and playn
(base) This Palamoun answerde / and seyde agayn
(base) ¶ Cosyn for sothe / of this opinioun
(base) Thow hast a vayn ymaginacioun
(base) This prisoun / caused me noght to crye
(base) But I was hurt right now / thurgh out myn Iye
(base) In to myn herte / that wol my bane be
(base) The fairnesse / of that lady that I se
(base) Yond in the gardyn / romen to and fro
(base) Is cause / of al my cryyng and my wo
(base) I noot wher she be womman / or goddesse
(base) But Venus / is it soothly / as I gesse
(base) And therwithal / on knees down he fil
(base) And seyde / Venus if it be thy wil
(base) Yow in this gardyn / thus to transfigure
(base) Bifore me / sorweful wrecched creature
(base) Out of this prisoun / help that we may scape
(base) And if so be / my destynee be shape
(base) By eterne word / to dyen in prisoun
(base) Of oure lynage / haue som compassioun
(base) That is so lowe ybroght by tirannye
(base) ¶ And with that word / Arcite gan espye
(base) Where as this lady / romed to and fro
(base) And with that sighte / hir beautee hurte hym so
(base) That if that Palamon / was wounded soore
(base) Arcite is hurt . as muche as he / or moore
(base) And with a syk / . he seyde pitously
(base) The fresshe beautee / sleeth me sodeynly
(base) Of hire / that rometh in the yonder place
(base) And but I haue / hir mercy / and hir grace
(base) That I may seen hire / at the leeste weye
(base) I nam but deed / ther nys namoore to seye
(base) ¶ This Palamon / whan he tho wordes herde
(base) Despitously / he loked / and answerde
(base) Wheither seistow this / in ernest or in pley
(base) ¶ Nay quod Arcite / in ernest by my fey
(base) God help me so / me list ful yuele pleye
(base) This Palamon / gan knytte his browes tweye
(base) ¶ It were to thee quod he / no greet honour
(base) For to be fals / ne for to be traytour
(base) To me / that am thy cosyn and thy brother
(base) Ysworn ful depe / and ech of vs til oother
(base) That neuere / for to dyen in the peyne
(base) Til that the deeth / departe shal vs tweyne
(base) Neither of vs / in loue to hyndre oother
(base) Ne in noon oother caas / my leeue brother
(base) But that thow sholdest trewely forthre me
(base) In euery caas / as I shal forthren thee
(base) This was thyn ooth / and myn also certeyn
(base) I woot right wel / thow darst it nat withseyn
(base) Thus artow of my conseil / out of doute
(base) And now / thow woldest falsly been aboute
(base) To loue my lady / whom I loue and serue
(base) And euere shal / til that myn herte sterue
(base) Now certes false Arcite / thow shalt nat so
(base) I loued hire first and tolde thee my wo
(base) As to my conseil / and my brother sworn
(base) To forthre me / as I haue told biforn
(base) For which / thow art ybounden / as a knyght
(base) To helpe me / if it laye in thy myght
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) Or ellis artow fals / I dar wel sayn
(base) This Arcite / ful proudly spak agayn
(base) ¶ Thow shalt quod he / be rather fals than I
(base) And thow art fals / I telle thee outrely
(base) For paramour / I loued hire first er thow
(base) What wiltow seyn / thow woost nat yet now
(base) Wheither she be a womman / or goddesse
(base) Thyn is / affeccioun of holynesse
(base) And myn is loue / as to a creature
(base) For which / I tolde thee myn auenture
(base) As to my cosyn / and my brother sworn
(base) I pose / that thow louedest hire biforn
(base) Wostow nat wel / the olde clerkes sawe
(base) That who shal / yeue a louere any lawe
(base) Quis / legem det amantibz
(base) Loue is a gretter lawe / by my pan
(base) Than may be yeue / to any erthely man
(base) And therfore / posityf lawe / and swich decree
(base) Is broke alday for loue / in ech degree
(base) A man moot nedes loue / maugree his heed
(base) He may nat fleen it / thogh he sholde be deed
(base) Al be she mayde / wydwe / or ellis wyf
(base) And eek it is nat likly / al thy lyf
(base) To stonden in hir grace / namoore shal I
(base) For wel thow woost thy self verraily
(base) That thow and I / been dampned to prisoun
(base) Perpetuelly / vs gayneth no raunsoun
(base) We stryue / as dide the houndes / for the boon
(base) They foghte alday / and yet hir part was noon
(base) Ther cam a kyte / whil that they were so wrothe
(base) That bar awey the boon / bitwix hem bothe
(base) And therfore / at the kynges court my brother
(base) Ech man for hymself / ther is noon oother
(base) Loue if thee lest . for I loue / and ay shal
(base) And soothly / leue brother this is al
(base) Heere in this prisoun / moote we endure
(base) And euerich of vs / take his auenture
(base) ¶ Greet was the stryf / and long bitwix hem tweye
(base) If that I hadde leyser for to seye
(base) But to theffect it happed on a day
(base) To telle it yow / as shortly as I may
(base) A worthy duc . that highte Parotheus
(base) That felawe was / vnto Duc Theseus
(base) Syn thilke day / that they were children lyte
(base) Was come to Atthenes / his felawe to visite
(base) And for to pleye / as he was wont to do
(base) For in this world / he loued no man so
(base) And he loued hym / as tendrely agayn
(base) So wel they loued / as olde bookes sayn
(base) That whan that oon was deed / soothly to telle
(base) His felawe wente / and soghte hym down in helle
(base) But of that storie / list me noght to write
(base) Duc Parotheus / loued wel Arcite
(base) And hadde hym knowe at Thebes / yeer by yere
(base) And finally / at requeste and prayere
(base) Of Parotheus / withouten any raunsoun
(base) Duc Theseus / hym leet out of prisoun
(base) Frely to goon / wher that hym liste oueral
(base) In swich a gyse / as I yow tellen shal
(base) This was the forward / pleynly for tendite
(base) Bitwixe Theseus / and hym Arcite
(base) That if so weere that Arcite weere yfounde
(base) Euere in his lyf by day / or nyght or stounde
(base) In any contree / of this Theseus
(base) And he weere caught . it was acorded thus
(base) That with a swerd / he sholde lese his heed
(base) Ther nas noon oother / remedye ne reed
(base) But taketh his leue / and homward he hym spedde
(base) Lat hym be war / his nekke lyth to wedde
(base) Hit were a gret thing to telle and to wite
(base) ¶ How greet a sorwe / suffreth now Arcite
(base) The deeth he feeleth / thurgh his herte smyte
(base) He wepeth / wayleth / cryeth pitously
(base) To sleen hymself he wayteth pryuely
(base) He seyde allas / the day that I was born
(base) Now is my prisoun / worse than biforn
(base) Now is me shape / eternally to dwelle
(base) Noght in purgatorie / but in helle
(base) Allas / that euere knew I Parotheus
(base) For ellis / hadde I dwelled with Theseus
(base) Yfettred in his prisoun eueremo
(base) Thanne hadde I been in blisse / and nat in wo
(base) Oonly the sighte of hire / whom that I serue
(base) Thogh that I neuere / hir grace may disserue
(base) Wolde haue suffised / right ynogh for me
(base) ¶ O deere cosyn / Palamon / quod he
(base) Thyn is the victorie / of this auenture
(base) Ful blisfully / in prisoun maystow dure
(base) In prison ; / nay certes / but in paradys
(base) Wel hath Fortune / yturned thee / the dys
(base) That hast the sighte of hire / and I thabsence
(base) For possible is / syn thow hast hire presence
(base) And art a knyght a worthy and an able
(base) That by som caas / syn Fortune is chaungeable
(base) Thow mayst to thy desir / som tyme atteyne
(base) But I / that am exiled and bareyne
(base) Of alle grace / and in so greet despeyr
(base) That ther nys Erthe / water / fyr / ne Eyr
(base) Ne creature / that of hem maked is
(base) That may me helpe / or do confort in this
(base) Wel oghte I sterue / in wanhope / and distresse

div.l: (base) Farwel my lyf / my lust and my gladnesse
(base) ¶ Allas / why pleynen folk so / in cōmmune
(base) On purueiance of god / or of Fortune
(base) That yeueth hem ful ofte / in many a gyse
(base) Wel bettre / than they kan hem self deuyse
(base) ¶ Som man desireth / for to haue richesse
(base) That cause is ofte / of his moerdre / or gret siknesse
(base) And som man wolde / out of his prison fayn
(base) That in his hous / is of his meynee slayn
(base) Infinite harmes / been in this matere
(base) We woot nat what thyng that we prayen heere
(base) We fare as he / that dronke is as a Mous
(base) A dronke man woot wel / he hath an hous
(base) But he noot which the righte wey is thider
(base) And to a dronke man / . the wey is slider
(base) And certes / in this world / so faren we
(base) We seken faste / after felicitee
(base) But we goon wrong ful ofte trewely
(base) Thus may we seyn alle / and nameliche I
(base) That wende / and hadde a greet opinioun
(base) That if I myghte / scapen fro prisoun
(base) Thanne hadde I been in ioye / and parfit heele
(base) Ther now / I am exiled fro my wele
(base) Syn that / I may nat seen yow Emelie
(base) I nam but deed / ther nys no remedie
(base) ¶ Vpon that oother syde Palamon
(base) Whan that he wiste / Arcite was agon
(base) Swich sorwe he maketh / that the grete tour
(base) Resowneth / of his yowlyng and clamour
(base) The pure fettres / of his shynes grete
(base) Were / of his bittre salte teeris wete
(base) Allas quod he / Arcita cosyn myn
(base) Of al oure stryf / god woot the fruyt is thyn
(base) Thow walkest now / in Thebes at thy large
(base) And of my wo / thow yeuest litel charge
(base) Thow mayst syn thou hast wisdom / and manhede
(base) Assemblen / al the folk of oure kynrede
(base) And make a werre / so sharp / on this Citee
(base) That by som auenture / or som tretee
(base) Thow mayst haue hire / to lady and to wyf
(base) For whom / that I moste nedes lese my lyf
(base) For as by wey / of possibilitee
(base) Sith thow art at thy large / of prisoun free
(base) And art a lord / greet is thyn auantage
(base) Moore than is myn / that sterue here in a cage
(base) For I moot wepe / and waille whil I lyue
(base) With al the wo / that prison may me yeue
(base) And eek wᵗith peyne / that loue me yeueth also
(base) That doubleth / al my torment and my wo
(base) Ther with / the fyr of Ialousie vp sterte
(base) With Inne his brest and hente hym by the herte
(base) So woodly / that he lyk was to byholde
(base) The Boxtree / or the Asshen dede / and colde
(base) ¶ Thanne seyde he / o crewel goddes / that gouerne
(base) This world / with byndyng of youre word eterne
(base) And writen / in the table of Atthamaıı̄unt
(base) Youre parlement . and youre eterne graıı̄unt
(base) What is man kynde / moore vnto yow holde
(base) Than is the sheep / that rowketh in the folde
(base) For slayn is man / right as another beest
(base) And dwelleth eek in prison and arrest
(base) And hath siknesse / and greet aduersitee
(base) And ofte tymes / giltlees pardee
(base) ¶ What gouernance / is in this prescience
(base) That giltlees / tormenteth Innocence
(base) And yet encreeceth this / al my penance
(base) That man is bounden / to his obseruance
(base) For goddes sake / to letten of his wille
(base) Ther as a beest may al his lust fulfille
(base) And whan a beest is deed / it hath no peyne
(base) But man after his deeth / moot wepe and pleyne
(base) Thogh in this world / he haue care and wo
(base) Withouten doute / it moot stonden so
(base) The answere of this / lete I to diuynys
(base) But wel I woot that in this world / greet pyne is
(base) ¶ Allas / I se a serpent or a theef /
(base) That many a trewe man / hath doon mescheef
(base) Goon at his large / and where hym lust may turne
(base) But I moot been in prison / thurgh Saturne
(base) And eek thurgh Iuno / Ialous / and eek wood
(base) That hath destroyed / wel neigh al the blood
(base) Of Thebes / with his waste walles wyde
(base) And Venus / sleeth me / on that oother syde
(base) For Ialousie / and feere / of hym Arcite
(base) ¶ Now wol I stynte / of Palamon alite
(base) And lete hym / in his prisoun stille dwelle
(base) And of Arcita / forth I wol yow telle
(base) ¶ The Somer / and the nyghtes longe
(base) Encreecen / double wise / the peynes stronge
(base) Bothe of the louere / and the prisoner
(base) I noot which hath / the sorwefuller myster
(base) For soothly for to seyn / this Palamon
(base) Perpetuelly / is dampned to prisoun
(base) In cheynes / and in fettres / to been deed
(base) And Arcite / is exiled / vpon his heed
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) For eueremo / as out of that contree
(base) Ne neueremo / ne shal his lady see
(base) ¶ Yow loueris / axe I now / this questioun
(base) Who hath the worse / Arcite / or Palamoun
(base) That oon may seen his lady / day by day
(base) But in prisoun / moot he dwelle alway
(base) That oother / where hym list may ride or go
(base) But seen his lady / shal he neuere mo
(base) Now demeth as yow list ye that kan
(base) For I wol telle forth / as I bigan
(base) ¶ Explicit prima pars ~
(base) ¶ Sequitur pars secunda ~
(base) ¶ Whan that Arcite / to Thebes comen was
(base) Ful ofte a day / he swelte / and seyde allas
(base) For seen his lady / shal he neuere mo
(base) And shortly / to concluden al his wo
(base) So muchel sorwe / hadde neuere creature
(base) That is or shal / whil that the world may dure
(base) ¶ His sleep / his mete / his drynke / is hym biraft
(base) That leene he weex / and drye as is a shaft
(base) Hise eyen holwe / and grisly to biholde
(base) His hewe falow / and pale as asshen colde
(base) And solitarie he was / and euere alloone
(base) And waillynge al the nyght . makynge his moone
(base) And if he herde / soong or Instrument
(base) Thanne wolde he wepe / he myghte nat be stent
(base) So feble eek were his spiritz / and so lowe
(base) And chaunged so / that no man koude knowe
(base) His speche / nor his voys / thogh men it herde
(base) And in his gere / for al the world he ferde
(base) Nat oonly / lyk the loueris maladye
(base) Of Hereos / but rather lyk Manye
(base) Engendred / of humour malencolyk
(base) Biforn his Celle fantastyk
(base) And shortly / turned was / al vp so down
(base) Bothe habit and eek disposicioun
(base) Of hym / this woful louere daun Arcite
(base) ¶ What sholde I al day / of his wo endite
(base) Whanne he endured hadde / a yeer / or two
(base) This cruel torment and this peyne and wo
(base) At Thebes in his contree / as I seyde
(base) Vpon a nyght in sleep / as he hym leyde
(base) Hym thoughte / how that the wynged god Mercurye
(base) Biforn hym stood / and bad hym to be murye
(base) His slepy yerde / in honde he bar vprighte
(base) An hat he wered / vpon his herys brighte
(base) Arrayed was this god / as he took keep
(base) As he was / whan that Argus took his sleep
(base) And seyde hym thus / to Atthenes shaltow wende
(base) Ther is thee shapen / of thy wo an ende
(base) ¶ And with that word / Arcite wook and sterte
(base) Now trewely / how sore that me smerte
(base) Quod he / to Atthenes right now wol I fare
(base) Ne for the drede of deeth / shal I nat spare
(base) To se my lady / that I loue and serue
(base) In hir presence / I recche nat to sterue
(base) ¶ And with that word / he caughte a greet Mirour
(base) And saugh / that chaunged was al his colour
(base) And saugh his visage / al in another kynde
(base) And right anoon / it ran hym in his mynde
(base) That sith his face / was so disfigured
(base) Of maladie / the which he hadde endured
(base) He myghte wel / if that he bar hym lowe
(base) Lyue in Atthenes / eueremoore vnknowe
(base) And seen his lady / wel ny / day by day
(base) And right anoon / he chaunged his array
(base) And cladde hym / as a poure laborer
(base) And al allone / saue oonly a Squyer
(base) That knew his pryuetee / and al his cas
(base) Which was disgised / pourely as he was
(base) To Atthenes / is he goon / the nexte way
(base) And to the Court he wente vpon a day
(base) And at the gate / he profreth his seruyse
(base) To drugge and drawe / what so men wol deuyse
(base) ¶ And shortly / of this matere / for to seyn
(base) He fil in office / with a Chambreleyn
(base) The which / that dwellyng was wᵗith Emelye
(base) For he was wys / and koude soone espye
(base) Of euery seruant which that serueth here
(base) Wel koude he / hewen wode / and water bere
(base) For he was yong . and myghty for the nones
(base) And ther to / he was strong and byg of bones
(base) To doon / what any wight kan hym deuyse
(base) A yeer / or two / he was in this seruyse
(base) Page of the chambre / of Emelie the brighte
(base) And Philostrate / he seyde that he highte
(base) ¶ But half so wel biloued a man / as he
(base) Ne was ther neuere in Court of his degree
(base) He was so gentil / of condicioun
(base) That thurgh out al the Court was his renoun
(base) They seiden / that it were a charitee
(base) That Theseus / wolde enhauncen his degree
(base) And putten hym / in worshipful seruyse
(base) Ther as he myghte / his vertu excercise
(base) And thus with Inne a while / his name is spronge
(base) Bothe of his dedes / and his goode tonge
(base) That Theseus / hath taken hym so ner
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) That of his chambre / he made hym a Squier
(base) And gaf hym gold / to mayntene his degree
(base) And eek men broghte hym / out of his contree
(base) Fro yeer to yeer / ful pryuely his rente
(base) But honestly / and sleighly / he it spente
(base) That no man wondred / how that he it hadde
(base) And thre yeer in this wise / his lyf he ladde
(base) And bar hym so / in pees / and ek in werre
(base) Ther was no man / that Theseus hath derre
(base) And in this blisse / lete I now Arcite
(base) And speke I wole / of Palamon alite
(base) ¶ In derknesse / and horrible / and strong prisoun
(base) This seuen yeer / hath seten Palamoun
(base) Forpyned / what for wo / and for distresse
(base) Who feeleth / double soor / and heuynesse
(base) But Palamon / that loue destreyneth so
(base) That wood out of his wit he gooth for wo
(base) And eek ther to / he is a prisoner
(base) Perpetuelly / nat oonly for a yer
(base) Who koude ryme / in englissh proprely
(base) His martirdom / for sothe it am noght I
(base) Therfore I passe / as lightly / as I may
(base) ¶ It fil / that / in that seuenthe yeer of May
(base) I wylle not taire yow alle the day
(base) The thridde nyght . as olde bokes seyn
(base) That al this storie / tellen moore pleyn
(base) Were it by auenture / or destynee
(base) As whan a thyng is shapen / it shal be
(base) That soone after the mydnyght Palamoun
(base) By helpyng of a freend / brak his prisoun
(base) And fleeth the Citee / faste as he may go
(base) For he hadde yeue / his Gailler drynke so
(base) Of a Clarree / maad of certeyn wyn
(base) With Nercotikes / and opye / of Thebes fyn / /
(base) That al that nyght . thogh that men wolde hym shake
(base) The Gailler sleep / he myghte noght awake
(base) ¶ And thus he fleeth / as faste as euere he may
(base) The nyght was short and faste by the day
(base) That nedes cost he moste hymseluen hyde
(base) And til a groue / faste ther bisyde
(base) With dreedful foot thanne stalketh Palamoun
(base) For shortly / this was his opynyoun
(base) That in that groue / he wolde hym hyde al day
(base) And in the nyght thanne wolde he take his way
(base) To Thebesward / his freendes for to preye
(base) On Theseus / to helpe hym to werreye
(base) And shortly / outher he wolde lese his lyf /
(base) Or wynnen Emelie / vnto his wyf
(base) This is the effect and his entente pleyn
(base) ¶ Now wol I turne / to Arcite ageyn
(base) That litel wiste / how neigh that was his care
(base) Til that Fortune / hadde broght hym / in the snare
(base) ¶ The bisy larke / messager of day
(base) Salueth in hir song the morwe gray
(base) And firy Phebus / riseth vp so brighte
(base) That al the Orient . laugheth of the lighte
(base) And with his stremes / dryeth in the greues
(base) The siluer dropes / hangynge on the leues
(base) And Arcita / that in the Court roial
(base) With Theseus / is Squyer principal
(base) Is risen / and looketh on the murye day
(base) And for to doon / his obseruance to May
(base) Remembrynge / on the point of his desir
(base) He on a Courser / startlynge as the fir
(base) Is riden in to the feldes / hym to pleye
(base) Out of the Court . were it a myle / or tweye
(base) And to the groue / of which that I yow tolde
(base) By auenture / his wey he gan to holde
(base) To maken hym / a gerland of the greues
(base) Were it of wodebynde / or hawethorn leues
(base) And loude he soong . ayein the sonne shene
(base) May / with alle thy floures / and thy grene
(base) Wel come be thow / faire fresshe May
(base) In hope / that I som grene gete may
(base) And from his courser / with a lusty herte
(base) In to the groue / ful hastily he sterte
(base) And in a path / he rometh vp and doun
(base) Ther as by auenture / this Palamoun
(base) Was in a bussh / that no man myghte hym se
(base) For soore afered / of his deeth was he
(base) No thyng knew he / that it was Arcite
(base) God woot he wolde haue trowed it ful lite
(base) But sooth is seyd / go sithen many yeris
(base) That feeld hath eyen / and the wode hath erys
(base) It is ful fair / a man to bere hym euene
(base) For alday meeten men / at vnset steuene
(base) Ful litel woot Arcite / of his felawe
(base) That was so neigh / to herknen al his sawe
(base) For in the bussh / he sitteth now ful stille
(base) ¶ Whan that Arcite / hadde romed al his fille
(base) And songen al the roundel lustily
(base) In to a studie / he fil sodeynly
(base) As doon thise louerys / in hir queynte gerys
(base) Now in the crop / now down in the brerys
(base) Now vp / now down / as boket in a welle
(base) Right as the friday / soothly for to telle
(base) Now it shyneth / now it reyneth faste
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) Right so / kan gery Venus ouercaste
(base) The hertes of hir folk . right as hir day
(base) Is gerful / right so chaungeth she array
(base) Selde is the friday / al the wike ylike
(base) ¶ Whan that Arcite hadde songe / he gan to syke
(base) And sette hym down / withouten any moore
(base) Allas quod he / that day / that I was bore
(base) How longe Iuno / thurgh thy crueltee
(base) Woltow werreyen / Thebes the Citee
(base) Allas / ybroght is to confusioun
(base) The blood roial / of Cadme and Amphioun
(base) ¶ Of Cadmus / which that was the firste man
(base) That Thebes bulte / and first bigan
(base) And of the Citee / first was crowned kyng
(base) Of his lynage am I / and his of spryng
(base) By verray ligne / as of the stok roial
(base) And now I am / so caytyf and so thral
(base) That he that is / my mortal enemy
(base) I serue hym / as his Squyer pourely
(base) And yet dooth Iuno / me wel moore shame
(base) For I dar noght biknowe myn owen name
(base) But ther as I was wont to highte Arcite
(base) Now highte I Philostrate / noght worth a myte
(base) ¶ Allas thow felle Mars / allas Iuno
(base) Thus hath youre Ire / oure lynage al fordo
(base) Saue oonly me / and wrecched Palamoun
(base) That Theseus / martireth in prisoun
(base) ¶ And oueral this / to sleen me outrely
(base) Loue hath his firy dart so brennyngly
(base) Ystiked / thurgh my trewe careful herte
(base) That shapen was my deeth / erst than my sherte
(base) Ye sleen me with youre eyen / Emelye
(base) Ye been the cause / wherfore that I dye
(base) Of al the remenant of myn oother care
(base) Ne sette I noght . the mountaunce of a tare
(base) So that I koude doon aught . to youre plesaunce
(base) And with that word / he fil down in a traunce
(base) A longe tyme / and afterward he vp sterte
(base) ¶ This Palamoun / that thoughte / that thurgh his herte
(base) He felte a coold swerd / sodeynly glyde
(base) For Ire he quook . no lenger wolde he byde
(base) And whan that he had herd / Arcites tale
(base) As he were wood / wᵗith face deed and pale
(base) He stirte hym vp / out of the buskes thikke
(base) And seyde Arcite / false traytour wikke
(base) Now art thow hent that louest my lady so
(base) For whom that I haue / al this peyne and wo
(base) And art my blood / and to my conseil sworn
(base) As I ful ofte / haue toold thee her biforn
(base) And hast byiaped here / duc Theseus
(base) And falsly / chaunged hast thy name thus
(base) I wol be deed / or ellis thow shalt dye
(base) Thow shalt noght / loue my lady Emelye
(base) But I wol loue hire oonly / and namo
(base) For I am Palamon / thy mortal foo
(base) And thogh that I / no wepne haue in this place
(base) But out of prisoun / am astert by grace
(base) I drede noght that outher thow shalt dye
(base) Or thow ne shalt noght louen Emelye
(base) Chees which thow wolt or thow shalt noght asterte
(base) ¶ This Arcite / with ful despitous herte
(base) Whan he hym knew / and hadde his tale herd
(base) As fiers as leoun / pulled out his swerd
(base) As fers as a liou saide thus be god that sittith aboue
(base) And seyde thus / by god that sitteth aboue
(base) Nere it that thow art syk and wood for loue
(base) And eek that thow / no wepne hast in this place
(base) Thow sholdest neuere / out of this groue pace
(base) But out of prisoun art y stert by grace
(base) That thow ne sholdest dyen of myn hond
(base) For I diffye / the seuretee and the bond
(base) Which that thow seist that I haue maad to thee
(base) What verray fool / thynk wel that loue is free
(base) And I wol loue hire / maugree al thy myght
(base) ¶ But for as muche / as thow art a worthy knyght
(base) And wilnest to darreyne hire by bataille
(base) Haue here my trouthe / tomorwe I nyl nat faille
(base) Withouten wityng of any oother wight
(base) That here I wol be founden / as a knyght
(base) And bryngen harneys / right ynogh for thee
(base) And chees the beste / and leef the worste to me
(base) And mete and drynke / this nyght wol I brynge
(base) Ynogh for thee / and clothes for thy beddynge
(base) And if so be / that thow my lady wynne
(base) And sle me in this wode / ther I am Inne
(base) Thow mayst wel haue thy lady / as for me
(base) ¶ This Palamon answerde / I graunte it thee
(base) And thus they been departed / til amorwe
(base) Whan ech of hem / hadde leyd his feith to borwe
(base) ¶ O Cupide / out of alle charitee
(base) O regne / that wolde no felawe haue to thee
(base) Ful sooth is seyd / that loue ne lordshipe
(base) Wol noght his thankes / haue no felaweshipe
(base) Wel fynden that Arcite and Palamoun
(base) ¶ Arcite / is riden anoon / vnto the town
(base) And on the morwe / er it were dayes lyght
(base) Ful priuely / two harneys hath he dyght
(base) Bothe suffisaunt and mete to darreyne
(base) The bataille in the feeld / bitwix hem tweyne
(base) And on his hors / allone / as he was born
(base) He carieth al this harneys / hym biforn
