div.l: (base) And in the groue / at tyme and place yset
(base) This Arcite / and this Palamon been met
(base) ¶ To chaungen / gan the colour in hir face
(base) Right as the hunterys / in the regne of Trace
(base) That stonden at the gappe / with a spere
(base) Whanne hunted is / the leoun or the Bere
(base) And hereth hym / come russhynge in the greues
(base) And breketh / bothe bowes / and the leues
(base) And thynketh / here cometh my mortal enemy
(base) Withoute faille / he moot be deed / or .I.
(base) For outher / I moot sleen hym / at the gappe
(base) Or he moot sle me / if that me myshappe
(base) So ferden they / in chaungyng of hir hewe
(base) As fer / as euerich / oother of hem knewe
(base) ¶ Ther nas no good day / ne no saluynge
(base) But streight withouten word / or rehersynge
(base) Euerich of hem / heelp for to armen oother
(base) As frendly / as he weere / his owene brother
(base) And after that with sharpe speres stronge
(base) They foynen / ech at oother / wonder longe
(base) Thou myghtest wene / that this Palamoun
(base) In his fightyng were a wood leoun
(base) And as a crewel Tygre / was Arcite
(base) As wilde boores / gonnen they to smyte
(base) That frothen / whit as foom / for Ire wood
(base) Vp to the Anclees / foghte they in hir blood
(base) And in this wise / I lete hem fightyng dwelle
(base) And forth I wole / of Theseus yow telle
(base) ¶ The destynee / Ministre general
(base) That executeth / in the world oueral
(base) The purueiance / that god hath seyn biforn
(base) So stroong it is / that thogh the world hadde sworn
(base) The contrarie of a thyng by ye / or nay
(base) Yet som tyme / it shal fallen on a day
(base) That falleth nat eft / with Inne a thousand yeer
(base) For certeinly / oure appetites heer
(base) Be it of werre / or pees / or hate / or loue
(base) Al is this ruled / by the sighte aboue
(base) ¶ This mene I now / by myghty Theseus
(base) That for to hunten / is so desirus
(base) And namely / at the grete hert in May
(base) That in his bed / ther daweth hym no day
(base) That he nys clad / and redy for to ryde
(base) With hunte and horn / and houndes hym bisyde
(base) For in his huntyng hath he swich delit
(base) That it is / al his ioye and appetit
(base) To been hymself the grete hertes bane
(base) For after Mars / he serueth now Diane
(base) ¶ Cleer was the day / as I haue told er this
(base) And Theseus / with alle ioye and blys
(base) With his ypolita / the faire queene
(base) And Emelie / clothed al in greene
(base) On huntyng be they riden roially
(base) And to the groue / that stood ful faste by
(base) In which ther was an hert as men hym tolde
(base) Duc Theseus / the streighte wey hath holde
(base) And to the launde / he rideth hym ful right
(base) For thider was the hert wont haue his flight
(base) And ouer a brook / and so forth on his weye
(base) This duc / wol han a cours at hym / or tweye
(base) With houndes swiche / as that hym list comaunde
(base) And whan this Duc. was come vnto the launde
(base) Vnder the sonne he looketh / and anon
(base) He was war / of Arcite and Palamoun
(base) That foghten breme / as it were boles two
(base) The brighte swerdes / wenten to and fro
(base) So hidously / that with the leeste strook
(base) It semed / as it wolde felle an ook
(base) But what they weere / no thyng he ne woot
(base) This Duc his courser / with the spores smoot
(base) And at a stert he was bitwix hem two
(base) And pulled out a swerd / and cryed hoo
(base) Namoore / vpon peyne / of lesyng of youre heed
(base) By myghty Mars / he shal anon be deed
(base) That smyteth any strook / that I may seen
(base) But telleth me / what myster men ye been
(base) That been so hardy / for to fighten heer
(base) Withouten Iuge / or oother officer
(base) As it weere in a lystes roially
(base) ¶ This Palamon / answerde hastily
(base) And seyde / sire / what nedeth wordes mo
(base) And seide sire what nedith wordes moo
(base) We haue the deeth disserued / bothe two
(base) Two woful wrecches been we / two caytyues
(base) That been encombred / of oure owene lyues
(base) And as thow art a rightful lord and Iuge
(base) Ne yif vs / neither mercy ne refuge
(base) But slee me first. for seinte charitee
(base) But slee my felawe eek as wel as me
(base) Or slee hym first. for thogh thow knowe it lite
(base) This is thy mortal foo / this is Arcite
(base) That fro thy lond / is banysshed on his heed
(base) For which / he hath deserued to be deed
(base) For this is he / that cam vnto thy yate
(base) And seyde / that he highte Philostrate
(base) Thus hath he iaped thee / ful many a yeer
(base) And thow hast maked hym / thy chief Squyer
(base) And this is he / that loueth Emelye

div.l: (base) For sith the day is come / that I shal dye
(base) I make pleynly / my confessioun
(base) That I am / thilke woful Palamoun
(base) That hath thy prisoun / broken wikkedly
(base) I am thy mortal foo / and it am I
(base) That loueth so hoote / Emelye the brighte
(base) That I wol dyen / present in hir sighte
(base) Wherfore I axe deeth / and my Iuwise
(base) But slee my felawe / in the same wise
(base) For bothe haue we / deserued to be slayn
(base) ¶ This worthy Duc answerde anoon agayn
(base) And seyde / this is a short conclusioun
(base) Youre owene mouth / by youre confessioun
(base) Hath dampned yow / and I wol it recorde
(base) It nedeth noght to pyne yow with the corde
(base) Ye shul be deed / by myghty Mars the rede
(base) ¶ The queene anoon / for verray wommanhede
(base) Gan for to wepe / and so dide Emelye
(base) And alle the ladies / in the compaignye

(base) That yet men wenen / that no mannes wit
(base) Of noon estaat ne koude amenden it /
(base) ¶ The Mynstralcye / the seruyce / at the feeste
(base) The grete yiftes / to the meeste and leeste
(base) The ryche array / of Theseus Paleys
(base) Ne who sat first or last vpon the deys

(base) Ne who moost feelyngly / speketh of loue
(base) What haukes sitten / on the perche aboue

div.l: (base) Now comth the point and herkneth if yow leste
(base) ¶ The Sonday nyght er day bigan to sprynge
(base) Whan Palamon / the larke herde synge
(base) Althogh it nere nat day / by houres two
(base) Yet soong the larke / and Palamon right tho
(base) Vnto the temple purposeth he to go
(base) With holy herte / and with an heigh corage
(base) He roos / to wenden on his pilgrymage
(base) Vnto the blisful / Scitherea benygne
(base) I mene Venus / honurable and digne
(base) And in hir hour / he walketh forth a paas
(base) Vnto the lystes / ther hir temple was
(base) And down he kneleth / and with humble cheere
(base) And herte soor / he seyde as ye shal heere
(base) ¶ Faireste of faire / o lady myn Venus
(base) Doghter of Ioue / and spouse to Vulcanus
(base) Thow gladere / of the mount of Cytheron
(base) For thilke loue / thow haddest to Adoon
(base) Haue pitee / of my bittre teerys smerte
(base) And taak myn humble prayere at thyn herte
(base) ¶ Allas I ne haue no langage to telle
(base) Theffect. ne the tormentz of myn helle
(base) Myn herte / may myne harmes nat biwreye
(base) I am so confus / that I kan noght seye
(base) But mercy lady bright that knowest wele
(base) My thoght and seest what harmes that I feele
(base) Considre al this / and rewe vpon my soore
(base) As wisly / as I shal for euere moore
(base) Emforth my myght thy trewe seruant be
(base) And holden werre / alwey with chastitee
(base) That make I myn avow / so ye me helpe
(base) I kepe noght of armes for to yelpe
(base) Ne I ne axe noght to morwe / to haue victorie
(base) Ne renoun in this cas / ne veyne glorie
(base) Of prys of armes / blowen vp and down
(base) But I wolde haue / fully possessioun
(base) Of Emelye / and dye in thy seruyse
(base) Fynd thow the manere / how / and in what wyse
(base) I recche nat but it may bettre be
(base) To haue victorie of hem / or they of me
(base) So that I haue / my lady in myn armes
(base) For thogh so be / that Mars is god of armes
(base) Youre vertu is so greet in heuene aboue
(base) That if yow list I shal wel haue my loue
(base) ¶ Thy temple / wol I worshipe eueremo
(base) And on thyn Auter / wher I ryde or go
(base) I wol doon sacrifice / and fyres beete
(base) And if ye wol noght so / my lady sweete
(base) Thanne praye I thee / to morwe with a spere
(base) That Arcita / me thurgh the herte bere
(base) Thanne rekke I noght whan I haue lost my lyf
(base) Thogh that Arcita / wynne hire to his wyf
(base) This is theffect and ende of my prayere
(base) Yif me my loue / thow blisful lady deere
(base) ¶ Whan the orison was doon / of Palamon

(base) ¶ The thridde hour in equal / that Palamon

(base) The hornes ful of Mede / as was the gyse

(base) ¶ Smokynge the temple / ful of clothes faire
(base) This Emelye / with herte debonaire
(base) Hir body wessh / with water of a welle
(base) Hire body wesshe with herte debonarie
(base) But hou she dide hir ryte / I dar nat telle
(base) But it be / any thyng in general
(base) And yet it were a game / to heren al

(base) ¶ Hir brighte heer was kembed / vntressed al
(base) A corone / of a grene ook cerial
(base) Vpon hir heed was set ful fair and meete

(base) And dide hir thynges / as men may biholde
(base) In Stace of Thebes / and othere bokes olde
(base) Whan kyndled was the fyr / with pitous cheere
(base) Vnto Diane / she spak / as ye may heere
(base) ¶ O chaste goddesse / of the wodes grene
(base) To whom / bothe heuene / and erthe / and See is seene
(base) Queene of the regne of Pluto / derk and lowe
(base) Goddesse of maydens / that myn herte hast knowe
(base) Ful many a yeer / and woost what I desire
(base) As keep me / fro thy vengeance and thyn Ire
(base) That Attheoun / aboghte crewelly
(base) Chaste goddesse / wel wostow that I

div.l: (base) Desire / to been a mayden / al my lyf
(base) Ne neuere wol I be / no loue / ne wyf
(base) I am thow woost yet of thy compaignye
(base) A mayde / and loue huntyng and venerye
(base) And for to walken / in the wodes wilde
(base) And noght to been a wyf / and be with childe
(base) Noght wol I knowe / compaignye of man
(base) Now help me lady / sith ye may and kan
(base) For tho thre formes / that thow hast in thee
(base) And Palamon / that hath swich loue to me
(base) And eek Arcite / that loueth me so soore
(base) This grace I praye thee / withoute moore
(base) As seend loue and pees / bitwix hem two
(base) And fro me / turn awey / hir hertes so
(base) That al hir hote loue / and hir desir
(base) And al hir bisy torment and hir fyr
(base) Be queynt and turned in another place
(base) And if so be / thow wolt noght do me grace
(base) Or if my destynee / be shape so
(base) That I shal nedes / haue oon of hem two
(base) As seend me hym / that moost desireth me
(base) Bihoold goddesse / of clene chastitee
(base) The bittre teerys / that on my chekes falle
(base) Syn thow art mayde / and kepere of vs alle
(base) My maydenhode thow kepe / and wel conserue
(base) And whil I lyue / a mayde I wol thee serue
(base) ¶ The fyres brenne / vpon the Auter cleere
(base) Whil Emelie / is thus in hir prayere
(base) But sodeynly / she seigh a sighte queynte
(base) For right anon / oon of the fyres queynte
(base) And quyked agayn / and after that anon
(base) That oother fyr was queynt and al agon
(base) And as it queynte / it made a whistlynge
(base) As doon thise weete brondes / in hir brennynge
(base) And at the brondes ende / out ran anoon
(base) As it were / blody dropes many oon
(base) For which / so soore agast was Emelye
(base) That she was wel neigh mad / and gan to crye
(base) For she ne wiste / what it signyfied
(base) But oonly for the feere / thus hath she cryed
(base) And weep / that it was pitee for to heere
(base) ¶ And therwithal / Diane gan appeere
(base) With bowe in honde / right as an hunteresse
(base) And seyde doghter / stynt thyn heuynesse
(base) Among the goddes hye / it is affermed

(base) Thou shalt be wedded / vnto oon of tho

(base) Fare wel / for I ne may no lenger dwelle
(base) The fires / whiche that on myn Auter brenne
(base) Shul thee declaren / er that thow go henne
(base) Thyn auenture of loue / as in this cas
(base) And with that word / the Arwes in the Caas
(base) Of the goddesse / clateren faste and rynge
(base) And forth she wente / and made a vanysshynge
(base) For which / this Emelye astoned was
(base) And seyde / what amounteth this allas
(base) I putte me / in thy proteccioun
(base) Diane / and in thy disposicioun
(base) And hoom she gooth anoon / the nexte weye
(base) This is theffect ther nys namoore to seye
(base) ¶ The nexte houre of Mars / folwynge this
(base) Arcite / vnto the temple walked is
(base) Of fierse Mars / to doon his sacrifise
(base) With alle the rytes / of his payen wise
(base) With pitous herte / and heigh deuocioun
(base) Right thus to Mars / he seyde his orisoun
(base) ¶ O stronge god / that in the regnes colde
(base) Of Trace / honoured art and lord yholde
(base) And hast in euery regne / and euery lond
(base) Of armes / al the brydel in thyn hond
(base) And hem fortunest as thee list deuyse
(base) Accepte of me / my pitous sacrifise
(base) If so be / that my youthe may disserue
(base) And that my myght be worthy for to serue
(base) Thy godhede / that I may be oon of thyne
(base) Thanne praye I thee / to rewe vpon my pyne
(base) For thilke peyne / and thilke hote fyr
(base) In which / thow whilom brendest for desir
(base) Whan that thow vsedest the beautee
(base) Of faire yonge / fresshe Venus free
(base) And haddest hire / in armes at thy wille
(base) Although thee ones / on a tyme mysfille
(base) Whan Vulcanus / hadde caught thee in his laas
(base) And foond thee lyggyng by his wyf allas
(base) For thilke sorwe / that was in thyn herte
(base) Haue routhe as wel / vpon my peynes smerte
(base) I am yong / and vnkonnyng as thow woost /
(base) And as I trowe / with loue offended moost
(base) That euere was / any lyues creature
(base) For she that dooth me / al this wo endure
(base) Ne reccheth neuere / wher I synke or fleete
(base) And wel I woot er she me mercy heete
(base) I moot with strengthe / wynne hire in the place
(base) And wel I woot withouten help and grace

div.l: (base) Of thee / ne may my strengthe noght auaille
(base) Thanne help me lord / tomorwe in my bataille
(base) For thilke fyr / that whilom brende thee
(base) As wel as thilke fyr / now brenneth me
(base) And do that I tomorwe / may haue victorie
(base) Myn be the trauaille / and thyn be the glorie
(base) Thy souereyn temple / wol I moost honouren
(base) Of any place / and alwey moost labouren
(base) In thy plesaunce / and in thy craftes stronge
(base) And in thy temple / I wol my baner honge
(base) And alle the armes / of my compaignye
(base) And euere mo / vn til that day I dye
(base) Eterne fyr / I wol bifore thee fynde
(base) And eek to this auow / I wol me bynde
(base) My berd / myn heer / that hangeth long adown
(base) That neuere yet ne felte offensioun
(base) Of Rasour / nor of Shere / I wol thee yiue
(base) And been thy trewe seruant whil I lyue
(base) Now lord haue routhe / vpon my sorwes soore
(base) Yif me the victorie / I axe thee namoore
(base) ¶ The prayere stynt of Arcita the stronge
(base) The rynges / on the temple dore that honge
(base) And eek the dores / clatereden ful faste
(base) Of which Arcita / som what hym agaste
(base) The fires brende / vpon the Auter brighte

(base) A swete smel / anoon the ground vp yaf
(base) And Arcita / anoon his hand vp haf

(base) With othere rytes mo / and at the laste
(base) ¶ The statue of Mars / bigan his hauberk rynge
(base) And with that sown / he herde a murmurynge
(base) Ful lowe and dym / and seyde thus / victorie

(base) ¶ And thus with ioye / and hope / wel to fare
(base) Arcite anoon / vnto his In is fare
(base) As fayn as fowel / is of the brighte sonne
(base) ¶ And right anoon / swich stryf ther is bigonne
(base) For thilke grauntyng in the heuene aboue
(base) Bitwixe Venus / the goddesse of loue
(base) And Mars / the sterne god armipotente
(base) That Iuppiter / was bisy it to stente
(base) Til that the pale / Saturnus the colde
(base) That knew so manye / of auentures olde
(base) Foond in his olde experience / an art

(base) As sooth is seyd / elde hath greet auantage
(base) In elde / is bothe wisdom and vsage
(base) Men may the olde at renne / and nat atrede
(base) Saturne anoon / to stynten stryf and drede
(base) Al be it that it is agayn his kynde
(base) Of al this stryf he kan remedie fynde
(base) ¶ My deere doghter Venus / quod Saturne
(base) My cours / that hath so wyde for to turne
(base) Hath moore power / than woot any man
(base) Myn is the drenchyng in the See so wan
(base) Myn is the prison / in the derke cote
(base) Myn is the stranglyng and hangyng by the throte
(base) The murmur / and the cherles rebellynge
(base) The groynyng and the pryuee empoysonynge
(base) I do vengeance / and pleyn correccioun
(base) Whil I dwelle / in the signe of the leoun
(base) Myn is the ruyne / of the heighe halles
(base) The fallyng of the toures / and of the walles
(base) Vpon the Mynour / or the Carpenter
(base) I slow Sampson / shakyng the piler
(base) And myne be / the maladies colde
(base) The derke tresons / and the castes olde
(base) My lookyng is the fader of pestilence
(base) Now weep namoore / I shal doon diligence
(base) That Palamon / that is thyn owene knyght
(base) Shal haue his lady / as thow hast hym hight
(base) Thogh Mars shal helpe his knyght yet nathelees
(base) Bitwixe yow / ther moot be som tyme pees
(base) Al be ye noght of o complexioun
(base) That causeth al day / swich diuisioun
(base) I am thyn Aiel / redy at thy wille
(base) Weep now namoore / I wol thy lust fulfille
(base) ¶ Now wol I stynten / of the goddes aboue
(base) Of Mars / and of Venus / goddesse of loue
(base) And telle yow / as pleynly as I kan
(base) The grete effect. for which that I bigan
(base) ¶ Explicit tercia pars ~
(base) ¶ Sequitʳ pars quarta ~
(base) ¶ Greet was the feeste / in Atthenes that day
(base) And eek the lusty sesoun / of that May
(base) Made euery wight to been in swich plesaunce
(base) That al that monday / Iusten they and daunce
(base) And spenden it in Venus heigh seruyse
(base) And by the cause / that they sholde ryse
(base) Erly / for to seen the grete sight
(base) Vnto hir reste / wente they at nyght
(base) And on the morwe / whan the day gan sprynge
(base) Of hors and harneys / noyse and claterynge

div.l: (base) Of lordes / vpon steedes and palfreys
(base) Ther maist thow seen / deuysynge of harneys
(base) So vnkouth / and so ryche / and wroght so weel
(base) Of Goldsmythrye / of Broudyng and of steel
(base) The sheldes brighte / testers / and trappures
(base) Gold hewen helmes / hauberkes / cote armures
(base) Lordes in parementz / on hir coursers
(base) Knyghtes of retenue / and eek Squyers

(base) Gyggynge of sheeldes / with layners lasynge
(base) Ther as nede is / they were no thyng ydel
(base) The fomy steedes / on the golden brydel
(base) Gnawynge / and faste the Armurers also

(base) Yemen on foote / and communes many oon

(base) Pipes / trompes / Nakers / Claryounes
(base) That in the bataille / blowen blody sownes
(base) The paleys ful of peples / vp and down
(base) Heer thre / ther ten / holdynge hir questioun
(base) Deuynynge / of thise Thebans knyghtes two
(base) Somme seyde thus / somme seyden it shal be so
(base) Somme helden with hym / with the blake berd
(base) Somme with the balled / somme with the thikke herd

(base) He hath a Sparth / of twenty pound of wighte
(base) Thus was the halle / ful of deuynynge
(base) Longe after / that the sonne gan to sprynge
(base) ¶ The grete Theseus / that of his sleep awaked
(base) With mynstralcye / and noyse that was maked
(base) Held yet the chambres / of his paleys ryche
(base) Til that the Theban knyghtes / bothe yliche
(base) Honoured /. weren in to the Paleys fet
(base) ¶ Duc Theseus / is at a wyndow set
(base) Arrayed / right as he weere a god in Trone
(base) The peple preeseth / thiderward ful soone
(base) Hym for to seen / and doon heigh reuerence

(base) ¶ An heraud on a Scaffold / made an .oo.
(base) Til al the noyse / of the peple was ydo

(base) ¶ The lord hath / of his heighe discrecioun
(base) Considred / that it were destruccioun
(base) To gentil blood / to fighten in the gyse

(base) Wher fore / to shapen / that they shal noght dye
(base) He wole / his firste purpos modifie
(base) ¶ No man therfore / vpon peyne / of los of lyf
(base) No manere shot ne polax / ne short knyf

(base) ¶ The voys of peple / touched the heuene

(base) God saue swich a lord / that is so good

(base) ¶ Vp goon the trompes / and the melodye
(base) And to the lystes / ryt the compaignye
(base) By ordinance / thurgh out the Citee large
(base) Hanged with clooth of gold / and noght with sarge
(base) ¶ Ful lyk a lord / this noble duc gan ryde
(base) Thise two Thebans / vpon eyther syde
(base) And after rood the queene / and Emelye

(base) Ypolita the queene / and Emelye

(base) Arcite / and eek the hundred of his parte

(base) ¶ And in that selue moment Palamoun

div.l: (base) That any hadde / of oother auantage
(base) Of worthynesse / ne of estaat ne age

(base) ¶ Whan that hir names / rad were euerichon

(base) Of his welfare / that loueth hem so weel
(base) Kan he hem thank nay god woot neuer a deel
(base) That bothe his soule / and eek hem self offende
(base) And yet they mowe / hir lustes nat amende
(base) ¶ What may I conclude / of this longe serye
(base) But after wo / I rede vs to be merye
(base) And thanken Iuppiter / of al his grace
(base) And er we / departen from this place
(base) I rede we make / of sorwes two
(base) O parfit Ioye / lastynge euere mo
(base) And loketh now / wher moost sorwe is her Inne
(base) Ther wol I first amenden and bigynne
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) ¶ Suster quod he / this is my ful assent
(base) With al thauys / heer of my parlement
(base) That gentil Palamon / youre owene knyght
(base) That serueth yow / with wyl and herte myght
(base) And euere hath doon / syn ye first hym knewe
(base) That ye shal of youre grace vpon hym rewe
(base) And taken hym / for housbond and for lord
(base) Leen me youre hond / for this is oure acord
(base) Lat se now / of youre wommanly pitee
(base) He is / a kynges brother sone pardee
(base) And thogh he were / a poure Bachiler
(base) Syn he hath serued yow / so many a yeer
(base) And had for yow / so greet aduersitee
(base) It moste been considred / leueth me
(base) For gentil mercy / oghte to passen right
(base) ¶ Thanne seyde he thus / to Palamon the knyght
(base) I trowe / ther nedeth litel sermonyng
(base) To make yow / assente to this thyng
(base) Com neer / and taketh youre lady by the hond
(base) Bitwixe hem / was maad anon the bond
(base) That highte matrymoigne / or mariage
(base) By al the conseil / and the Baronage
(base) And thus / with alle blisse / and melodye
(base) Hath Palamon / ywedded Emelye
(base) And god / that al this world hath wroght
(base) Sende hym his loue / that hath it deere aboght
(base) For now is Palamon / in alle wele
(base) Lyuynge in blisse / in richesse / and in heele
(base) And Emelye / hym loueth so tendrely
(base) And he / hir serueth so gentilly
(base) That was ther no word hem bitwene
(base) Of Ialousie / or any oother teene
(base) Thus endeth Palamon / and Emelye
(base) And god saue / al this faire compaignye Amen
(base) ¶ Here is ended / the knyghtes tale

l.hi: Loo þus here eondiþe þe Kyntꝭes tale and nexstehere folowyng be gynnithe here þe ꝓprologe of the Milners tale

div.l: Whan þat þe knyght had þus his tale etold
In al þe companye . nas þer yong ner old
But þat þey sayde it was a noble storye
And worþy to beo drawen in memorye
And namlye þe gentelis eueryche oon
Oure hooste loughe . ⁊and swore by saynt Iohan
Þis gooþe aright . vnbokelde his þe male
Lette see whoo shalle telle nowe A noþ̉er/re tale
For sekurlye þis game is welle by gonne
Now telliþe yee sir monke yf þᵗat ye konne
Somwhat to qwite wᵗith þe knight his tale
Þe Milner for dronke . was al woron pale
So þat ouneoþes vppon his horse he satte
He wold avale . neyþ̉er/re hoode ne hatte
Nabyd noman for al his covrtasie
But pylates voyse . he gan to crye
And swore by Armes bloode ⁊and by boonys
I can a noble tale nowe for þe noons
Wᵗith wiche I wolle nowe qweyght þᵉ knyght his tale
¶ Oure hoost ꝑper/parceyvid / he was dronke of alle
And sayde Abyde Robyn my leve broþ̉er/re
Some bett̉er/re man shall telle vs First a noþ̉er/re
Abyde ⁊and lete vs wyrche . nowe thryfftelye
By goddis soule qd he þat wylle I noute
For I wolle speke . or ellꝭes nowe goo my weye
Oure hoste Aunswerd what go Adevelisweye
Þowe arte A foole þi witte is ouer come
¶ Nowe herkeniche quod þis Miller Alle ⁊and some
But First I make A protestaciou
Þat I am dronke I knowe it be my soune
And þer fore yff I mys speke or saye
Wyte it þe Ale of Souþewerke I yowe praye
For I wolle telle A legende ⁊and A lyff
Booþe of A carpenter ⁊and of his wyf
Howe þat þe Clerke sette þe wreyght cappe
¶ Þe Reve Answerd Robyn now stynte þi clappe
Lat beo þei levde dronken harlotrye
Hit is booþe synne / and eke greete folye
Tappeyrin Any man / or him deffame
And eke to bryng wyves / in suche A name
Þowe mayest enowghe of oþ̉er/re thynges seyn
Þis dronken Miller / speke ful sone A gayne
¶ And sayd leve broþer / O leve oswold
Whoo naþe noo wyf / he nys noo Cukwolde
But I sey not þer . fore þat þow art oon
Þer been ful good wyves . right many oon
Whi art þow Angery wᵗith my tale nowe
I have A wyf pardee / als wel a stowe
Yette nold I For þe oxssen in my plowhe
To take vppon me more þan I nowhe
As demen of my selff þat I wer won
I wol beleven Ay þat I am noon
¶ An husband shoulde not be in qvesetyf
Off godes previtee . ne of his wyff
So he maye Fynde godes foysou þeere ¶
Of þe remenaunt . neodeþe nought tenqvere
¶ What shoulde I sayn but þᵗat þis lewde Milner
He nil his wordes for noman forbere
But telle his chorles tale in his manere
Me For thynkeþᵉ I shal Reherse hit here
¶ And þ̉er/refore eủer/rey gentil wight I praye
Demeþe it not . For goddes love þᵗat I seye
Of euyl entente / but for I mot Reherse
Hir tales Alle . beo þey bett̉er/re or wersse
Or ellꝭes fayled sōmme of my matere
And þer fore who so liste hit not here
Tourne ouer þe lef / and chese some oþ̉er/re tale
For ye shalle fynde enowe gret ⁊and smale
Historial þyngꝭes touchyng gentillesse
Some Mora litee and som holynesse
Blameþe not me give þat yee chese A mysse
Þe Milner is a chorle ye knowe welle þis
So was þe Reve Eke / and soo þer were moo
And harlotrye þey spak booþe twoo
Avyseþe yowe / and put me owte of blame
And eke men shalle not maken eornste of game

l.hi: Loo nowe here eondiþe þe prologgꝭes of þe milneris tale / and nexte Folouyng bygynneþe þe milners tale .

div.l: Whilom þer was dwellyng at Oxenford
A Riche knoffe þat held gestes to borde
Þe wiche of his craffte he was A carpent̉er/re
Wᵗith him þer was dwellyng a poure scoler
Þat had lerned arte / but Al his fantasye
Was tourned / For to lerne Astrologye
And coude A certayne of concluciones
To deme by / Interrogaciounes
If þat men axsed him in certayne houres
Wher men shoulde have drought ellꝭes shoures
Or yf men Aske hem / what þᵗat shoulde be falle
Of euery thyng I may not Reken Alle
¶ Þis Clerke was clepid / heond Nicholas
He koude of derne love / And prevye solas
And þ̉er/reto he was slye / ⁊and Ful pryue
And liche A mayde / meke For to seo
¶ A chaumbre had he in þᵗat hostelarye
Allone wᵗith outen any companye
Ful Fetisly Dyte / withe erbes swoote
And he him selfe Als swete as is þe rote
Of likoris or elles of setwale
His Almageste / And bookes gret or smale
His Astrologye . longyng for his Arte
Heos augryme stoonys / liing ful feyre A parte
On shelves couched at hees beddes hede
His presse Ecoủer/reed wᵗith A faldyng Rede
And al above þer lay A gay savtree
On wich he made an nyghtes melodye
So swetlye off þᵗat al þe chaumb̉er/re Ronge
And Aungelous ad Virgenem was þoo his songe
And Aftir þᵗat he song þe kyngꝭes note
Ful offte Eblessid was his mury throte
And þus þis swete clerke his tyme spente
Afftir his freondes fyndyng ⁊and his Rente
¶ Þis Carpenter had E wedded newe awyffe
Whome þᵗat he loved / as his owen lyfe
Of eghteeneþe yeere sheo was I gesse of Age
Ialous he was / and kepte hir streyte in cage
For sheo was wylde and yong and he was olde
And demed him selffe / wel liche a Cukkewolde
He knew not Catoune For his witte was Rude
Þat bad men to wedde þeyre symilitude
Men shoulde wedde / Affter þeyre de gree
Wheþer hit happon / it be he or sheo
Or elleꝭes loo Afftir þeyre owne estate
For yowþe and elde ben offt at debate
But sithe þe wreyte was falle in þe snare
He moste enduren as oþer folke his care
¶ Fayre was þis younge wyf And þ̉er/re wᵗith alle
As Any wesell hir bodye gente ⁊and smal
A sceynte she wered barred Al wᵗith silke
A barmecloþe as wheyte as morowe mylke
Vppon hir leondes ful of many A goore
White was hir smokke ⁊and enbrowdered by fore
And eke be hynde on her coler A bowte
Of colblak silke . wᵗith Inne ⁊and eke wᵗith owte
Þe tapes of hir whyte fayre wolupere
Were of þe same sute of hir colere
Hir Filette brode of silke ⁊and sette fulle hie
And sekourly sheo hadde A lekerovs eye
Ful smale epulled were her browes twoo
And þoo were bente and blac as any sloo
Sheo was moore blissful / vppon for to see
Þanne is newe blossemed / Ienettes tree
And sofftre þanne þe wolle is of A weddre
And by hir gurdell þer hang a purse of leþer
Tasselde wᵗith silke ⁊and perled wᵗith latoune
In al þis worlde to seche vppe ⁊and downe
Þer is noman so weyse / þat kouþe thenche
So gaye a popelotte or ellꝭes a wēmche
Ful brighte was þe shyning of hir hewe
Þanne in þe toure / þe noble forged newe
But of hir song hit was als loude and yerne
As any swalou sittyng on A berne
Þer to sheo kouþe skyppe and maken men game
Arte Any kidde or kalfe Filowyng hir dame
Hir mowthe was swete as is bragote or meþe
Or horde of Apples liging in Any hethe
Wynsyng sheo was as is A younge colte
Long as a maste and vprite as A bolte
A brooche sheo bare vppon hir lowe collere
As broode as is þe boose of a bokelere
Hir shoon were lassed vppon hir legges hye
Sheo was a prymerolle / A pygges nyee
For Any lorde to lyen in his bed
Or yette for any yoman for to wedde
¶ Nowe sir ⁊and effte sir þus be felle þe cas
Þat on A day þis good hende Nicholas
Fel wᵗith þis younge wyf to Rage ⁊and pleye
While þᵗat hir husbond was þanne at Osneye
As Clerkes beon Ful sotyle ⁊and ful qveynte
And prevely he kaught hir by þᵉ qweynte
And saide I wisse but yf I have my wille
For deorne love of þee lemman I spille
And held hir Faste by þe haunche boones
And saide hir leman / love me wele at oones
Or I wolle deye so god my soule mot save
And sheo spronge þanne as A colt doþe in A thrave
And wᵗith hir hede sheo wreyed faste A weye
Sheo saide I wolle not kysse þee be my Feye
Whey lette beo qd ych . late be swete Nicholas
Or I wolle crye . owte harrowe and ellas
Doþe wey yowr handes for youre courtesye
Þis Nicholas ganne mercye for to crye
And spake so fayre and proferd him so faste
Þat sheo hir love hym graunte at þe laste
And swore hir ooþe by saynt Thomᵃs of kente
Þat sheo wold ben at his comaundement
Whanne þat sheo may her leysoure wele espye
Myn husband is so fulle of Ialowsye
But yf yee wayte wele / and beo prevye
I wot right wele I name but ded qd sheo
¶ For yee mote be ful derne as in þis cas
Nay þer of care yee nowte quod Nicholas
A Clerke had Full lewdelye be sette his wylle
But yf he kouþe A carpenter be gyle
And þus þer were A corded ⁊and sworne
To wayten A tyme As I sayde yow be forne
Whanne Nicholas had doon þus eủer/reye deele
And thakked her Aboute þe leondes weele
He kyssethe her swete And takeþe his saute
And playeþe þer on ⁊and makeþe melodye
¶ Þanne felle it þus þᵗat to þᵉ pariche chorche
Cristes oune werkes þanne . þer to worche
Þis goode wyf went vppon an halydaye
Hir forehede shone / als lyght as anye daye
So was it wasshe . whan þᵗat sheo leffte werke
¶ Nowe was þer of chirch a parishe clerke
Þe wiche þat was clepid þer Absolou
Croulle was his here / and as þe gold hit shon
And strouted as a Fane / large ⁊and broode
Ful streyte ⁊and even laye his Iolye swoode
His rod was rede / heos / eyen grey as goos
Wᵗith poules wyndowes corven on his shoes
In hosyn Rede . he went ful fetovselye
Ecloþed he was Ful smalle ⁊and propurlye
Al in A kirtil of light wachchette
Ful fayre ⁊and thykke beon þe poyntes sette
Aboven þat he hadde A gay surplise
Als wheyte as is þe blossom on þe Ryse
A mury chylde he was so god me save
Full well koude he . lete bloode clippe ⁊and shave
And make Achartre of lond and acquitaunce
In twentye manes coude he trippe ⁊and davnce
Affter þe scole of Oxenford yoo
And wᵗith his leggꝭes casten too ⁊and Froo
And pleyne songes vppon A smal Rubibe
And som tymes he song a loude qvenyble
He kouthe some tyme pleyne on a Geterne
In the towne þer nas no brewhouse ne taverne
Þat he ne vesited / withe his solas
Þer þat any gaye tapester was
But sooþe to seyne / he was somwhat sqweymous
Of krackyng ⁊and of speche Ful daıı̄ungerouse
¶ Þis Absolon þᵗat was þus Ioly ⁊and gaye
Gooþe wᵗith a sensoure / vppon þe sonondaye
Sensyng þe wyves / of þe parishe Faste
And many A lovely loke on hem caste
To loke on hem him thoute A mury lyffe
And namlye vppon þe carpent̉er/reis wyff
Sheo was so propre and swete ⁊and lekerows
¶ I Dare welle seyne and sheo had ben A movse
And he A catte / he wold her hent A noon
Þis Parishe Clerke þis Ialye Absolon
Hathe In his herte / suche A love longyng
Þat of noo wyff wold he take offeryng
For courtesye he saide þᵗat he wold noon
Þe moone whanne it was night Ful bryght shone
¶ And Absolon haþe his geterne etake
For paramours . he thoughte For wake
And Forþe he gooþe Iolye ⁊and Amerowse
Til þat he cam to þe Carpenters howse
A litelle to fore þe Cokke þenne hade crowe
And dressyd hym vndir a shoppe wyndowe
Wich þat was vppon þe carpent̉er/res walle
He singithe in his voyce so gentil ⁊and smal
Nowe dere ladye / yf þat þi wille be
I pray yowe þᵗat yee wolle Rewe on Me
Ful welle Acordyng in his geternyng
Þis Carpenter A wooke ⁊and herd hym syng
And spake vnto his wyf / and sayde a noon
What Alisou herestow nowght Absolou
So woweþe her þat him was woo bygon
He wakeþe Al þe nyght ⁊and al þe daye
He kembed heos lokkes / and made him wondir gay
He woweþe her by menys and brocage
And swore he wold beon hir owne page .
He syngeþe and brockeþe as doþe þe nyghtingale
He sent her pyement booþe ⁊and spiced Ale
And wafforis piping hote / owte of þe glede
And For þat he wold spede he proferd mede
For some folkes wolle be wonne . for Richesse
And some for strookes / ⁊and some for gentilesse
¶ And For to shewe his lyghtnesse ⁊and his mastrye
Some tyme he playd Erawde ou skaffold hye
But what awaylethe him as in þis cas
So loveþe she him this Fayre Niclolas
Þᵗat Absolon may blowe þe buckes horne
He had For his laboure nought but A scorne
And þus sheo makeþe Absolou hir Ape
And Al his Eornste torniþe but to A Iape
¶ For sooþe it is þis proverbe may not lye
Men seyn Al weyes þat þe nyght sley
Makeþe þe Fer love / For to be looþe
For þowe þᵗat Absolou beo woode or wroþe
By cause þat he was fer from her syght
Þis neghe Nicholas stoode aye in his lyght
¶ Nowe bere þee wele / I rede hende Nicholas
For Absolon may wepe ⁊and singe allas
And soo byfelle . þat on A saturdaye
Þis Carpent̉er/re was goone til Osnaye
And Nicholas ⁊and oure dame Alesoıı̄un
A cordid were to þis conclusiou
Þat Nicholas shoulde shapen him A wyle
Þis cely Ialous husbond / For to be gyle
And yf so beo þat þe game went A ryght
Sheo shoulde slepe in his Armes at nyght
For þat was his desire ⁊and hers Alsoo
And Right anoon . wᵗith outen wordes Moo
Þis Nicholas wolle no lenger tarye
But tille his Chaumbre doþe ful Faste carie
Booþe mete ⁊and drynke for a day or tweye
And to hir husband bad hir for to seye
Yf þat he axsed Afftre þis Nicholas
She shoulde seye sheo nist wher her was
Off al þat day she seyhe hym not wᵗith yee
Sheo trowed he was Fallen in sum maledye
For For noo crye þᵗat hir mayde kouþe calle
He nold Aunswere for ought þat myght be falle
¶ Þis passithe forþe al þe saturday
Þat Nicholas stille in his bed laye
And ete ⁊and slepe ⁊and did what him liste
Til on þe sonday þat þe sonne gane Reste
Þis cely carpenter . haþe grete marvayle
Of Nicholas or what thyng might him eyle
And sayde I am A drede . by saynt . Thomᵃs
Hit stondiþe not Al A Right wᵗith Nicholas
God shild hit / þat he deye ought sodaynelye
Þis world is Ful ferful . nowhe sekurlye
I Sawhe to day a corpus borne on to þᵉ chorche
Þat nowe on monday laste I sawhe him wirche
Goo vp quod he vn to his man A noon .
Cleepe at his doore . or knokke wᵗith sum stoone
Looke howe it is and telle me boldlye
His knave sterte him vppe þanne Ful stordelye
And at þe chaumbre dore wheyle þat he stoode
He cryed ⁊and knokked at þat he were woode
What how what do yee my mastre Nicholaye
Howe may ye slepen þus all þis longe daye
But al for nought . herde he neuer a worde
An hoole he fonde . right lowe vppon ye bord
Þer as þe catte was wont i to crepe
And at þe hole he loked ondir deope
So at þe laste he had of him a syght
Þis Nicholas seete gapyng aye vpright
As he had keked vppon þe newmoone
A doune he gooþe ⁊and told his mastre sone
In what Aray he sawhe þis ilke man
¶ Þis Carpenter to blessen him biganne
And saide ladye helpen vs nowe Frydesswyde
A man wot litille what shalle him be tyde
Þat man is Fallen wᵗith his Astronomye
Wᵗith some woodnesse or some Agonye
I thought welle howe þᵗat hit wold bee
Men shoulde not knowen of goddes pvitee
Ye blessid bee Alwey þe lewed man
Þat nought oonlye . but his byleeve can
So ferde A noþ̉er/re clerke wᵗith Astronomye
He walked in to þe feldes for to prye
Vppon þe sterris to wit what shoulde be falle
Til he was In a marble pitte efalle
He saughe nowte þer but yette be seynt Thomᵃs
Me Rueþe soore / for þis heend Nicholas
He shalle be Ratid of his studeyng
Yif þat I may by Ihesus hevene kyng
¶ Get me a staffe / whiles þou mayst vndersparre
Wheyles þat þowe Robyn heve þe dore of harre
He shal oute of his stondyng as I gesse
And to þe chaumbre dore he ganne him dresse
His knave was a strong chorle For þe Noons
And by þᵉ haspe he have þe dore at oones
Þᵗat in to þe floore . þe doore felle A noon
Þis Nicholas sette stille as anye stoone
And euer gapeþe opwardes in to þayre
Þis Carpenter wende he were in dispayre
And hente him by þe shoulderes myghtlye
And shooke hym herde / and cryde dispetouslye
What Nicholas howe what loke A downe
A wake and thinke on crystes passioune
I crowche þee froom elves ⁊and from wighes
And god in þis house beo to nyghtes
On foure halves here loo vs Abowte
And on þe thresswolde of þe dorre wᵗith outen
Ihesus cryste and eke þe saynt benedyte
Nowe blesse þis howse from everye wyked wyght
For þe . nightes warye þe wight Pater Noster
Where wentestowe where þowe petris sustre
And at þe laste þis heend Nicholas
Ganne for to seken soore / and seyde ellas
Shal al þe world be loste affte soones nowhe .
Þis Carpenter aunswered man what saystowe
What thynke on god as we doon men þᵗat swynke
Þis Nicholas Answerd Faste Feche me drynke
And afftur ward wolle I speke in previtee
Of certayne thyng þat toucheþe þe ⁊and mee
I wolle telle hit þee / noon oþir man certayne
Þis Carpent̉er/re gooþe doune / and comthe A gayne
And browte of myti Ale A quarte
And whanne þᵗat eche of hem had dronke his parte
Þis Nicholas his doore þoo faste he shete
¶ And doune by hym þe Carpent̉er/re he sette
And sayde Iohan myn hoste . so leve and dere
Þou shalt vppon þi trowþe ensure me here
Þat to no wyght þowe shalt þis counsaile wire
For it is cristes counceyle þat I seye
And yf þow telle it man þow art For lore
For þis vengeaunce þowe shalt have þer Fore
Þat yf þow be wreye me þowe shalte Rynne woode
Nay crist for bede hit for his hoolye bloode
Quod þoo þis cely man I name noo labbe
And þauhe I sey hit I nam nat leffe to gabbe
Seye what þowe wolte I shalle it never telle
To wyf ne chylde by him þᵗat harowed helle
¶ Nowe Iohan quod Nicholas I wolle not lyee
I have efounden in myn Astrologye
As I have looked in þe moone so bryght
Þat nowe on monday nexst at quarter night
Shalle falle a Rayne / and þᵗat soo wyld ⁊and woode
Þat halfe so greete nas neuer Noyes floode
Þis world he sayde in lasse þanne in an oure
Shal Al be dreynt so hydous is þe shoure
Þus shall man kynde drenche and leesse his lyf
Þis Carpenter Answerd / ellas my wyff
And shal sheo drenche ellas myn Alesoune
For fere of þis he felle Almoste A doune
And saide is þer no Remedye in þis cas
Yisse yisse ful good quod þoo heende Nicholas
Yf þᵗat þowe wolt worche After loore ⁊and Rede
Þou maiste not worche Afftir þin oune hede
¶ For þus saithe Salamou so wyse ⁊and trewe
Wirche al by counsayle ⁊and þowe shalt not Rewe
And yf þowe wylt nowe wirche by trew counsayle
I vndretake hit wᵗith outen maste or sayle
Yette shalle I save hir boþe þee ⁊and mee
Haste þowe not herde / howe þᵗat saved was Noe
Whanne þᵗat oure lorde had warned him byforne
Þat al þe worlde wt þat Floode shoulde beo for lorne
¶ Yisse quod þis Carpenter ful youre A goo
Haste towe not harde quod Nicholas Alsoo
Þe sorowe of Noe withe his Feleshippe
Er þat he myght gete his wyff to shippe
Him had wele lever . I dare vnder take
At þilke tyme þanne al heos oxen blake
Þat sheo hadde had a shippe þer hir selfe A loone
¶ And þer fore wotyste þowe what is best to doone
Þis Axsithe haste . and of an hastye thyng
Men may not preche and maken tareyng
Anoon goo gete vs faste in to þis Inne
A knedyng trowhe or ellꝭes A kemelyne
For eche of vs but looke þᵗat þey beo large
In wiche men may wel Rowen as In a barge
And have þeyre vetayles wᵗith hem suffisaunt
But for oon daye . fye on þe Remnaunt
Þe wat̉er/re shalle A slake . and goon A weye
A boute prime on þe nexst daye
But Robyn may nat wit of þis þi knave
Ne nought þⁱ mayde Gylle I may not save
Axsse þen not whey / For þowhe þowe axsse it me
I wolle not telle þe goddis previtee
Suffiseþe þe but gyff / þⁱ wyttes be madde
To have als grete a gras as þat Noe had
Þy wyf I shalle wel saven have þowe no dovte
Goo nowe þy wey ⁊and spede þee here Aboute
¶ But whanne þowe hast for hir ⁊and þee ⁊and me
E goton vs þeos knedyng tubbes three
Þan shalt þowe hang hem in þe Rooffe an hye
Þat noman of oure purviaunse espie
And whanne þowe haste doone þus / as I have saide
And haste oure wetayle in hem welle I layde
And eke an axsse to smyte þe corde a twoo
Whanne þᵗat þe wat̉er/re comythe þᵗat we may goo
And breke an hoole on hye vppe on þe gable
Vn to þe gardyn wardes towardes þe stable
Þat we may Freely passen forþe oure waye
Whanne þᵗat þe grete shoure is paste A weye
Þanne shalt þowe swymme as mury I vndirtake
As dooþe þᵉ wheyte ducke / Afftir þe drake
Þanne wolle I Clepe howe Alison howe Iohan
Beo mury for þe floode wol passe A noon
And þowe wolt sayn hayle maiste Nicholay
Goode morowe I see þe weele / For it is daye
And þanne we shulle beo lordes al owre lyve
Of alþis world as Noye was ⁊and his wyff
¶ But þat of on thyng I warne þe ful Right
Beo wel A wysid on þᵗat yche nyght
Þat we beon enterid wᵗith sune þe shippes borde
Þat noon of vs ne speke nought a worde
Ne clepe ne creye but bydden þeyre prayere
For it is goddes owne hestes so deere
Þy wyff ⁊and þowe moste honge Fer A twynne
For þat be twyxste yowe þer beo noo synne
Namore In lokyng / þanne þer shalle in dede
Þis ordenaunce is sayde goo god þe spede
¶ To morowe at night / whanne men ben al on slepe
In to oure knedyng tubbes wol we crepe
And sitte þer stille Abydyng þer godes grace
Go þowe þy wey I have noo lenger space
To make of þis no lenger sermonyng
¶ Men sayn sende þe wyse ⁊and say noo thyng
Þowe art so wyse it neodeþe not þe teche
Goo save oure lyves and þᵗat I þe beseche
Þis cely Carpent̉er/re gooþe forþe his wey
Ful offte he sayde ellas ⁊and wellawaye
And to his wyff he told his pvitee
¶And sheo was ware and knew hit bett̉er/re þan he
What al þis qweynte caste / was for to meene
Sheo ferd for fere as sheo wold dede beon
And sayde alas man goo þy wey A Noon
Helpe vs to scape or we be dede echoone
I am þy trewe werray wedded wyff
Goo nowe dere spouse / and helpe to sauve oure lyff
Loo wiche thyng is nowe gret Affeccioune
Men may deye of suche ymagenacioune
Soo deepe loo impressioun may be take
Þis cely Carpent̉er/re bygynnythe to qwake
Him semithe verraylye / þᵗat he may see
Noyes flood cometh rennyng as þᵉ se
To drenchyn Alesoune his oune dere
He wepithe waylethe ⁊and makeþe sory chere
He sykeþe soore . wᵗith many an hevy thovte
He gooþe and getiþe him A knedyng trowhe
And eke A tubbe ⁊and A large kymlyne
Ful prevelye he sent hem to his Inne
And hang hem vppe in þe Rooff wᵗith prevyte
Hes owne handes he made ladderis þree
To clymben by þe ronges and by þe stalkes
Vn to þe tvbbes honging by þe balkes
And hem haþe vetayled boþe trowhe ⁊and tobbe
Wᵗith brede ⁊and chese . and good ale in A Iubbe
Sufficeaunt e noughe as For A daye
But or he had made al þis Arraye
He sent his knave ⁊and his wenche Alsoo
Vppon his erond to lond For til goo
¶ And on þe monday whanne it drowe to nyght
He shitte his dorre / withe outen candel light
And dressyd al thyng as it shoulde be
And shortly clomben þey vppe alle three
Þey setten stille wele A fourlong weye
Nowe Pater Noster clome / saide / Nicholaye
And clome quod Iohan / and clome qd Alysoune
Þis Carpenter saide his devocioune
And stille he sittiþe and biddiþe his prayere
A wayting on þe Rayne gyf he might hit here
Þe dede slepe for wereye bysines
Fel on þis carpent̉er/re right I Gesse
Abowte couerfen tyme / or lytel moore
For travaylling of his gooste he groneþe sore
And gynneþe to Rowte for his hede mislaye
Downe of þe laddre stalkeþe Nicholaye
And Alisoune ful soffte A downe hir spedde
Wᵗith outen wordes moo þey goon to bedde
Þer as þe Carpent̉er/re was wont to lye
Þer nas but Revelle ⁊and gret melodye
And þus lyen Alison / and Nicholas
In besynesse in mirthe and in solase
Til þat þe belle of lavdes gane to Rynge
And Freres in þeyre chaunselle ganne to syng
Þis parishe clerke . þis Amerowse Absolon
Þat is For love allweye so woo by goone
Vppon þe monday / he was at Osnaye
Wᵗith coumpanye him to disporte and playe
And Asked of A Chanoune cloysterere
Ful prevelye / affter Iohan Carpentere
And he drowhe him A parte owte of þe chyrche
And sayde I saughe him noute þis day here wirche
¶ Sythe saturday I leve þᵗat he be wente
For tymbre þer oure / Abbot haþe him sente
For he is wonte . For tymbre for to goo
And dwellyng atte þe graunge a day or twoo
Or ellꝭes he is at his house certayne
Wher þᵗat he beo I can not sooþelye seyne
¶ Þis Absolon was ful Iolye þanne ⁊and lyght
And thought now is tyme to wake Al nyght
For sikurlye I sawe him not storynge
A boute his dore sythe day by ganne to spryng
So mote I thryve I shalle at cokkes crowe
Ful prevely knocken at his wyndowe
Þat stante so lowe vppon hir boures walle
To Alisoune nowe wolle I tellen al
My love longing . at hardest I shalle not misse
But at þe leeste weye I shalle hir kisse
Some maner counforte shal I have ꝑper/par Faye
My mouþe haþe eched / Al þis long daye
Whan þᵗat þᵉ Firste Cocke haþe crowe A noone
Vpryste þis Iolye lover Absolon
And him arrayethe gaye at poynt devise
But Firste he cheveþe greynes and licouryse
To smellen soote or he had kempte his here
Vndir his tonge a trew love grasse he bere
For þer bye he wende for to beo graciouse
¶ He Romeþe to þe Carpenters howse
And stille he stoode vnder þe shoppe wyndowe
Vn to his breste it Raught it was so lowe
And soffte he knokkeþe . wᵗith a semy sowne
What do ye nowhe honycombe . myn Alesoun
My fayre brid my swette synamome loo
A wake lemon myn . and speke me too
Wel lytelle thynke yee vppon my wo
Þat for yoᵘur love I swelt nowe as I goo
No wondre is þoughe I mowrne and swete
Right as þe lambe afftir þe modres teete
I wysse leman I have suche love longyng
Þᵗat liche A turtille trewe is my mornyng
I may nowte ete namoore þan may a mayde
Go frome þe wyndowe / Iacke fole sheo sayde
I love bette oþ̉er/re and ellꝭes I were to blame
Welle more þan þe by Ihesu ⁊and his dame
Go forþe thy weye or ellꝭes I wille caste Astoone
Go lette me slepe A twenty devilweye
Ellas quod Absolon and wellaweye
Þat trewloue was evyr so evil bysette
Þanne isse me swete sithe I may be no bette
For Ihesus love / and for þe love of me
Wiltowe þan goo . þy wey quod sheo
Yee serteyse lemman quod þis Absolou
Þanne make Redye quod sheo I come A noon
¶ Þis Absolon doune sette him on his kenes
I am a lord ꝙquodd he at al degres
Derke was þe nyght as pyche or any cole
And at þe wyndow sheo put owte hir hole
Þis Absolon him selfe ne better ne wersse
But wᵗith his mowthe he kyste hir naked ers
Ful sauourely / or he were ware of þis
A backe he sterte ⁊and þowte hit was amisse
For wel he wyste a womman had noo berd
He felte a thyng Al Rowhe and long herid
And saide fye ellas what have I doo
Tehe quod sheo and clapte þe wyndowe too
And Absolon gooþe forþe a sory pas
A berde A berde thought heonde Nicholas
By goddes Corpus þis gooþe fayre ⁊and welle
Þis Cely Absolon hard eueryche deele
And on his lippe he ganne angre for to byte
And to him selffe he sayde I shalle qveyte
Whoo Rubbithe nowe whoo Frotiþe nowe his lippis
Wᵗith douste wᵗith strawe wᵗith clooþes and wᵗith chyppes
But Absolon þᵗat seythe ful offete ellas
My soule y be take to þe Satanasse
But I had lever þan Alle þis towne qd he
Of þis despite A wroken for to beo
Ellas qd he ellas I nade ebleynte
His hoote love is colde / and al eqveynte
For frome þe tyme þᵗat he had kyste her ers
Of peramours / he sette nought at A cresse
For he was heled of his maladye
Ful often paramours he can þer deffye
And wepte as dooþe a chylde þᵗat is ebeete
¶ A soffte paas he wente ouer þe strete
Vn to a smythe men callen daun Gervyse
Þᵗat in his Forge smyþed plough herneyse
He sharpithe shares ⁊and covlters . besylye
Þis Absolon knokkeþe al eselye
And sayde vn to Gerveyse and þᵗat a noon
What who art towe it am I Absolou
What Absolon what criest swete oreete
Whi Rise yee so raþe . O benedicitee
What eyliþe yowe some gaye gyrle god it woote
Haþe browte yowe þus in þe veritote
Be saynt Note ye woote welle what I mene
This Absolou ne wrought not abene
Of all his play no worde agein him gaf
He had more towe . on his distaf .
Than absolon answerd and seid frend so dere
The hote cultre in þe Chymney here
As lene hit me . I haue þ̉er/rewith to don
And I shal bring hit the agein full sone
Gerveis answerd / a certes ⁊and hit were gold
Or in a poke nobles all vntold
¶ Thou shuldest it haue as I am true Smyth
Ey cristis fote / what woll ye do therwith
Therof qd Absolou / be as be may
I shal wele telle þe to morow day
And caught the cultre by the hote stele
Ful softly oute Atte the dore gan he stele
And wente vnto þe Carpenters Walle
He coughed first and knokked þ̉er/rewith all
Vpon þe wyndow right as he did er
This Alisoun Answerd . hey who is ther
That knokkith so . I warant it is a theof .
See nay quod he . god wote my swete lyf .
I am thyne Absolou . thi dere derlyng
Of gold quod he . I haue the brought A Ryng
My moder gaf hit me . so god me save .
Full fyne hit is . and þ̉er/reto wele I grave
This woll I geve you ⁊and ye woll me kysse
This Nicholas was risen vp to pisse
And thought he wold amenden all all þᵗat iape
That he shuld kysse his taille er þᵗat he scape
And vp þe wyndow he did he hastely
And leid his taill ende oute ful pryvily
Over the buttok vnto þe haunche bon
Therwith speke / this clerk this Absolou
Speke þᵘ faire swete bird . I note wheþ̉er/re þᵘ Art
This Nicholas let flie a cherlissh fart
As grete as hit had ben a thondir dynte
And wᵗith the stroke . he was almoste blynt
And Absolou was redy wᵗith Iren hote
And Nicholas in þe Ars he smote .
Of goth the skyn an hondfull brode abowte
The hote cultre brent so þ̉er/ree his foule toute
That for the smert ; he wēmt for to dye .
As he were wode . he gan for to crie .
How . water . water . help for goddis hert
This Carpent̉er/re oute of his slombre stert
And herd oon crie . water as he were wood
And thought here comyth now ; nowels flode
And sette him vp . wᵗithouten wordes mo .
And with an Axe . he smote the cordis atwo
And doune goth all he founde neither to selle
Brede ner Ale / tyll he come to þe celle
Vpon þe flore and þ̉er/ree a swou he laye
Vpstert then Alisou and Nicholaie .
And criden oute and harowe in þe strete
The neighbours þ̉er/ree . bothe the smale and grete
In ran for to gawren vpon þis man
That astonyed lay both pale and wan
For with that fall to broste is his Arme .
But stonden he moste vnto his owne harme
For whan he spake he was anon borne doune
Wᵗith hende Nicholas and feire Alisou .
Thei told eủer/rey man ; þat he was wode
He was so agast . of þat nowels flode
Thorugh fantasie ; that of his vanyte .
He had so bought kneding tubbes thre .
And had ehongid hem hy in þe Roof
And how he preid him for goddis love
To sitten in the Roof par companye .
The folkes gan laughen At his fantasye .
And to the Roof þei keyken ⁊and þei gape
And turned all his harme vnto iape
For what so euer this Carpenter answerd
Hit was for nought / noman his resou herd
With othes grete he was so borne adoun
That he was holden wode thurgh the toun
For eủer/rey Clerk anon thei held wᵗith othir
Thei seid the man is wode hit is non oþ̉er/re
And eủer/rey man gan laughen at þis stryf .
Thus ʆser/sirued was the Carpenters wif
For all his keping / and his Ielousie
And Absolou had kist her nethir eye
And Nicholas is brent fore in to þe toute
This tale is don . god saue all this rowte
(base) ¶ The Prologe / of the Reues tale
(base) Whan folk hadde laughen / at this nyce cas
(base) Of Absolon / and hende Nicholas
(base) Diuerse folk / diuersely they seyde
(base) But for the moore part they lowe and pleyde
(base) Ne at his tale / I seigh no man hym greue
(base) But it were oonly / Osewold the Reue
(base) By cause he was / of Carpenters craft
(base) A litel Ire / is in his herte ylaft
(base) He gan to grucche / and blamed it alite
(base) So the ik quod he / ful wel koude I thee quyte
(base) With bleryng of a proud Millerys Iye
(base) If that me liste / speke of ribaudye
(base) But ik am oold / me list no pleye for age

div.l: (base) Gras tyme is doon / my fodder is now forage
(base) This white top / writeth myne olde yerys
(base) Myn herte / is also mowled / as myne herys
(base) But if ik fare / as dooth an Openers
(base) That ilke fruyt is euer lenger the wers
(base) Til it be roten / in Mollok or in stree
(base) We olde men / I drede so fare we
(base) Til we be roten / kan we noght be rype
(base) We hoppe alwey / whil that the world wol pipe
(base) For in oure wil / ther stiketh euere a nayl
(base) To haue an hoor heer / and a grene tayl
(base) As hath a leek / for thogh oure myght be goon
(base) Oure wil desireth folie / euere in oon
(base) For whan we may noght doon / than wol we speke
(base) Yet in oure asshen olde / is fyr yreke
(base) Foure gleedes haue we / whiche I shal deuyse
(base) Auauntyng lyyng Anger Coueitise
(base) Thise foure sparkles / longen vnto eelde
(base) Oure lymes / mowe wel been vnweelde
(base) But wil ne shal noght faillen / that is sooth
(base) And yet I haue alwey / a coltes tooth
(base) As many a yeer / as it is passed henne
(base) Syn that my tappe of lyf / bigan to renne
(base) For sikerlik whan ik was bore anon
(base) Deeth drogh the tappe of lyf / and leet it goon
(base) And euere sith / hath so the tappe yronne
(base) Til that almoost / al empty is the tonne
(base) The streem of lyf / now droppeth on the chymbe
(base) The sely tonge / may wel rynge and chymbe
(base) Of wrecchednesse / that passed is ful yoore
(base) With olde folk / saue dotage is namoore
(base) ¶ Whan that oure hoost hadde herd this sermonyng
(base) He gan to speke / as lordly as a kyng
(base) He seyde / what amounteth al this wit
(base) What shal we speke alday / of holy writ
(base) The deuel made / a Reue for to preche
(base) Or of a Soutere / a Shipman / or a leche
(base) Sey forth thy tale / and tarie noght the tyme
(base) Lo Depeford / and it is half wey pryme
(base) Lo Grenewych / ther many a sherewe is Inne
(base) It were al tyme / thy tale to bigynne
(base) ¶ Now sires / quod this Osewold the Reue
(base) I pray yow alle / that ye noght yow greue
(base) Thogh I answere / and som del sette his howue
(base) For leueful is / with force / force of showue
(base) This dronken Millere / hath ytoold vs heer
(base) How that / bigiled was a Carpenter
(base) Parauenture in scorn / for I am oon
(base) And by youre leue / I shal hym quyte anon
(base) Right / in his cherles termes / wol I speke
(base) I pray to god / his nekke mote to breke
(base) He kan wel / in myn eye / seen a stalke
(base) But in his owene / he kan noght seen a balke
(base) ¶ Heere bigynneth / the Reues tale ~
(base) AT Trompyngtoun nat fer fro Cantebrygge
(base) Ther gooth a brook and ouer that a brygge
(base) Vp on the which brook ther stant a Melle
(base) And this is verray sooth that I yow telle
(base) A Miller was ther dwellyng many a day
(base) As any pecok he was proud and gay
(base) pipen he koude and fisshe and nettes beete
(base) And torne coppes and wel wrastle and sheete
(base) And by his belt he baar a long panade
(base) And of a swerd ful trenchaunt was the blade
(base) A ioly popper baar he in his pouche
(base) Ther was no man for peril dorste hym touche
(base) A sheffeld thwitel baar he in his hose
(base) Round was his face and camuse was his nose
(base) As piled as an Ape was his skulle
(base) He was a Market beter at the fulle
(base) Ther dorste no wight hand vp on hym legge
(base) That he ne swoor he sholde anon abegge
(base) A theef he was for sothe of corn and mele
(base) And that a sleigh and vsant for to stele
(base) His name was hoten deynous Symkyn
(base) A wif he hadde comen of noble kyn
(base) The person of the toun hir fader was
(base) With hir he yaf ful many a panne a bras
(base) For that Symkyn sholde in his blood allye
(base) She was yfostred in a Nonnerye
(base) For Symkyn wolde no wyf as he sayde
(base) But she were wel ynorissed and a mayde
(base) To sauen his estaat of yemanrye
(base) And she was proud and peert as is a pye
(base) A ful fair sighte was it vp on hem two
(base) On halidayes biforn hir wolde he go
(base) With his tipet wounden aboute his heed
(base) And she cam after in a gyte of reed
(base) And Symkyn hadde hosen of the same
(base) Ther dorste no wight clepen hire but dame
(base) Was noon so hardy that wente by the weye
(base) That with hire dorste rage or ones pleye
(base) But if he wolde be slayn of Symkyn
(base) With panade or with knyf or boydekyn
(base) For Ialous folk been perilouse eueremo
(base) Algate they wolde hir wyues wenden so
(base) And eek for she was som del smoterlich
(base) She was as digne as water in a dich
(base) And ful of hoker and of bismare
(base) Hir thoghte that a lady sholde hir spare
(base) What for hir kynrede and hir nortelrye
(base) That she hadde lerned in the Nonnerye
(base) A doghter hadde they bitwix hem two
(base) Of twenty yeer with outen any mo
(base) Sauyng a child that was of hal yeer age

div.l: (base) In Cradel it lay and was a propre page
(base) This wenche thikke and wel ygrowen was

(base) His purpos was for to bistowe hir hye

(base) How that the hoper wagges til and fra

(base) He looketh vp and doun til he hath founde
(base) The clerkes hors ther as it stood ybounde

div.l: (base) Oure hors is lost. Alayn for goddes banes
(base) Step on thy feet com of man al atanes
(base) Allas oure wardeyn has his palfrey lorn
(base) This Alayn al forgat bothe mele and corn

(base) What whilk wey is he gane he gan to crye
(base) The wyf cam lepyng Inward with a ren

(base) Allas quod Iohn Aleyn for Cristes peyne

(base) I is ful wight god waat as is a ra

(base) Ilhail by god Alayn thow is a fonne

(base) Thise sely clerkes rennen vp and doun

(base) They koude noght thogh they dide al hir myght

(base) Wery and weet as beest is in the reyn
(base) Comth sely Iohn and with hym comth Aleyn
(base) Allas quod Iohn the day that I was born
(base) Now ar we dryuen til hethyng and til scorn
(base) Oure corn is stole men wil vs foolis calle
(base) Bothe the wardeyn and oure felawes alle
(base) And namely the Millere weilawey
(base) Thus pleyneth Iohn as he gooth by the wey
(base) Toward the Mille and Bayard in his hond

(base) But for the loue of god they hym bisoght

(base) The Millere seide agayn if ther be eny
(base) Swich as it is yet shal ye haue youre part
(base) Myn hous is streyt but ye han lerned art
(base) Ye kan by argumentz make a place
(base) A myle brood of twenty foot of space
(base) Lat se now if this place may suffise

(base) Now Symond seyde this Iohn by Seint Cutberd
(base) Ay is thou myrie and that is faire answerd
(base) I haue herd seye men sal tak of twa thynges
(base) Swilk as he fyndes or tak swilk as he brynges
(base) But specialy I pray thee hoost deere
(base) Get vs som mete and drynke and make vs cheere
(base) And we wol payen trewely at the fulle
(base) With empty hand men may none haukes tulle
(base) Lo heere oure siluer redy for to spende

(base) Noght from his owene bed but ten foot or twelue
(base) His doghter hadde a bed al by hir selue
(base) Right in the same chambre by and by
(base) It myghte be no bet and cause why
(base) Ther was no rowmer herberwe in the place
(base) They soupen and they speken hem to solace

(base) Wel hath this Millere vernysshed his heed

(base) He yexeth and he speketh thurgh the nose

(base) The Cradel at hir beddes feet is set

(base) And whan that dronken al was in the Crowke
(base) To bedde wente the doghter right anon
(base) To bedde gooth Aleyn and also Iohn
(base) Ther nas namoore hem neded no dwale
(base) This Millere hath so wisly bibbed ale

(base) Ne of his tayl bihynde he took no keep
(base) His wyf bar hym a burdon a ful strong
(base) Men myghten hir routyng heren a furlong

(base) Aleyn the clerc that herde this melodye

(base) Lo swilk a couplyng is ymel hem alle
(base) A wilde fyr on thair bodyes falle

(base) This lang nyght ther tydes me na reste

div.l: (base) If that I may yon wenche wol I swyue
(base) Som esement has lawe shapen vs
(base) For Iohn ther is a lawe that says thus
(base) That gif a man in a point be agreued
(base) That in another he sal be releued
(base) Oure corn is stoln soothly it is na nay
(base) And we han had an ille fit to day
(base) And syn I sal haue naan amendement
(base) Agayn my los I wil haue esement
(base) By goddes saule it sal naan other be
(base) This Iohn answerde Aleyn auyse thee
(base) The Millere is a perilous man he sayde
(base) And if that he out of his sleep abrayde
(base) He myghte doon vs bathe a vileynye

(base) Now pley Aleyn for I wol speke of Iohn
(base) This Iohn lith stille a furlang wey or two

(base) He has the Milleris doghter in his arm
(base) He auntred hym and has his nedes sped
(base) And I lye as a draf sak in my bed
(base) And whan this iape is told another day
(base) I sal ben halden a daf a Cokenay
(base) I wil arise and auntre it by my fayth
(base) Vnhardy is vnsely thus men sayth
(base) And vp he roos and softely he wente

(base) And nyste wher she was for it was derk

(base) And seyde fare wel Malyn swete wight
(base) The day is come I may no lenger byde

(base) I is thyn awen clerk so haue I sel
(base) Now deere lemman quod she go farewel

(base) Whan that thow wendest homward by the Melle
(base) Right at the entree of the dore bihynde

div.l: (base) And with the fal out of hir sleep she brayde
(base) Help holy cros of Bromholm she sayde
(base) In manus tuas lord to thee I calle
(base) Awake Symond the feend is on me falle
(base) Myn herte is broken help I nam but ded
(base) Ther lyth oon vp on my wombe and vp myn hed
(base) Help Symkyn for the false clerkes fighte

(base) And therfore this prouerbe is seyd ful sooth
(base) Hym thar nat wene wel that yuele dooth
(base) A gilour shal hym self bigiled be

(base) Here endeth the Reues tale
ÞE cooke of london whiles þe Reve spake

A tale of me þᵗat am a poure man

And þer fore Henry Rayly by þy feythe
Þaughe þᵗat my tale beo of an hostelier
Ne beo not wroþe and tolde as ye may here
A Prentis whilome dwellid in oure Citee

To hoppe ⁊and singe ⁊and to make disporte

Fpr om þe toune nas þer noo prentyse

Vppon A Daye whanne he his papre sowght

div.l: But Take no kepe of suche vanite

A wyf is goddis yefte verely
Al oþe man yeftꝭes herdely
As londes Rentꝭes pasturis ⁊and Comovne ¶/
Or oþe yeftis meuable of Fortune

But drede not yf I pleynly spekyng shalle /
A wyf wolle laste ⁊and in thin hovse endure
Wel leng than the lyst ꝑper/paraventure

He þat hathe no wyf is but shent
He livithe helples ⁊and is al disolate

And herkyn whi y sey not this for nowte /
The womman is for mannis helpe ewroute /
The hie god when he had Adam maked
And sawe hīm alone bely naked
God of his grete goodnes seide then
Lete vs now make an helper to this man

Her may yee see ⁊and her may ye preve

So buxum ⁊and so vertuous is she

A wyf a Seynte mary benedicite
How myght aman have ony aversitee

The blisse that is be twyxe hēm tweye

div.l: And also they be so trewe and eke so wyse

div.l: For yf so wer þᵗat I had so myschaunce

div.l: I sey it is acursid man qd he

And ben assentid sodenly þat he shuld

And when he was from hir cōmdiscendit

Þat Impossible it wer to Replie

And thankid god that he myght have hir al

For sithe that verrey hevin is boute so der
Wᵗith tribulaciou ⁊and gret penaunce /
How shulde I leve in suche plesance
As al weddid men do wᵗith þe wyfes
Come to the blis þer Crist etern on live is

Assoylithe me this questiou y yowe pray
Iustinus whiche that hathe t his foly

ꝐPer/Parauenture she may be yoᵘur purgatory

(base) ¶ Hom goth the cherl that highte Claudius
(base) This false Iuge that highte Apius

div.l: (base) Agayns the lawe agayn al equitee
(base) Holdeth expres agayn the wyl of me
(base) My seruant which that is my thral by right
(base) Which fro myn hous was stole vpon a nyght
(base) Whil that she was ful yong this wol I preue
(base) By witnesse lord so that it nat yow greue
(base) She nys his doghter nat what so he seye
(base) Wher to yow my lord the Iuge I preye
(base) Yeld me my thral if that it be youre wille
(base) Lo this was al the sentence of his bille
(base) ¶ Virginius gan vpon the cherl biholde
(base) But hastily er he his tale tolde
(base) And wolde haue proued it as sholde a knyght
(base) And eek by witnessynge of many a wight
(base) That it was fals that seyde his Aduersarie
(base) This cursed Iuge wolde no thyng tarie
(base) Ne here a word moore of Virginius
(base) But yaf his Iuggement and seyde thus
(base) ¶ I deme anon this cherl his seruant haue
(base) Thou shalt no lenger in thyn hous hir saue
(base) Go bryng hir forth and put hire in oure warde
(base) The cherl shal han his thral this I awarde
(base) ¶ And whan this worthy knyght Virginius
(base) Thurgh sentence of this Iustice Apius
(base) Moste by force his deere doghter yeuen
(base) Vnto the Iuge in lecherie to lyuen
(base) He goth hym hom and sette hym in his halle
(base) And leet anoon his deere doghter calle
(base) And with a face deed as asshen colde
(base) Vpon hir humble face he gan biholde
(base) With fadres pitee stikyng thurgh his herte
(base) Al wolde he from his purpos nat conuerte
(base) ¶ Doghter quod he Virginia by thy name
(base) Ther been two weyes outher deeth or shame
(base) That thow most suffre allas that I was bore
(base) For neuere thow deseruedest wherfore
(base) To dyen with a swerd or with a knyf
(base) O deere doghter endere of my lyf
(base) Which I haue fostred vp with swich plesance
(base) That thow were neuere out of my remembrance
(base) O doghter which that art my laste wo
(base) And in my lyf my laste ioye also
(base) O gemme of chastitee in pacience
(base) Tak thow thy deeth for this is my sentence
(base) For loue and nat for hate thow most be deed
(base) My pitous hand moot smyten of thyn heed
(base) Allas that euere Apius thee say
(base) Thus hath he falsly Iugged thee to day
(base) Is there no grace is there no remedie cat
(base) And tolde hire al the cas as ye bifore
(base) Han herd nat nedeth for to telle it moore
(base) ¶ O mercy deere fader quod this mayde
(base) And with that word she bothe hir armes layde
(base) Aboute his nekke as she was wont to do
(base) The teeris borste out of hir eyen two
(base) And seyde goode fader shal I dye
(base) Is ther no grace is ther no remedye
(base) ¶ No certes deere doghter myn quod he
(base) ¶ Thanne yif me leyser fader myn quod she
(base) My deeth for to compleyne a litel space
(base) For pardee Iepte yaf his doghter grace
(base) For to compleyne er he hir slowe allas
(base) And god it woot no thyng was hir trespas
(base) But for she ran hir fader for to se
(base) To wel come hym with greet solempnytee
(base) And with that word she fil aswowne anon
(base) And after whan hir swownyng is agon
(base) She riseth vp and to hir fader sayde
(base) Blessed be god that I shal dye a mayde
(base) Yif me my deeth er that I haue a shame
(base) Dooth with youre child youre wyl a goddes name
(base) And with that word she preyed hym ful ofte
(base) That with his swerd he wolde smyte softe
(base) And with that word aswowne doun she fil
(base) ¶ Hir fader with ful sorweful herte and wil
(base) Hir heed of smoot and by the top it hente
(base) And to the Iuge he gan it to presente
(base) As he sat yet in doom in Consistorie
(base) ¶ And whan the Iuge it saw as seith the storie
(base) He bad to take hym and anhange hym faste
(base) But right anon a thousand peple In thraste
(base) To saue the knyght for routhe and for pitee
(base) For knowen was the false Iniquitee
(base) ¶ The peple anon hadde suspect in this thyng
(base) By manere of the cherles chalangyng
(base) That it was by the assent of Apius
(base) They wisten wel that he was lecherus
(base) For which vnto this Apius they gon
(base) And caste hym in a prison right anon
(base) Ther as he slow hymself and Claudius

(base) Was demed for to hange vpon a tree
(base) But that Virginius of his pitee
(base) So preyde for hym that he was exiled
(base) And ellis certes he hadde been bigyled
(base) The remenant were anhanged moore and lesse
(base) That were consentant of this cursednesse
(base) ¶ Heere may men seen how synne hath his merite
(base) Beth war for no man woot whom god wol smyte
(base) In no degree ne in which manere wise
(base) The worm of conscience may agrise
(base) Of wikked lyf thogh it so pryuee be
(base) That no man woot ther of but god and he
(base) For be he lewed man or ellis lered
(base) He noot how soone that he shal been afered
(base) Therfore I rede yow this conseil take
(base) Forsaketh synne er synne yow forsake
(base) ¶ Here endeth the Phisiciens tale
(base) ¶The myry talkyng of the hoost to the Phisicien and the Pardoner
(base) Et Incipit Prologus de la Pardoner cum fabula sua .
(base) Oure hoost gan to swere / as he were wood
(base) Harrow quod he / by nayles and by blood
(base) This was a fals cherl / and a fals Iustise
(base) As shameful deeth / as herte may deuyse
(base) Come to thise Iuges / and hir Aduocatz
