div.l: (base) Algate this sely mayde / is slayn allas
(base) Þe deuyl I bekenne him al at ones
(base) Allas / to deere boghte she beautee
(base) Wherfore I seye alday / that men may se
(base) That yiftes of Fortune / and of nature
(base) Been cause of deeth / to many a creature
(base) Her beaute was her deth I dar wel sayn
(base) Allas so pitously as she was slayn
(base) Of bothe yiftes / that I speke of now
(base) But her of wil I not ꝓprocede as now
(base) Hir beaute was hir deþ I dar wel sayn
(base) Men han ful ofte / moore for harm than prow
(base) Hir beaute was hir deth I dar wel sayn
(base) Allas so pitously as she was slayn
(base) ¶ But trewely / myn owene maister deere
(base) This is a pitous tale / for to heere
(base) But nathelees passe ouer is no fors
(base) I pray to god / so saue thy gentil cors
(base) And eek thyne vrynals / and thy Iurdones
(base) Thyn Ypocras / and eek thy galyones
(base) And euery boyste / ful of thy letuarie
(base) God blesse hem / and oure lady Seinte Marie
(base) So mote I then / thow art a propre man
(base) And lyk a prelat / by Seint Ronyan
(base) Seyde I nat wel / I kan nat speke in terme
(base) But wel I woot thow doost myn herte to erme
(base) That I almoost haue caught a Cardynacle
(base) By corpus bones / but if I haue triacle
(base) Or ellis a draghte / of moyste and corny ale
(base) Or but I heere anon / a murye tale
(base) Myn herte is lost for pitee of this mayde
(base) ¶ Thow beel amy / thow Pardoner he sayde
(base) Tel vs som myrthe / or Iapes right anon
(base) ¶ It shal be doon quod he / by Seint Ronyon
(base) But first quod he / heere at this ale stake
(base) I wol bothe drynke / and eten of a Cake
(base) ¶ And right anon / thise gentils gonne to crye
(base) Nay lat hym telle vs / of no ribawdye
(base) Tel vs som moral thyng / that we may leere
(base) Som wit / and thanne wol we gladly heere
(base) ¶ Gladly quod he and seide as ye shal here
(base) But in the cuppe wol I me bithinke
(base) ¶ I graunte ywis quod he / but I moot thynke
(base) Vpon som honeste thyng whil that I drynke
(base) Here endeth the reheytyng of our hoost
(base) Radix omnium malorum est cupiditas
¶ Here begynnithe þe ꝐPer/Pardoners tale .
LOrdinges quod he in churchis when I prech
I peyne me to have an haunten spech
Herang it out as rounde as goithe a bell
For I Can alle by rote that I telle
My tyme is alwey on ⁊and eủer/re was
Radix omniu maloru est cupeditas
First I pronounce whens that I come /
And thanne my bull schew I all ⁊and sum
Ovre lege lordis sele is my patente
Þat schew I fyrst my body to warent
Þat no man be so bolde prest ne clerke
Me to distroble of Crystꝭes holy werke
And aftir that telle I forthe my tales
Bullis of popes and of Cardinalles
Of patriaches ⁊and bisshopes I schewe /¶
And in latyne I speke a wordes fewe
To saverou withe my predicaciou
And for to styr men to devocioun
Þan schew I Forthe my long cristal stones
I Cramyd ful of Cloutes ⁊and of bonis
Relikes thei ben as wen thei echone
Þan have I in latou a scholderbone /
Which was an holy Iewes schepe
God men sey I take of my wordes kepe
Yf that this bone be wasche in ony welle
Yf cow or Calfe or schepe or ox swell
Þat eny worme hathe I rote or I stonge
Touche he this bone a nōmn he schalle be sounde
And yit also forthermore
Of pocke or scabbe or of oþ̉er/re sor
Schall eủer/rey schepe be hole þat of this well
Drynkithe a drawte or take kepe what I telle
Wol eủer/rey wyght er þᵗat þe cok him crowith
And do thing that him hovithe
Fastyng drink of this welle a drawte
As thilke holy Iew oure elders ones tauȝt
His bestꝭes ⁊and his stor schul multeplie
And sirs also hit helithe Ielowsye
And þ̉er/re a man befal in Ielousy rage
Lete make wᵗith this wat̉er/re his potage
And neủer/re schall he mor̉er/re wyf mystrest
Þei he þe sothe a defaute by hir wyst
Al had sche taken prestꝭes two or þre
Her is a meteyne eke ye may se
He that his honde wolle put in that meteyn
He schalle have multepliyng of his greyn
When he hathe sowen be it whet or otꝭes
So that of pens oþir of grotꝭes
And men ⁊and women o thing werne I yowe
Yf ony wyȝt be now in this chorche
Þat hathe done synne horryble þᵗat he
Dere nouȝt for schame schryven be
Or ony woman be sche yong or olde
Þat hathe made hir husbonde kukwolde
Suche folke schall have no power ne grace
To offre to my relikꝭes in þis place
And who so fyndithe hi oute of suche blame
Yf thei wolle come vp ⁊and offr a goddes name /
And I asoyle hem by the auctoryte
Suche that by bull was grauntid me
By this gavde have I wonne every yer
An hundrid marke sith I was pardon
I stonde like a Clerke in a pulpit
And schew lewde peple ⁊and doun thei sett
I preche so as ye have hard be for
And tel an hunderde Iapis more
Þenne peyne I me to strech forth my necke
And est ⁊and west vpon the peple I becke
As dothe a dofe syttyng vp on a berne
My . hondes ⁊and my tonge go so yerne
Þat it is Ioy to se my besynes ¶
Of averice and suche oþ̉er/re cursidnes
Is al my prechyng to make he fre
To yeve her panes ⁊and namly vn to me
For myn entente is nouȝt but for to wyn
And no thing for correcciou of synne
I rek neủer/re when thei be buryed
Þowhe that hir soules go a blak buryd
For Certes mony a predicaciou
Sounithe ofte tyme in evil entenciou
Som for plesaunce of folke ⁊and for flaterye
To be avauncid be Ipocrasye
And som for veyne glorie ⁊and some for hate
For when I dare not oþ̉er/re wyse debate
Þan wol I stynge he wᵗith my tong smerte
In preching so that he schall not a starte /
To ben defamed falsely yf þᵗat he
Hathe trespassid to my broþ̉er/re or to me
For thow I telle not his proꝑper/par name
Men schul wel know it is the same
By simony ⁊and by oþ̉er/re circumstaunces
Thus quite I folke that doith vs displesauns
Þus spete I oute venym vnder huȝe
Of holynes to seme holy ⁊and trewe
But schortly myn entent I wol devise /
I preche of nothing but of Covetise
Þer fore my tyme is yit ⁊and eủer/re was
Radix omnium maloru est Cupeditas
Þus Can I preche a yene the same vice
Suche as I vse ⁊and that is averise
But they I my selfe be gylty in that synne
Yit Can I make oþ̉er/re folke to wynne
From Avaryece / and sor to repent
But that is nauȝt my pryncipall entente
I preche no thinge but for couetyse
Of this mat̉er/re I ouȝt I now suffise
Þan tel I of ensamples meny one
Of olde stories longe tyme a gone
For lewde peple louen tales olde
Whiche thingꝭes Can thei well reporte ⁊and holde
What trow ye whiles that I may preche
And wynne golde ⁊and sylủer/re for I teche
Þat I wolle lyve in povert wylfully
Nay nay I thouȝt it neủer/re truly
For I wolle preche ⁊and bede in sundry londes
I wol not do no labour wᵗith my hondes
And make balkes ⁊and liue þ̉er/re by
Be cause I wolle not begge ydelly
I wolle none of the aposteles count̉er/refete
I wolle have mony Cheses ⁊and whete
Al were it evin of the porest page
Oþir of the porest widow in a vilage /
Al schulde hir Childerin sterve for famen
Nay I woll drynke þe likoure of þe wyn
And have a Ioly wenche in every toun
But herkenithe lordes in conclusiou ¶
Youre likyng is that I schall tel a tale
Now I have dronke a drawte of Corny ale
Be god I hope I schall telle yow a thinge
Þat schall be reson ben at yoᵘur likyng
For thowe my selve be a ful viciouse man
A moral tale yit I yow tel can
Which . I am wont to preche for to wynne
Now holde yoᵘur pese my tale I wol begynne
IN flaunderis whilom was a company
Of yong folke that haunten foly
As ryot hasard steves ⁊and taverns
Þei daunsen ⁊and pley at dyse both day ⁊and nyȝt
And etyn also ⁊and dronken oủer/re al hir myȝt
Þorow which þei don þe devil sacrefise
Wᵗith in the develis temple in cursid wyse
Þe suꝑper/parfluites abhominable
Hir othis ben so grete ⁊and dampnable
Þat it is gresely for to here . hem swer
Oure blessid lordes body þei to tere
Hem thouȝt Iewes rent him not I nowe
And eche of hem at oþris synis lowhe
And þan ryȝt a none cam to ublesteres
Fetes ⁊and smal yong frutesteres
Syngers wᵗith harpes baudes wafereris
Such ben verre the develis offisers
To kyndill ⁊and blow the firis of lechery
That is avexid to glotony
Þe holy wryte take I to wytnesse
Þat lechery is in wyne is a dronknes
Loo how that dronken loothe onkyndly
Ley by his douȝt̉er/rees two vnwetyngly
So dronke he was he wist not what he wroute
And þe for fro repent him ouȝt
Heroudes who so wolle þe storys seche
Þe may ye lerne ⁊and by ensample teche
When he of his wyne was replete at his fest
Ryȝt at his oune table yave his hest
To slene the baptist Iohn ful gyltles
Senek seith eke gode wordes doutles
He seith he can no dyfferens fynde
Be twyx a man that is oute of his mynde
And a man that is dronklew
But þᵗat wodnes is fallen in a schrew
Parseverth leng than doth dronknes
O glotony ful of cursidnes
O Cause first of oure confusiou
O original first of oure dampnaciou
Til Crist had boute vs wᵗith his blode a yen
Lo how der ⁊and schortly was to seyne
A boute was the Cursid vilony
Corupte was al this worlde þorow gloteny
Adam oure fadir ⁊and his wyf also
From paradyse to laboᵘur ⁊and to woo
Were drivin for þᵗat vyse it is no drede ¶
For whiles that adam fastid as I rede /
He was in paradyse ⁊and when that he
Ete of þe frute defendid on a tre
And a none he was oute cast to wo ⁊and pyne
O glotony on the wel oute vs pleyne
O wist a man how mony maladys
Folowith the excersyse of glotenyes
He schuld be þe mor mesurable
Of his dyete syttyng at the table
Alas the schorte throte the tendir mouthe
Makest þat Est ⁊and west Northe ⁊and southe
In erthe in eyr in wat̉er/re men to swynke
To gete a glotou mete ⁊and drynke
Of this mat̉er/re O poule wel Canst þᵘ trete /
Mete vn to wombe ⁊and wombe eke vn to mete
Schal god distriıı̄une boith as poule seithe
Alas a foule thing is be my feith
To sey this worde ⁊and fouler is þe dede
When men so drynkith of the white ⁊and of þe rede /
Þat of his throte he makith his prive
Þorow thilke cursid suꝑper/parfluite
Þe Apostel seith weping ful petovsly
Þ̉er/re walken mony of whiche yow told have I
I Sey it now wepyng wᵗith petouse voyse
Þer ben enmyes of Cristꝭes croise
Of which þe ende is dethe þe wombe is hir god
O wombe O . holy o stynkyng god
Fulfillid of dung and of Corrupciou
At eyþ̉er/re ende of þe foule is þe sounde
How gret Cost and labour is to fynde
Thes cokes how þei stampe streyn ⁊and grynde
And turn substaıı̄unce in to Accidente /
To fulfil al thi lekerouse talent
Oute of the harde bonis knokinge þei
Þe Mary for thei Cast nouȝt a weye
Þat may go þorow the golet softe ⁊and sate /
Of spiceri of levis barke ⁊and rote /
Schall be his sause made by delyte
To make him yit a newer apetite /
But certes he that hauntith such delites

Stondith thus quod Mellebe and sothe
it is that

Causles and with oute cause
and resouns

ye han dou gret Iniuryes
and wronges to me ⁊and to my wyf and
to my douȝt̉er/re / also

ye haue enterid in
to myn house by violence

⁊and han don
suche outrage that al men knowen wel
that ye haue deseruid dethe /

and þ̉er/refor̉er/re
wolle I wute ⁊and know of yow

whethir
ye wolle put the punyschyng and þe
Chastisyng and þe vengeaunce of þis
outrage in the wille of me ⁊and of my
wyf or ye wolle nat ~~ . ~~ .

Than the wysest of hem þre //an=
swerde for hem al and said

Sir
we knowen wel þat we be vnworthi for
to Come to the Courte of so gret a lord
and so worthi as ye ben

for we han so
gretly mystaken vs offendid ⁊and gyltid
in such a wyse a geyne youre hie //lord=
schipe

that treuly we han deseruid
þe dethe

and yit for the grete godnes
and debonarte that all the world //witn=
essith of your ꝑper/parsone

we submittin vs
to the excellence ⁊and þe benyngnite of
your gracious lordscipe

and ben redy
to obey to al your comaundmentis

besekyng /
yow of your mcyable pitee ye wolle //cōmsi=
derin our gret repentaunce / and low /
submyssioun

and graunt vs foryevenes
of oure outragious trespassis ⁊and of offencꝭes

For wel ye knowen that oure liberall
grace / and mercy strechen hem forþ̉er/re
in to godenes than done our //outragio=
us / giltis and tresspasses in to wickidnes

al be it that Cursidly and dampnabely
we han a gyltid a yene your hye //lordsc= hipe

Than Mellebe toke hem
vp from the grounde / ful //beny=
ngly

and resceyuid hir obligacions and
hir bondes by hir othis vp on hir pleggꝭes
and borowes

and assinid hem a certeyn
day to returin vn to his Court

accepe
and receyvin the centence and the //Iuge=
ment / that Mellebe wolde Comaunde to
be dou on hem by the Causes by fore /
saide

which thingꝭes ordeynid oủer/rey man
returnid to his owne house / ~~ . ~~

ANd when dame prudence
saw hir tyme sche feynid and
axte hir lord Mellebe /

what vengeance
he thovgh to take vp on his adủer/resarijs

TO which Mellebe aunswerd ⁊and
saide certes qd he I think ⁊and //pur=
pose me fully

to disherite hem of alle
that eủer/re they han ⁊and for to put hem in
Exilid for eủer/remor̉er/re . ~~ . ~~ . ~~ .

CCertes qd dame prudens this wer̉er/re
a cruel Centence / and mochil a .
geyne resou

for ye be rich I now ⁊and have
non nede of othir menis gode

and ye
myten ful lyȝtly in this wyse gete yow
a couetouse name

which is a visious .
lyving and ought to ben eschued of eủer/rey //
gode man

for aftir the saw of þe worde of þe
apostle Couetise is rote of al harmes

and
þ̉er/refore / it is bett̉er/re for yow for to lese so mochel /
gode of youre oune þan for to taken of hir
gode in this man

for bett̉er/re it is to lese gode
withe worschipe / than it is to wyn gode
withe vilony and schame

and eủer/rey man ouȝt
to do his deligence and his besynes to getyn
him a gode name /

and yit schall he not only
besy him in kepyng of his gode name

but
he schall al wey enforsyn hem to do som
thing by which he may reneve his gode
name

for it is written þat the olde gode
lose of a man or gode name is sone gone
and passid when it is not newed ne //re=
noveled /

and as towching þat ye seyn þat
ye wolle exile your adủer/resarijs

þat thinkith
me muchel ayenst resou and out of //mes=
ure /

Considering the power̉er/re that thei han
yeven yow vpou hem selfe /

and it is wretyn
þat he is worthi to lese his prevelage / þat
mys vsithe þe myȝt and powere that is yevyn
him

and I sett case ye myȝt enioyne hem
that peyne by ryȝt and by law

which I .
trow ye may not do

I sey ye myȝt not put
it to execuciou ꝑper/paraventure

and than were
it likly to turn it to wer̉er/re as it was be forn

and þ̉er/refore yf ye wolle þat men do yow . /
obeysaunce ye must deme more //curte=
sly

þis is to seyn ye must yef more esyer /
sentence / and Iugement

for it is wretyn
that he that most curteysely comaundith to him
men must obeyen

and þ̉er/refor I prey yowe
þat in this necessite and in this nede ye
hast yow to overcom youre herte /

For senek
seith he that oủer/recomes his hert oủer/recomes
twyes /

and Tullius seithe þer is no thing
so comendable in a gret lord

as when he
is debonayr̉er/re and meke and aparleth him
lyȝtly

and I pray yow þat ye wolle for ber̉er/re
now to done vengeaunce /

in suche a man
þat your gode name may be kepte and .
conseruid

and that men may have cause
and mater̉er/re to preise yow of pite and mcy

and that ye hau no cause to repent yow
of thing that ye done

for senek / sithe he
oủer/recomyth in an evil man þat repentith
him of his victory

wher for I pray yow .
lete mercy be in your harte

to the effect /
and the entente / that god almyȝty hau
mercy on yow in his last Iugement

For
Seint Iame seith in his epistil Iugement
with outen mcy schal be don to him þat
hath no mcy on a noþ̉er/re wyȝt / . ~~ . ~~

Whenne Mellebe had hard the grete
Styles ⁊and resones of dame prudēmce /
his wyf and hir wyse enformacoıı̄uns
and techingꝭes

his herte gan encline to þe //
wille of his wyf considering hir trew /in=
tente /

Confermid him anone and assentid
him to worke aftir her counsell

and thankid
god of whom procedeth al vertu and al
godnes þat him sent a wyf of so grete
discreciou

and when the day come that
his adủer/resarijs schulde a pere in his psence

he spake to hem ful godely and seide in þis /
wyse

al be it so that of youre pryde and hye
psumpsiou and foly and of youre necligens
and onconnyng

ye haue mysborne yow and
trespassid a yenst me /

yit for as much as
I se be your grete humilite

and that ye be
so sory and repentaunt of your gyltꝭes

it //
restreynith me to do yow grace / and mcy
wher for I receyve yow to my grace /

and
for yeve yow vtterly alle the offencꝭes Iniurijs
and wronges that ye haue done ayenst me
and myn

to this effecte and to this ende
þat god of his endles mcy

wolle at the
tyme of my dying / for yeve me my gyltꝭes
that I have trespassid to him in this wrecchid
worlde

for doutles yf we be sory ⁊and repentant
for oure synnes and gyltꝭes þe whiche we //
haue trespassid in the syȝt of oure lorde god
he is so free and so mcyable

þat he wolle /
for yeve vs our gyltꝭes

and bryng vs to þe
blys þat neủer/re schall have ende . ~~ .

div.l: When Endid was the tale of Mellebe
And of prudence / and hir benignite
Oure host seide as I am feytheful man
And by the pcious Corpus Madrian
I had leủer/re than a barell of Ale
Þat gode lefe my wyf had hard this tale
For sch nys no thing of such paciens
As was this Mellibe ⁊and his wyf prudense
By goddes bones when I bete my knaves
Sche bryngith me the grete Clobbid stavis
And Crieth slee the doggꝭes eủer/rey chone
And breke both bak ⁊and also bone
And yf that eny neyȝbour̉er/re of myn
Wol not in church to my wyf enclyne
Or so hardy to hir trerspas
When sche Comythe home sche Rampith in my face
And / Criethe fals Coward wrek thi wyf
By Corpus dominus I wol have thi knyf
And thow shalt have my distaff and goo spynne
Fro day to nyȝte / ryȝt thus she wolle be gynne
Alas she saith that eủer/re I was shape
To wedde a mylke soppe or so grete an ape
Þat wolde ben oủer/reladde wᵗith eủer/rey wyȝte
Thow darste not stonde by thy wyfe aryȝte
This is my lyfe / but yf I wolde fyȝte
And oute at the dore anone I mote me dyȝte
Or ellꝭes I am loste but yf that I
Be like a wylde lioune foule hardy
I wote welle she wolle done me slee some day
Some neyȝbour and than go my wey
For I am ꝑper/parlous wᵗith knyf in honde
All be it that I dare not her̉er/re wiþ stonde
For she is bygge in armes by my feythe
That shall he fynde þᵗat he here mys seyþ
But lete vs passe oủer/re of this mat̉er/re
My lorde sir monke he saith be mury of cher̉er/re
For ye shalle telle a tale trewly
Loo rowchest̉er/re stondith her̉er/re faste by
Ryde forþ myn owne lorde ⁊and breke not yowr̉er/re game
But be my trowthe I knowe not your name
Wher̉er/re I shalle Calle yow my lorde daun Iohn
Or daun Thomᵃs or daun Albou
Of what howse be ye by yoᵘur fadir kyn
I a vowe to god þᵘ hast a ful fair̉er/re skyn
It is a gentil pasture þ̉er/re þᵘ goste
Thou art not like a penaunte or a goste
Vp on my feyþe þow art som officere
Som worthi sextein or som selarere
For be my fadir soule as to my dome
Þᵘ art a mast̉er/re whan þᵘ art at home
No pore Cloysterere ne no pore novice
But a goủer/renour wyli ⁊and wyse
And þ̉er/re wᵗith al of brawes ⁊and of bones
A wel fayr̉er/re ꝑper/parsone for the nones
I pray to god yeve him cōmfusiou
That First the browȝt in to relugiou
Thow wost han be a . tredefoule a ryȝte
Haddist thow as grete leve as þᵘ hast myȝte
To parforme al thi luste in engenderure
Þow hadest be gotou mony a Creature
Allas whi werist thow so wyde a Cope
God yeve me sorow and I were a pope
Not only þᵘ but eủer/rey myȝty man
Thowȝe he were shore hey vp on þe pan
Shulde han a wyf for alle þis worlde is lorne
Religion hathe taken vp alle þe Corne
Of tredynge ⁊and be borell men ben shrimpes
Of feble trees Comythe wrecchid ympes
This makithe our childeren ben so slender
And feble that þei ne may not wele engendre
This makithe that our wyfes wolle assay
Religyous folke for þey may bett̉er/re paye
Of venus payment that may we
God wote no lussheborows pay yee
But beþ not wroth my lord thow I playe
Ful ofte in game a sooþ I have hard say
This worthi monke toke alle in paciens
And saide I wol done al my deligence
As ferre as sonneþ in to honestee
To telle yow a tale or too oþ̉er/re þree
And yf thow leste to herkyn hedirward
I wolle yow seye the lyf of seint Edwarde
Or eles tregedies / first wolle I telle
Of which I have an hundred in my selle
Tregedyes is for to telle a Certeyne story
As elde bokes maken memorye
Of hēm that stonde in grete prosꝑper/parite
And is yfalle oute of hyhe degree
In to myserye ⁊and endith wrecchidly
And they ben versefyed comenly
Of sex fete þᵗat men clepen examytrou
In prose eke ben endited many one
And eke of meter in many sundry wyse
Loo this ouȝte you ynow suffice
Now harkenith yf you lyst it for to her̉er/re
But first I yow be seche in this matere
Thouȝ I by ordre telle not þos þynges
Be it of popes Emꝑper/paroᵘurs or kynges
And aftir age as men wreten fynde
But telle hem . some bifore ⁊and some by hynde
As it Comeþ now to my remembraunce /
Have me Excusid of myn ignoraunce /
I wolle be wayle in mane of tregedye
The harme of hīm that stondith in hye degre /
And fellen so þᵗat þ̉er/re nas no remedye
To bryng hem oute of hir adủer/resitee
For Certeyne whan fortune liste to flee
Ther may no man of hure þe cours be holde
Lete noman truste on blynde ꝓprosꝑper/parite
Beþ ware by this ensample yong ⁊and olde
At lucyfere þow he an aıı̄ungel were
And not a man at hīm I wolle begynne
For youþ ne fortune may nōm aungel der̉er/re
From hyȝe degree yit felle he for his synne
Doune into helle wher as he is yit ynne
O lucifere bryȝtest of angelles alle
Now art thow sathanas that maist not twynne /
Out of mysery in wych þᵘ art I falle
Lo adam in the felde of damascene
Wᵗith goddes owne fynger wrouȝt was / he
And not by getynge of mannes sperme vnclene
And welte alle paradys sauynge oo tree
Hadde neủer/re worldly man so hye degree
A adam hadde til he for his goủer/renaıı̄unce
Was drevyn oute of his hye ꝓprosꝑper/parite
To laboure and to helle ⁊and to myschaunse
LOo Sampsone which was annunciat
By the aıı̄ungel longe or his natiuite
And was to god almyȝty cōmsecrat
And stode in noblesse / while he myȝt see
Was neủer/re suche anoþ̉er/re as was he
To speke of strenght ⁊and þ̉er/reto of hardynesse
But to his wyfes tolde his secree
Thorow whiche he slow hīm selve for hevynesse
Sampson this noble ⁊and myȝti champiou
Wᵗith oute wepene save his hondes tweyne
He slowe and al to rente þe lyone
Toward his weddynge walkynge by the weye
His fals wyf Coude him so plese ⁊and preye
Tille she his Counseill knew ⁊and she vntrewe
Vnto his foos his Counseill gan be wrey
And him forsoke ⁊and toke a noþ̉er/re newe
An hunderid foxes toke sampsou for Ire
And alle hir tayles he to gedyr bonde
And sette the foxes tayles al on fyre
For he in eủer/rey tayle had put a bronde
And thei brent alle Cornes in that londe
And alle hir olyves ⁊and hir vynes eke
A thovsand men he slowe wᵗith his honde
And had no wepene but an asse cheke
Whenne thei were slayne so thristid he þᵗat he
Was wel ny lorne For which he gan to prey
That god wolde of his mcy have some pyte
And send him drynke or eles most he dye
And of this asse Cheke þᵗat was so drye
Oute of a wange toþe spronge anon a welle
Of which he dronke y nowe shortly to seye
Thus helpe him god as Iudicu can telle
By verray force at gasou on a nyȝte
Maugre philicitiens of that Citee
The gate of þe toun he haþ vp plyȝt
And on his bakke y caryed hīm hathe he
Hye on an hille wher as myȝt see
O noble ⁊and myȝti sampsou leve ⁊and dere
Ne haddest thow tolde to wommen þy secree
In al this worlde ne hadde be thi pece
This sampsou neủer/re syþ̉er/re dronke ne wyn
Ne on his hede Came rasour non ne sher̉er/re
By pcepte of þᵉ messang devyn
For al his strenght was in his here
And fully twenty yeer̉er/re by yeer̉er/re
He hadde of Irall þe goủer/renaunce /
But sone aftir shalle he wepe ful many a teere
For women shule brynge hīm to mysche
UN to his leman dalida he tolde
That in his heris al his strenght lay
And falsly to his fomen she hīm solde
And shepyng in hir barme vpon a day
She made to Clyppe or shere his her̉er/re aweye
And made his foo men all his Crafte aspien
And when thei him fonde in such araye
They bonde hīm fast ⁊and put oute his yen
Bvt or his hede / were Clippid or y schave
Ther was no / bonde þᵗat myȝt hēm bynde
But now is he in psoune put in / a / cave
Wher as thei made hīm at the querne grynde
O noble Sampsou strengest of mankyd
O whilom Iugge in gloryre ⁊and richesse
Now maiste thowe wepe wᵗith thin yen blynde
Sithen thow art I falle into wrecchidnesse
The Ende of thes Caytyfes was as I shall sey
His foo men made a fest vp ou a day
And made hīm as hure fole by fore hēm play
And this was a temple of a grete araye
But at the laste he made a foule a fraye
For he too postꝭes shoke ⁊and made hēm falle
And doun felle þe temple ⁊and al þ̉er/re it laye
And slowhe him selfe ⁊and eke his fomen alle
This is the Ende þe pⁱrinces eủer/reychone
And eke a thousand bodijs were þ̉er/re slayne
Wᵗith fallyng of the grete temple of stone
Of Sampson wolle I no more sayn
Be ware of this Ensample olde ⁊and pleyne
That no man telle her Counseill to hir wyfes
Of suche thinge as þey wolde have secre fayne
Yf that it touche hir lemes or hir lyves
OF Ercule that soủer/reayne cōmquerour
Sygned his werkes lewed ⁊and hye renoun
For in his tyme of strenght he bare þᵉ flour̉er/re
He slowe ⁊and by rafte the skynne of the lyoun
He of seynt aures leyde þe bost a downe
He arpies slowh þe cruell bridde felle
He golden apples raffte of the dragou
He drowe oute Serberoys þe hounde of helle
HE slowe þe Cruell Tyraunt Buserous
And made his hors to frete hīm flesche ⁊and bone
He slowe the veraye serpent venemous
Of achilles too hornes brake he one
And he slow Cacus in a Cave of stone
He slowe the geaunt Anteus þe stronge
He slowe the gresly bore ⁊and þᵗat a none
And bare his hede vpou his necke longe
Was neủer/re wyȝte sithen the worlde be gan
Þat slowe so many mynstres as did he
Þorow oute þis wyde world his name ran
What for his strenght and his bounte
And into eủer/rey reme went he for to see
He was so stronge that no man myȝt hīm lette
And at the worldes ende as saith trophe
In stede of boundes he a piler sette
A lemman had this noble Champiou
That hyȝte dyaniyre / as fresche as may
And as the Clerkes maden menciou
She hath him sent a sherte freshe ⁊and gaye
Allas his shirt and welaweye
Evenemed was subtily wᵗith alle
That or he had werid it halfe a daye
Hit made his bones from his fleshe falle
Bvt natheles some Clerkes her̉er/re excuson
By one that hyȝt nessus þᵗat it maked
Be as it be may I wille hure not accusen
But on his bak this shert he werid al naked
Tyl that his flessh was for þe venyme blakid
And whan he saw non othir remedy
In hote coles he hath hīm selve raked
For wᵗith no / venym deynid hīm to dye
Thus straf this worthi myȝti Arcules
Loo ho may trust on fortune ony throwe
For hīm that folowith all þis worlde of pres
Or he be ware is ofte leyde full lowe
Ful wyse is he that him self Can knowe
By ware for whanne that fortune lyst to glose
Thene waytith she hir man downe to throwe
By suche a weye as he wolde lest suppose
The myȝti trone the psious tresoure
The glorious septre ⁊and Riall mageste
That had the kyng nabugodonoser
Wᵗith tonge vnneþe may discreuid be
He twyes wan Ierlm the Citee
The vessell of the temple wᵗith him ladde
At babulon was his soủer/reayne se
In whiche his glorye ⁊and his delite he hadde
The fairest childer of þe blode rialle
Of Ierlm he dide do gylde a none
And make eche of hēm to bēm his cherle
Amonge al oþ̉er/re danyel was one
That was the wysest childe of eủer/rey chone
For he the dromes of þe kynge expounde
Wher as in Calday Clerke was þ̉er/re none
That wyst to what fyne his dremes souned
This proude kynge lete make a statute of
Sexty Cubettꝭes longe ⁊and seven in brede
To which ymage boþe yonge ⁊and olde
Comaunded he to loute ⁊and have in drede
Or in a forneyse full of flaumes rede
He schuld be brente þat wolde not obeye
But neủer/re wolde assent to that dede
Daniysel ne his yonge felawes tweyne
This kyng was proude passing of his degre
He wende god þᵗat syttith in mageste
Had nouȝt be so gret a lorde as he
But sodenly he loste his dignitee
And like a best hīm semid for to be
And ete heye as an Oxe and laye þ̉er/re oute
In rayne wᵗith bestꝭes wylde walkid he
Til Certeyne tyme was comyn a boute
And like an eglis fetheris was his heris
His nayles like briddes Clawes wer̉er/re
God releued him a certeyne yeeris
And yaf hīm wytte ⁊and than wᵗith many a teere
He thankid god / ⁊and eủer/re his lyf in fere
Was he to done a mys or more to trespas
And or that tyme . y leyde was on his bere
He knewe wele that god was ful of myȝt ⁊and gᵃce /
His sone which that / hyȝt baltazer
That helde the regne aftir his fadris day
He by his fadir Couþe not be ware
For proude he was of herte ⁊and of araye
And eke an ydolastre was he aye
His heye estate assured hīm in pryde
But fortune Cast him downe ⁊and þ̉er/re he laye
And sodenly his regne ganne devide
A Feste he made vn to his lordis alle
Vpou a tyme he made hēm blyþe be
And than his officers gan he Calle
Goo bryngith forthe þe vesseles qd he
Which that my fadir in his prosꝑper/parite
Oute of the temple of Ierlm be rafte /
And to oure heye goddes thanke . wee
Of honoure that oure elders wᵗith vs lafte /
His wyf his lordes ⁊and his concubynes
Ay drynken whiles hir apetyte last
Oute of this noble vessels sondry wynes
And on a walle he his yen Caste
And sawe an hande armles þᵗat wrouȝte ful fast
For fere of which he quoke ⁊and sykid sore
This hond that baltaser made so sore a gast
Wrote mene techil phares ⁊and no more
IN all that londe magican was þ̉er/re non
Þat couþe expoune what þis lre ment
But danyel Expouned it a none
And saide kynge / god to þi fadir sent
Glorie and honoᵘur Regne tresour ⁊and rent
And þ̉er/refore god grete wreche on him sent
And him be rafte the regne that he hadde
HE was oute Caste of manis companye
Wᵗith asses was his habitaciou

Vp on a day as he was wonte to gone
And in the Capitole anone hīm hente
This fals brutus ⁊and his fals foon
Han stikid hīm / wᵗith boydkyns a none
Wᵗith many a wounde ⁊and þus þei lete hīm lye
But neủer/re grunte he att noo stroke but one
Or ellꝭes at too but yf his story lye
SO manly was this Iulius of herte
And so welle loved estatly honeste
Þat Þouȝe his dedely wondes so sore smerte
His mantell oủer/re his hepes cast hee
For no man shulde see his pvitee
And as he lay in dyenge on a traunce
And wist verraly þᵗat dede was he
Of honeste yit hadde he remembraunce /
Lvcane to this storye I recomende
And to swetou ⁊and to valerious also
Þᵗat of this story writethe worde ⁊and ende
How that these grete cōmqueroures too
Fortune was hir frende ⁊and aftir hir foo
No man trust vpou his fauour̉er/re longe
But have here in a wayte eủer/re moo
Wytnesse of all þes conquerous stronge
This rich gresus whilom kynge of lyde
Of whiche gresus sequnis lord hīm dradde
Yit was he Couȝte amonges all this pryde
And to be brente men to the fuyre hīm ladde
But suche arayne doun fro the walken shadde
Þat slowe the fyre ⁊and made him to escape
But to be ware yitt no grace he hadde
Til fortune on the galous made hīm gape
Whanne he escaped was Can he not stynte
For to be gynne a new regne a yene
He wend wele for that fortune hīm sent
Suche happe þᵗat he escaped þorouȝe þe rayne
That of his foos he myȝt not be slayne
A suche a sweven vpou a nyȝte he mette
Of whiche he was so proude ⁊and eke so fayne
That he in vengaunce all his hert sette
Opou a tree he was as him thouȝte
Þer Iubit̉er/re him wysshe bothe hals ⁊and syde
And phebus eke a fayre to wayle hīm brouȝte
To drye hīm wᵗith ⁊and þ̉er/refore waxe his pryde
And to his douȝt̉er/re that stode hym besyde
Which that he knewe in heye sentence abounde
He badde hir telle what hit signified
And she his dreme þus expounde
The tree quod she the galows is to mene
And Iubiter by tokenith snowe ⁊and rayne
And phebus wᵗith his towayle so clene
Tho bene the sonis stremes for to sayne
Þou shalt an honged be fadir Certeyne
Rayne shall the wasshe and sonne shalle þe drye
Þus warned she him ful platte ⁊and ful playne
His douȝt̉er/re þat callid was phavye
AN honged was gresus þe proude kynge
His Riall trone myȝt him noȝt avayle
Tregedys is non oþ̉er/re man thinge
Ne canne in synnynge / crye ne be wayle
But that fortune alwey wolle assayle
Wᵗith vnware stroke þe reynes that ben proude /
For whanne / men trustithe hir than wolle she fayle
And Coủer/re hir bryȝt face wᵗith a cloude
O noble o worthi petre glorie of Spayne
Whom fortune helde so highe in mageste
Wel oughten men this pitous dethe cōmpleyne
Out of thi londe thi broþ̉er/re made þe flee
And aftir at a sege be subtilite
Þou were betraisshed ⁊and lad vn to his tente
Where as he wᵗith his owne honde slewe þe
Succeding in þi regne and in thi rente
The felde of snowe wᵗith þe Egle of blak þ̉er/reynne
Chought wᵗith þe lymerod colourid al wᵗith glede
He brewe this cursidnesse ⁊and all this synne
Þe wiked nest was worker of this nede
Nought charles Olyuer that toke ay hede
Of trowþe and honoᵘur but of Armorike
Genylon Olyuer corupt for mede
Brought this worthi king / to such a brike
O worthi petre / king of Cipre alsoo
Þat alisaundir wan bi hygh mastrie
Ful many an hethen wroughtest þou woo
Of which tweyne oune liges hadde envie
And for no thing but for thi cheualrie
Thei in thi bed han slayne þe by þe morow
Þus can fortune hire wheel gouerne ⁊and gie
And oute of Ioye brynge men to sorowe
OF milayne gret Gernabo viscoıı̄unte
God of delite and scorge of lumbardie
Whi shulde I nowe þi in fortune acoıı̄unte
Syn in estate þou clomben were so hye
Thi broþers soone þat was thi double allye
For he thi nevew was ⁊and soone in lawe
Wiþ inne his psonne made the to dye
But whi ne how not I / þat þou were slawe
OF the Erle hugelyn of pise þe langoᵘur
Ther may no tunge telle for pitee
But litle out of pize stant a toure
In which toure in pⁱrisoune put was he
And wᵗith him ben his litle childerin thre
Þe eldest scarsly fyve yere was of age
Allas fortune it was grete cruelte
Suche briddis to put in suche a cage
Dampned was he to die in þᵗat presou
For Rogier whiche þat bisshop of pize
Had on him made a fals suggestiou
Þurgh þe peple gan vp on him arise
And put him in prisou in suche wyse
As ye haue harde and mete ⁊and drinke he hadde
And þerwithal it was ful pore ⁊and badde
And on a day be fille þᵗat in þᵗat houre
When that his met wont was to be broute
Þe Gailoᵘur shette þe dores of the toure
He harde it wel but he spake right nought
And in his herte a noon þ̉er/re fille a þought
þat they for hung wolde don hīm dien
Allas quod he allas þᵗat I was wrouȝt
Þer with þe teris fille from his eien
His yonge son þat þre yere was of age
Vn to him saide fadir fadir whi do ye wepe
When wil þe gailour bringe vs potage
Is þer no morcel brede þᵗat ye do kepe
I am so hungry / þat I may not slepe
Now wolde god that I myȝt slepe eủer/ree
Þan shulde not hıı̄unger in my wombe crepe
Þere nys no thing but brede þᵗat me were leủer/re
Thus dai be dai this childe be gan to crie
Tyl in his fadris barme a doune it lay
And saide farewel fadir I mot dye
And kist his fadir and dide þe same daie
And whan the woful fadir this thing sai
Fo woo his armes too he gan to byte
And saide allas fortune and weilaway
Þi fals whele my wo al may I wite
His chelderin wende / that it for hung was
Þat he his armes gnow and not for woo
And seiden fadir do not so allas
But rather ete the flessh vpou vs too
Oure Flessh þᵘ gaff vs take oure Flessh vs froo
And ete I now þus thei to hīm saide
And aftir that wiþinne a day or too
Þei leyde hem in his lappe a doıı̄une ⁊and dide
Him selfe despeired eke for hunger starfe
Þus endid is this myȝti erle of pize
From hye estate fortune awey him carf
Of this tragedie it ought I nough suffise
Who so wolde here it in a leng wyse
Redeþ the gret poete of Itayle
Þat hight daıı̄unt for he can it al devise
From point to point nat a worde wol he fayle

l.hi: Here stintith þe knyȝt þe monk of his tale

div.l: ¶ Here stintith þe knyȝt þe monk of his tale
O quod the knyȝt gode sire nomere of this
Þat ye haue saide is ryȝt I now I wis
And moche more for litle heuynesse
Is ryght I now for moch folke I gesse
Yoᵘur talis Don vs no disport nor game
Þerfor sir monke . o daıı̄un pers by your name
I pray you hertli telle vs sumwhat eles
For sikirli nere for clynkyng of yoᵘur bellis
Þat on yoᵘur bridel hongen on eủer/rey syde
Be hevene kyng that for vs al dide
I shulde er this have falen doıı̄un for slepe
Al þow the snowe had neủer/ree ben so depe
Þan had yoᵘur tale al be tolde in veyne
For certayne as þat þes clerkes seien
Wher as a man may have noon audience
Nouȝt helpith to telle his sentence
And wel I wot þe substaunce is in me
Yf any thing shal wel reportid be
Sir seie sumwhat of huntyng I you praye
Nay quod this monke / I have no lust to plaie
Now late a noþ̉er/re telle as I have tolde
Þan spake our host with rude speche ⁊and bolde
And saide vn to nōmnys prest a noon
Come nere thow prest come hedir þᵘ sir Iohn
Tel vs such thing as may oure hartꝭes glade
Be blithe þowe þou ride vp on a Iade
What thowe þi horse be boþe foule ⁊and lene
Yf he wil serue the rekke not a bene
Loke þat thi hartis be merye euer moo
Ȝis sir qd he ȝis sir so mot I goo
But I be merie I wis I wil be blamed
And ryȝt a noon his tale he hathe a tamed
And þus he saide vnto vs eủer/reychone
This swete prest þis gooli man sir Iohn

Here begynnith þe nōmne preste
of chauntclere~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~
A Pore wedow somdele steppid in Age
Was some tyme dwellyng in a narow cotage
Be syde a greue stonding in a dale
Þis widow of which I telle yow my tale
Syn that ilke day þat she was last awyf
In paciens ladde a ful simple lyf
For litle was hir Cataill / and hir rente
By husbondrye of suche as god hir sent
She fonde hir self ⁊and eke hir Doughtren too
Thre large sowes had she and nomoo
Thre keen and eke a shepe þat hight malle
Ful soti was hir boure and eke hir halle
In whiche she ete ful many a slender mele
Of poynaıı̄unt sauce she nedide neủer/re a dele
No deynte morcelle passed þurgh hir þrote
Hire diete was accordaıı̄unt to hir cote
Replexion ne made hir neủer/re seeke /
Attempre diete / was al hir phisek
And excersice and hertꝭes suffisaıı̄unce
Þe goute lette hir noþing / for to daıı̄unce
Napoplexie shent not hir hede
No wyn ne drank she noþ̉er/re white ne rede
Hir lorde was seruid moste wᵗith white ⁊and blak
Melk ⁊and broune brede in which she fonde no lak /
Seynd bacou and some tyme an eye or tweye
For she was as it were a man deie
A yerde she had enclosid al a boute
With stikkꝭes ⁊and a drie diche withouten
In whiche she had a cok that hiȝte chauntcler
In al the londe of Crowynge nas his pere
His vois was merier þan þe meri orgon
On masse dayes þat in þe chirche gone
Wel sikerer was his crouyng in his logge
Þan is a clok or any abbey oriloge
By nature he krewe his assenciou
Of þe equinoxial in that toune
For whan degreis vx were assendid
Þan krewe he þᵗat it myȝt not ben amendid
His colour was redder þan þe fine coral
And batailed as it were a castel wal
His bille was blak / and as þe Ieet it shone
Like asure were his legges and his ton
His nayles whitt̉er/re than the lile floure
And like the bornid gold was his coloure
Þis gentil kok had in his goủer/renaunce
Seven henes to done al his plesaunce
Which wer his sustris and his ꝑper/paramours
And wondir / like to him of colours
Of whiche the fairest hewed on hir þrote
Was clepid faire Damsel ꝑper/partelote
Curtes she was discret and debonayre
And compaynable / and bare hir selfe so faire
Syn þilke day þᵗat she was sevene yeer olde
That truly she hath þe harte in holde ¶
Of chantclere lokyn in eủer/rey lith
He louid hir so þat wel was him þ̉er/rewith
But suche a ioie it was to hire hēm singe
When that the bryȝt sonne be gan to springe /
Wiþ swete a cord my leef is faren on londe
For thilke tyme as I have vndirstonde
Bestꝭes ⁊and birdis coude speke ⁊and synge
And so bi felle that in a dawnynge
As chaıı̄untcler amongis his viuis alle
Sat on his perche þᵗat was on an halle
And next him satt Dame pertelote
This chaıı̄untclere gan grone in his þrote
As man that in his dreme is drecchid sore
And whan that partelot þus harde hīm rore
She was agast and saide harte dere
What eylith you to grone in þis mane
Ye ben a verrai sleper fi for shame
And he Aunswerd þus ⁊and saide madame
I pray you þat ye take it not agref
By god me mette I was in such myschef
Ryȝt nowe þat yitt my harte is sore a fright
Now god qd he my swevyne reche a riche
And kepe my bodi out of foule psoune
Me mette how þat I romede vp and doune
Withynne ȝerde wher that I sawe a best
Was like an hounde ⁊and wolde han made a reste
Vpon my body ⁊and hadde me dede
His Coloure was be twyxt yelow ⁊and rede
And tipped was his tayle and boþe his eris
With blak vnlike þe remenᵃnt of his heris
His snoute smal wᵗith glowyng eien tweye
Ȝitt for his loke for feer almost I deie
This causid me my gronyng / doutles
Awoy qd she fy on yow hertles
Allas qd she for by that god A boue
Now haue ye loste myn hart ⁊and al my love
I Canne not loue a coward be my feyth
For certis what so any woman seith
We all desiren yf it myȝt be
To han husbondes hardi wyse ⁊and free
And secre and no nygard ne no foole
Ne him that is a gast of eủer/rey toole
Ne noon avaıı̄untoᵘur by þat god above
How durste ȝe seien for shame vnto yoᵘur love
Þat any thing might make yow a ferde
Han ye no manys herte ad han a berde
Allas and cāmne ye ben a gast of sweuenys
Noþing god wote but vanyte / . in sweuen is
Sweuenes engenderin of replecioıı̄uns
And ofte of fume and of compleccioıı̄uns
Whan humoᵘurs ben to habundaunt in a wight
Certis þis Dreme whiche ȝe han mette to night
Comeþ of þe grete suꝑper/parfluite
Of yoᵘur rede colora ꝑper/parde
Whiche causen folke to dredin in hir dermes
Of arwis and of fir wᵗith rede lemes
Of rede bestes þat thei wolle hīm byte
Of contek and of whelpes grete ⁊and lyte
Right as þe humoᵘur of malencolie
Causith ful many a man in slepe to crye
For feer of blak beres or of bolis blake
Or elles blake deuelis wil hem take /
Of oþir humoᵘurs coude I telle also
That wreken many a man in slepe ful woo
But I wolle passe as lyȝtly as I can
Lo caton whiche that was so wyse a man
Seide he not thus / ne do no fors of dremes
Now sir quod she whan we flie from þe bemes
For godes love take sum laxatyf
Vp ꝑper/parill of my soule ⁊and of my lyf
I coıı̄unseil you þe beste I wol not lye
That boþe of Colere and malencolye
Ye purge you / and for ye shal not tarie /
Þow in this tou is noon a potecarie
I shall my silf to erbes teche yow
That shulde bene for yoᵘur hele ⁊and for yoᵘur prow
And in oure yerde too ȝerbis shall I fynde
Þe whiche han of hir propre be kynde
To pʳge yow beneþe ⁊and eke a bove
For gete not this for goddis owne loue
Ye ben ful colerike / of complexiou
War þe sonne in his ascencioıı̄un
Ne finde you nat replet of humoᵘurs hote
For yf he do I dare leie a grote
Þat ye shul haue a fefer tarcian
Or an agu that may ben yoᵘur bane
A dai or too ye shalle have digestius
Of wermis er ye take yoᵘur laxatyfis
Of lauriole sentaurie and fumetere
Or elles of Clebre þᵗat growith þ̉er/re
Of catapuce or of gattris bereis
Or erbe yve þᵗat growiþ in oure ȝerde þ̉er/re merye is
Pik hem vpright as thei growe ⁊and ete hēm in
Be mery husbond for yoᵘur fadir kynne
Dredithe no dreme / I can sey yow nomore
Madame qd he graunt mercy of yoᵘur lore
But natheles as touchith dau catou
Þat hath of wysdom suche a grete renoune /
Þow that he bad no dremes for to drede
Be god men may in olde bokes rede
Of many a man more of auctorite
Than eủer/re catou was so mot I thee
Þat alle þe riuers seyn of his sentence
And han wel founden by exꝑper/pariens
Þat dremes ben significacioıı̄uns
Aswel of ioie as of tribulacions
Þat folke endure in this lyf psent
Þer nedith of þis maken none
Ther verray pve / shewith it in dede
Some of the grettist auctoᵘurs as men rede
Seiþ þus þat to felawis went
On pilgrimage wᵗith ful gode entente
And happid so þei comen in a tou
Wher as þer was such a congregaciou
Of peple and eke so streite of herbigage
Þat thei ne fonde as moch as a cotage
In which þei myȝt boþe logged be
Wherfore þei musten of necessite
As for þat nyght deꝑper/parten company
And eche of hem gothe til his hostelerie
And toke his logyng as it holde falle
Þat oone of hem was logid in a stalle
Fer in a ȝerde with oxen of þe plough
Þat oþ̉er/re man was logid wel I nowght
As was his aventure or his fortune / Þ̉er/reᵉþll¶
div.fw: Þat vs goủer/renᵉþ all as in comun
div.l: Þat vs goủer/reneþ alle as in comune
And so byfil þat longe er it was daie
Þis man mette in his bed þ̉er/re as he lay
How that his felaw gan vpon him Calle
And saide allas for in an oxes stalle
Þis nyȝt I shalle be morderid þ̉er/re I lie
Now helpe me Dere brothir er I die
In all hast Come to me he saide
This man out of his slepe for fere a breide
And whanne that he was wakenid of his slepe
His tʳned hīm and toke of this no kepe
Him thouȝt his Dreme nas but a vanyte
Thus twys in his sleping dremed he
And atte þe thirde tyme ȝit his felawe
Cam as hīm thouȝt ⁊and saide I am now slawe
Be holde my blody woundes depe ⁊and wyde
Arise vp erly in þe morow tyde
And at the west gate of þe toune qd he
A carte ful of Donge ther þᵘ shalt se
In whiche my bodi is hid ful pⁱriueli
Do þilke cart arest boldly
My gᵒld Causid my mordre certeyn
And tolde hīm eủer/rey point how he was slayne
With a wel pitous face pale of hewe
And trust wel this dreme he fonde ful trewe
For on the morow as sone as it was dai
To his felawe he took next wai
And whan that he come to his oxis stalle
Aftir his felaw he be gan to calle
The hosteler Aıı̄unswerd hīm a noon
And saide sir yoᵘur felawe is a goon
Assone as daie he went oute of þe tou
Þis man gan fallyn in suspeciou
Remembring him on þe dremes þᵗat he mette
And forthe he goith no leng wolde he lette
Vn to the west gate of the toıı̄un and fonde
A Donge cart went as it were to donge londe
Þat was arayed in this same wyse
As ye have harde þe dede man deuise
And wᵗith an hardi harte he gan to crie
Vengeaunce and Iustice of þis felonie
My felawe morderid is this same nyȝt
And in this Carte here he lith gaping / vpright
I Crie oute on þe mynistris qd he
Þat shulde kepe and rewle þis citee
Harrow allas here lith my felaw slayn
What shuld I more vn to this tale sayn
Þe peple out sterte / ⁊and caste þe carte to grounde
And in the medil of the Donge þei foıı̄unde
Þe dede man that morderid was al newe
O blisful god that art so Iust ⁊and trewe
Loo howe that þᵘ bewreyist mordre al wey
Mordre wil oute þᵗat se we dai be dai
Mordre is so latsom and abhominable
To god þat is so iust ⁊and resonable
Þat he ne wol not suffre þat it helid be
Þow it a bide a ȝeer to or þre
Mordre wil oute þis my Conclusion
And ryght a noon ministers of þe toıı̄un
Hent the cart̉er/re / ⁊and so sore him pynyd
And eke the hostelere so sore engyned
Þat thei be knew hir wikkidnesse a noon
And were an hanged by þe nekke bon
Here may men see þat dremes ben to drede
And certꝭes in the same boke I rede
Ryȝt in the next Chapitre aftir this
I gabbe not so have I ioie or blisse
Too men þat wolde have passid ovir þe see
For Certen Cause in to a fer countree
If that þe wynde ne had I ben contrary
Þat made hem in a citee for to tarie
Þat stode ful mery / vpon an hauene side
But on a day ageyne þe evintide
Þe wynd gan chaunge ⁊and blew ryȝt as hēm list
Iolyf and glad þei wente / to hir reste
And casten hem ful erly for to sayle
But herkenith to that on man fil a gret mervayle
Him thouȝt a man stood bi his beddis syde
And him comaundid þat he shuld abide
And seide him thus yf þou to morow wende
Þow shalt be draynte my tale is at an ende
He wook ⁊and tolde his felow what he mette
And praid him his viage for to lette
As for that day he prayd him for to a bide
His felow þat lai bi his beddis side
Gan for to laughe ⁊and scorned hīm ful faste
No dreme qd he mai so my herte gaste
Þat I wolle lette / for to do my thingꝭes
I Sette notte a strawe bi thi dremynges
For dremes ben but vaniteis ⁊and Iapis
Men dreme al day of oulis ⁊and of apis
And of many a mase þerwiþe alle
Men dreme of thing þat neủer/re was ne shall
But sith I se þat þou wilt here a bide
And thus for slouthen wilfulli þi tyde
God wote it Rueþe me and have gode day
And thus he toke his leve ⁊and went his way
But er þat he had half his cours I seiled
Not I not whi / ne what myschaunce it eiled
But casuelli þe shippis botme it rente
And shippe ⁊and man vndir þe wat̉er/re it went
In sight of othir shippis be syde
Þat wᵗith hem seiled at þe morowe tyde
And þ̉er/refor faire ꝑper/partelot so dere
Bi suche ensamples olde maiste þᵘ lere
Þat noman shulde ben so recheles
Of dremes for I sei the doutles
Þat many a dreme ful sore is for to drede
Lo in the lyf of seint kenelm I rede
Þat was kenelphus sone þe noble kinge /
Of Mertnryke how kenelm mette a thing
A litil or he was mordred on A day

And appetit flemeth discrecioun

The lewedeste wolf that she may fynde
And leest of reputacioun that wol she take
In tyme whan hire lust to han a make
Alle thise ensamples speke I by thise men
That ben vntrewe but no thyng by wommen
For men han euere a likerous appetit
On lower thyng to parformen hir delit
Than on hire wyues be they neuer so faire
Ne neuer so trewe ne so debonaire
Flessh is so newfangel with meschaunce
That we ne konne in no thyng han plesaunce
That sowneth in to vertu any while
This Phebus which that thoughte vpon no gile
Deceyued was for al his iolitee
For vnder hym another hadde she
A man of litel reputacioun
Nat worth to Phebus in comparisoun
The moore harm is it happeth ofte so
Of which ther cometh muchel harm and wo
And so bifel whan Phebus was absent
His wyf anon hath for hire lemman sent
Hir lemman certes this is a knauyssh speche
Foryeueth it me and that I yow biseche
The wise Plato seith as ye may rede
The word moot nede acorde with the dede
If men shal telle proprely a thyng
The word moot cosyn be to the werkyng
I am a boystous man right thus seye I
Ther nys no difference trewely
Bitwix a wyf that is of heigh degree
If of hire body deshoneste she be
And a poore wenche oother than this
If it so be they werke bothe amys
But that the gentile in estat aboue
She shal be clepid his lady as in loue
And for that oother is a poore womman
She shal be clepid his wenche or his lemman
And god it woot myn owene deere brother
Men leyn that oon as lowe as lyth that oother
Right so bitwix a titlelees tiraunt
And an Outlawe or a theef erraunt
The same I seye ther is no difference
To Alisandre was told this sentence
That for the tiraunt is of gretter myght
By force of meyne for to sleen doun right
And brennen hous and hoom and make al playn
Lo therfore is he clepid a Capitayn
And for the Outlawe hath but smal meynee
And may nat doon so gret an harm as he
Ne brynge a contree to so gret meschief
Men clepen hym an Outlawe or a theef
But for I am a man noght textuel
I wol noght telle of textes neuer a del
I wol go to my tale as I bigan
Whan Phebus wyf hadde sent for hire lemman
Anon they wroghte al hire lust volage
The white Crowe that heng ay in the Cage
Biheld hir werk and seyde neuer a word
And when that hoom was come Phebus the lord
This Crowe sang Cokkow Cokkow Cokkow
What bryd quod Phebus what song syngestow
Ne were thow wont so myrily to synge
That to myn herte it was a reioysynge
To here thy voys allas what song is this
By God quod he I synge nat amys
Phebus quod he for al thy worthynesse
For al thy beautee and thy gentillesse
For al thy song and al thy Mynstralcye
For al thy waityng blered is thyn eye
With oon of litel reputacioun
Nat worth to thee in comparisoun
The montaunce of a gnat so mote I thryue
For in thy bed thy wif I sey hym et cetera
What wol ye moore the Crowe anon hym tolde
By sadde toknes and by wordes bolde
How that his wyf hadde doon hire lecherye
Hym to gret shame and to gret vileynye
And tolde hym ofte he say it with hise eyen
This Phebus gan aweyward for to wryen
And thoughte his sorweful herte brast atwo
His bowe he bente and sette ther Inne a flo
And in his Ire his wyf thanne hath he slayn
This is theffect ther nys namoore to sayn
For sorwe of which he brak his Mynstralcye
Bothe harpe and Lute and Gyterne and Sawtrye
And eek he brak hise arwes and his bowe
And after that thus spak he to the Crowe
Traytour quod he with tonge of Scorpioun
Thow hast me broght to my confusioun
Allas that I was wroght why nere I ded
O deere wyf o gemme of lustihed
That were to me so sad and eek so trewe
Now lystow ded with face pale of hewe
Ful giltlees that dorste I swere ywys
O rakel hand to doon so foule amys
O trouble wit o Ire recchelees
That vnauysed smytest giltlees
O wantrust ful of fals suspecioun
Where was thy wit and thy discrecioun
O euery man be war of rakelnesse
Ne trowe ye no thyng withouten strong witnesse
Smyt nat to soone er that ye witen why
And beth auysed wel and sobrely
Er ye do any execucioun
Vpon youre Ire for suspecioun
Allas a thousand folk hath rakel Ire
Fully fordoon or broght hem in the Myre
Allas for sorwe I wol my seluen sle
And to the Crowe o false theef seyde he
I wol thee quyte anon thy false tale
Thow songe whilom lyk a nyghtyngale
Now shaltow false theef thy song forgon
And eek thy white fetheres euerichon
Ne neuere in al thy lyf ne shaltow speke
Thus shal men on a traytour ben awreke
Thow and thyn ofspryng euere shul be blake
Ne neuere swete noyse shul ye make
But euere crye agayn tempest and rayn
In tokenynge that thurgh thee my wyf is slayn
And to the Crowe he stirte and that anon
And pulled hise white fetheres euerichon
And made hym blak and refte hym al his song
And eek his speche and out at dore hym slong
Vnto the deuel which I hym bitake
And for this cas ben alle Crowes blake
Lordynges by this ensample I yow preye
Beth war and taketh kepe what I seye
Ne telleth neuere no man in youre lyf
How that another man hath dight his wyf
He wol yow haten mortally certeyn
Daun Salomon as wise clerkes seyn
Techeth a man to kepen his tonge wel
But as I seyde I nam nat textuel
But nathelees thus taughte me my dame
My sone thenk on the Crowe agoddes name
My sone keep wel thy tonge and kepe thy freend
A wikke tonge is worse than a feend
My sono kepe wel þi tonge and kepe þi frende
My sone from a feend men may hem blesse
My sone god of his endelees goodnesse
Walled a tonge with teeth and lippes eke
For man sholde hym auyse what he speeke
My sone ful ofte for to muche speche
Hath many a man ben spilt as clerkes teche
But for litel speche auysely
Is no man shent to speke generally
My sone thy tonge sholdestow restreyne
At alle tymes but whan thow doost thy peyne
To speke of god in honour and prayere
The firste vertu sone if thow wolt leere
Is to restreyne and kepe wel thy tonge
Thus lernen children whan that they ben yonge
My sone of muchel spekyng yuele auysed
Ther lasse spekyng hadde ynow suffised
Comth muchel harm thus was me told and taught
In muchel speche synne wanteth naught
Wostow wher of a rakel tonge serueth
Right as a swerd forkitteth and forkerueth
An arm atwo my deere sone right so
A tonge kitteth frendship al atwo
A Ianglere is to god abhomynable
Rede Salomon so wys and honurable
Rede Dauid in his psalmes rede Senekke
My sone spek noght but with thyn hed thow bekke
Dissimule as thow were deef if that thow heere
A Ianglere speke of perilous matere
The flemyng seith and lerne it if thee leste
That litel Ianglyng causeth muchel reste
My sone if thow no wikked word hast seyd
Thee thar nat drede for to be biwreyd
But he that hath mysseyd I dar wel sayn
He may by no wey clepe his word agayn
Thyng that is sayd is seyd and forth it gooth
Though hym repente or be hym leef or looth
He is his thral to whom that he hath sayd
A tale of which he is now yuele apayd
My sone be war and be noon Auctour newe
Of tidynges wher they ben false or trewe
Wher so thow come amonges heye or lowe
Kepe wel thy tonge and thynk vpon the Crowe
Here is ended the Manciples tale of the Crowe
Explicit fabula mancipij
¶ The Prologe / of the Persons tale
⁊and Incipit prologus Rectoris fabule
By that the Maunciple hadde his tale al ended
The Sonne // fro the South lyne is descended
So lowe / that he nas nat to my sighte
Degrees . 29 . as of highte
Ten of the Clokke / it was so as I gesse
For eleuene foot and litel moore / or lesse
My shadwe was / at thilke tyme as there
Of swiche feet / as my lengthe parted weere
In . 6 . feet equal / of proporcioun
Ther with / the Mones exaltacioun
I mene Libra / alwey gan ascende
As we were entryng at a Thropes ende
For which oure hoost as he was wont to gye
As in this cas / oure Ioly compaignye
Seyde in this wise / lordynges euerichon
Oure lord seid lordyngꝭes eủer/reychone
Now lakketh vs / no tales / mo than oon
Fulfild is my Sentence / and my decree
I trowe / that we han herd of ech degree
Who wile now telle a tale let se
At that forsoith it lekith mee
Almoost fulfild is al myn ordinaunce
I pray to god / so yeue hym right good chaunce
That telleth this tale / to vs lustily
Sire preest quod he / artow a Vicary
Or arte a parson / sey sooth by thy fey
Be what thow be / ne breke thow nat oure pley
For euery man saue thow / hath toold his tale
Vnbokele / and shewe vs / what is in thy Male
For trewely / me thynketh by thy cheere
Thow sholdest / knette vp wel a greet matere
Telle vs a fable anon / for Cokkes bones
This parson / answerde al atones
Thow getest fable noon / ytoold for me
For Poul / that writeth vnto Thymothe
Repreueth hem / that weyuen Soothfastnesse
And tellen fables / and swich wrecchednesse
Why sholde I sowen draf out of my fest
Whan I may sowen whete / if that me lest
For which I seye / that if yow list to heere
Moralitee / and vertuous matere
And thanne / that ye wol yeue me Audience
I wole ful fayn / at Cristes reuerence
Do all the besynesse that eủer/re I can
To telle some morall thung to plese god and man
Do yow plesance / leueful / as I kan
But trusteth wel / I am a Southren man
I kan nat geste / rom / ram / ruf / by lettre
Ne god woot rym holde I but litel bettre
And therfore if yow lest I wol nat glose
I wol yow telle / a myrie tale in prose
To knytte vp al this feste / and make an ende
And Ihu for his grace / wit me sende
To shewe yow the wey / in this viage
Of thilke parfit glorious pilgrymage
That highte Ierusalem celestial
And if ye vouche sauf anon I shal
Bigynne vpon my tale / for which I preye
Telle youre auys / I kan no bettre seye
But nathelees / this meditacioun
I putte it ay / vnder correccioun
Of clerkes / for I am nat textuel
I take but the sentence / trusteth wel
Therfore / I make protestacioun
That I wol stonde / to correccioun
Vpon this word / we han assented soone
For as it semed / it was for to doone
To enden / in som vertuous sentence
And for to yeue hym / space and audience
And bede oure hoost he sholde to hym seye
That alle we / to telle his tale hym preye
Oure hoost hadde the wordes for vs alle
Sire preest quod he / now faire yow bifalle
Sey what yow list and we wol gladly heere
And with that word / he seyde in this manere
Telleth quod he / youre meditacioun
But hasteth yow / the sonne wole adoun
Beth fructuous / and that in litel space
And to do wel / god sende yow his grace

Heer eendith the persous prolog
and begynneth his tale
